book.name: Matthew
book.info: Matthew, also called Levi, formerly a tax collector, later an apostle ([link]9:9[/link]; [link]Luke 5:27[/link]), as indicated by the omitted reference to him as the host of the reception in [link]Matt. 9:10[/link] and by the special mentioning of him as the tax collector in [link]10:3[/link].
Approximately A.D. 37-40, shortly after the Lord's resurrection ([link]28:15[/link]) and prior to the destruction of the temple ([link]24:2[/link]).

The Jews in general, as indicated by the absence of explanations about Jewish customs and festivals ([link]15:2[/link], cf. [link]Mark 7:2-3[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:17[/link], cf. [link]Mark 14:12[/link]).

verse.text: The book of the [xref]a[/xref]generation of [note]1[/note]Jesus [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Christ, the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]son of David, the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]son of Abraham:
verse.note: The first name and the last name ([link]Rev. 22:21[/link]) in the New Testament is Jesus, proving that Jesus Christ is the subject and content of the New Testament.[br][br]The Bible is a book of life, and this life is a living person, the wonderful and all-inclusive Christ. The Old Testament gives a portrait, in types and prophecies, of this wonderful person as the Coming One. Now, in the New Testament, this wonderful person has come. The first page of the New Testament, in recommending this wonderful person to us, gives us His genealogy. This genealogy can be considered an abstract of the Old Testament, which in itself is the detailed genealogy of Christ. To understand the genealogy in Matthew, we need to trace the origin and history of every incident.[br][br]Christ, as the wonderful center of the entire Bible, is all-inclusive, having many aspects. The New Testament at its beginning presents four biographies to portray the four main aspects of this all-inclusive Christ. The Gospel of Matthew testifies that He is the King, the Christ of God prophesied in the Old Testament, who brings the kingdom of the heavens to the earth. The Gospel of Mark tells us that He is the Servant of God, laboring for God faithfully. Mark's account is most simple, for a servant does not warrant a detailed record. The Gospel of Luke presents a full picture of Him as the only proper and normal man who ever lived on this earth; as such a man, He is the Savior of mankind. The Gospel of John unveils Him as the Son of God, the very God Himself, who is life to God's people. Among the four Gospels, Matthew and Luke have a record of genealogy; Mark and John do not. To testify that Jesus is the King, the Christ of God prophesied in the Old Testament, Matthew needs to show us the antecedents and status of this King, to prove that He is the proper successor to the throne of David. To prove that Jesus is a proper and normal man, Luke needs to show the generations of this man, to attest that He is qualified to be the Savior of mankind. For the record of a servant, Mark does not need to tell us His origin. To unveil that Jesus is the very God, neither does John need to give us His human genealogy; rather, he declares that, as the Word of God, He is the very God in the beginning.[br][br]The kingdom, of which Christ is the King, is composed of Abraham's descendants, including both his descendants in the flesh and those in faith. Hence, the genealogy of Christ in Matthew begins with Abraham, the father of the called race, not with Adam, the father of the created race. God's kingdom is not built with the created race of Adam but with the called race of Abraham, which includes both the real Israelites ([link]Rom. 9:6-8[/link]) and the believers in Christ ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]29[/link]). To prove by relating His genealogy that Jesus is a proper man qualified to be the Savior of mankind, Luke traces His genealogy back to Adam, the first generation of mankind.

In the genealogy of Jesus given by Luke, which proves that He is a proper man, the title [i]Christ[/i] is not mentioned ([link]Luke 3:23-38[/link]). But in the genealogy of Christ given here by Matthew, which proves that He is the King, the Christ of God, the title [i]Christ[/i] is emphasized repeatedly ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]16-17[/link]).

Solomon is a type of Christ as the son of David, the One who inherits the throne and kingdom of David ([link]2 Sam. 7:12-13[/link]; [link]Luke 1:32-33[/link]). Solomon, as a type of Christ, did mainly two things: he built the temple of God in the kingdom ([link]1 Kings 6:2[/link]) and spoke the word of wisdom ([link]1 Kings 10:23-24[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:42[/link]). Christ, in fulfilling this type, is now building the real temple of God, the church, in the kingdom of God and has spoken the word of wisdom.

Isaac is a type of Christ as the son of Abraham, the One who inherits the promise and blessing God gave to Abraham ([link]Gen. 22:17-18[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link], [link]14[/link]). Isaac also, as a type of Christ, did mainly two things: he obeyed his father even unto death and was resurrected from death ([link]Gen. 22:9-10[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:19[/link]), and he took Rebekah, a Gentile woman, as his wife ([link]Gen. 24:61-67[/link]). Christ, in fulfilling this type, was put to death and offered to God and was resurrected from death, and He is taking the church as His bride out of the Gentiles.

verse.text: Abraham begot [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Isaac, and Isaac begot [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jacob, and Jacob begot [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Judah and his [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]brothers,
verse.note: Abraham begot eight sons ([link]Gen. 16:15[/link]; [link]21:2-3[/link]; [link]25:2[/link]). Among those eight, only Isaac is counted as the promised seed ([link]Rom. 9:7-8[/link]). Hence, Christ is his descendant to fulfill God's promise given to Abraham and to him ([link]Gen. 22:18[/link]; [link]26:4[/link]).

Isaac begot twin sons, Esau and Jacob ([link]Gen. 25:21-26[/link]), but only Jacob was chosen by God ([link]Rom. 9:10-13[/link]). Hence, Christ is his descendant to fulfill God's promise given to Abraham, to Isaac, and to him ([link]Gen. 22:18[/link]; [link]26:4[/link]; [link]28:14[/link]).

The birthright of the promised seed consists of the double portion of the land, the priesthood, and the kingship. Reuben, as the firstborn son of Jacob, should have inherited the birthright. But because of his defilement he lost the birthright ([link]Gen. 49:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]). The double portion of the land went to Joseph through his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim ([link]Josh. 16-17[/link]); the priesthood went to Levi ([link]Deut. 33:8-10[/link]); and the kingship was given to Judah ([link]Gen. 49:10[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:2[/link]). Hence, Christ, the King of God's kingdom, is a descendant of Judah ([link]Heb. 7:14[/link]); as such, He inherits the kingdom.
Neither the brothers of Isaac nor the brother of Jacob, but only the brothers of Judah, are mentioned in this genealogy, because only Judah's brothers were chosen by God.

verse.text: And Judah begot [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pharez and Zarah of [note]2[/note]Tamar, and Pharez begot [xref]b[/xref]Hezron, and Hezron begot Aram,
verse.note: Pharez and Zarah were twins. At the time of delivery Zarah put out his hand, and the midwife marked it with a scarlet thread, indicating that he would be the firstborn. However, Pharez preceded him to be the firstborn ([link]Gen. 38:27-30[/link]). Pharez was not chosen by man but was sent by God, proving that it was not by man's choice but by God's.

In the genealogy of Adam no woman is recorded ([link]Gen. 5:1-32[/link]), but in this genealogy of Christ five women are mentioned. Only one of these five was a chaste virgin — Mary, a descendant of the chosen race. Of her, Christ was directly born ([link]v. 16[/link]). Among the rest — Tamar, Rahab, Ruth ([link]v. 5[/link]), and Bathsheba, who had been the wife of Uriah ([link]v. 6[/link]) — some were Gentiles, some were remarried, and three were even sinful — Tamar committed incest, Rahab was a prostitute, and Bathsheba committed adultery. This indicates that Christ is related not only to the Jews but also to the Gentiles, even to the sinful people, and is the kingly Savior of typical sinners. Tamar was Judah's daughter-in-law. Judah begot Pharez and Zarah of her by incest ([link]Gen. 38:6-30[/link]). What an evil!

verse.text: And Aram begot Aminadab, and Aminadab begot Nahshon, and Nahshon begot Salmon,
And Salmon begot Boaz of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Rahab, and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Boaz begot Obed of [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Ruth, and Obed begot [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Jesse,
verse.note: Rahab was a prostitute in Jericho ([link]Josh. 2:1[/link]), a place cursed by God for eternity ([link]Josh. 6:26[/link]). After she turned to God and God's people ([link]Josh. 6:22-23[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:31[/link]) and married Salmon, a leader of Judah, the leading tribe ([link]1 Chron. 2:10-11[/link]), she brought forth Boaz, a godly man, out of whom Christ came. Regardless of our background, if we turn to God and His people and are joined to the proper person among God's people, we will bring forth proper fruit and participate in the enjoyment of the birthright of Christ.
Boaz redeemed his kinsman's inheritance and married the man's widow ([link]Ruth 4:1-17[/link]). By so doing he became a notable forefather of Christ, a great associate of Christ.

The origin of Ruth was incest, for she belonged to the tribe of Moab ([link]Ruth 1:4[/link]), the fruit of Lot's incestuous union with his daughter ([link]Gen. 19:30-38[/link]). [link]Deuteronomy 23:3[/link] forbade the Moabites to enter the assembly of Jehovah, even to the tenth generation. Ruth, however, not only was accepted by the Lord but also became one of the most important ancestors of Christ because she sought God and God's people ([link]Ruth 1:15-17[/link]; [link]2:11-12[/link]). Regardless of who we are and what our background is, as long as we have a heart that seeks God and His people, we are in a position to be accepted into the birthright of Christ.[br][br]Boaz's mother, Rahab, was a Canaanitess and a prostitute, and his wife, Ruth, was a Moabitess of incestuous origin and a widow. Both were Gentiles and of low class, yet they are associated with Christ. Christ is joined not only to the Jews but also to the Gentiles, even to those of low estate.

[link]Isaiah 11:1[/link] prophesied that Christ would be "a sprout...from the stump of Jesse, and a branch from his roots." Christ came out of Jesse. However, [link]Isa. 11:10[/link] says that Christ is the root of Jesse, indicating that Jesse came out of Christ. Jesse was one who brought forth Christ, one who branched out Christ by being rooted in Christ.

verse.text: And Jesse begot [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]David the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]king. And David begot [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Solomon of her [i]who had been the[/i] [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref][i]wife[/i] of Uriah,
verse.note: David was the eighth son of his father and was chosen and anointed by God ([link]1 Sam. 16:10-13[/link]). The number eight signifies resurrection. That David as the eighth son was chosen by God indicates that his association with Christ was in resurrection. Furthermore, he was a man after the heart of God ([link]1 Sam. 13:14[/link]) and brought in God's kingdom for Christ.[br][br]David was the last of the generations of the fathers. He was also the first of the generations of the kings. He was the conclusion of one age and the beginning of the next. He became the landmark of two ages because he brought in the kingdom of God and was closely associated with Christ.
In this genealogy, only David is called "the king" because it was through him that the kingdom with the kingship was brought in.

When David committed murder and adultery, he was rebuked by the prophet Nathan, whom God had sent purposely to condemn him ([link]2 Sam. 12:1-12[/link]). When David was condemned, he repented. Psalm 51 is the record of his repentance. He repented and God forgave him ([link]2 Sam. 12:13[/link]). Then he begot Solomon ([link]2 Sam. 12:24[/link]). Hence, Solomon is the issue of man's transgression and repentance plus God's forgiveness.[br][br]The genealogy in Matthew says that David begot Solomon, but the genealogy in Luke says that Nathan was the son of David ([link]Luke 3:31[/link]). [link]First Chronicles 3:5[/link] tells us that Nathan and Solomon were two different persons. Luke's record is the genealogy of David's son Nathan, who was Mary's forefather, whereas Matthew's record is the genealogy of David's son Solomon, who was Joseph's forefather. One genealogy is the line of Mary, the line of the wife; the other is the line of Joseph, the line of the husband. Both Mary and Joseph were descendants of David. Under God's sovereignty they were joined together by marriage, so that through Mary, Joseph was indirectly associated with Christ. Christ can be counted as a descendant of David through either Solomon or Nathan. Hence, He has two genealogies.[br][br]Strictly, Solomon was not a direct forefather of Christ. His relationship with Christ was indirect, through the marriage of Joseph, his descendant, to Mary, of whom Christ was born ([link]v. 16[/link]). The Old Testament did not say that Christ would be Solomon's descendant, but it prophesied repeatedly that Christ would be a descendant of David ([link]2 Sam. 7:13-14[/link]; [link]Jer. 23:5[/link]). Although Christ was not a direct descendant of Solomon, the Old Testament prophecies concerning Christ as a descendant of David were nevertheless fulfilled.

Uriah was a Hittite, a heathen, and his wife was Bathsheba ([link]2 Sam. 11:3[/link]). David murdered him and took Bathsheba. Hence, she was remarried as a result of murder and adultery ([link]2 Sam. 11:26-27[/link]). David, a man after the heart of God, did right in the eyes of the Lord all the days of his life, except for this one evil ([link]1 Kings 15:5[/link]). This genealogy does not say "of Bathsheba" but "of her who had been the wife of Uriah," to emphasize this great sin of David's, thus showing that Christ as the kingly Savior is related not only to the heathen but also to sinners.

verse.text: And Solomon begot [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Rehoboam, and Rehoboam begot Abijah, and Abijah begot Asa,
verse.note: Beginning with Rehoboam, the kingdom of David was divided ([link]1 Kings 11:9-12[/link]; [link]12:1-17[/link]). Of the twelve tribes, one was kept for David's sake ([link]1 Kings 11:13[/link]), that is, for Christ. Christ needed the kingdom that belonged to the house of David, because He had to be born as an heir to David's throne.[br][br]After being divided, the kingdom of David was in two parts. The northern part was called the kingdom of Israel (a universal name) and was composed of ten tribes of Israel; the southern part was called the kingdom of Judah (a local name) and was composed of two tribes, Judah and Benjamin. Although the kingdom of Israel was more universal than that of Judah, not one of the names of the kings of Israel was included in the genealogy of Christ. The kings of Israel were excluded because they were not associated with Christ. They were for something other than Christ.

verse.text: And Asa begot Jehoshaphat, and Jehoshaphat begot Joram, and [note]1[/note]Joram begot Uzziah,
verse.note: The genealogy here records that "Joram begot Uzziah." However, [link]1 Chron. 3:11-12[/link] says, "Joram his son, Ahaziah his son, Joash his son, Amaziah his son, Azariah" (who is Uzziah — [link]2 Kings 15:1[/link], [link]13[/link]). Three generations — Ahaziah, Joash, and Amaziah — were omitted. This must have been because of the evil marriage of Joram and the daughter of Ahab and Jezebel, which corrupted Joram's descendants ([link]2 Chron. 21:5-6[/link]; [link]22:1-4[/link]). In accordance with [link]Exo. 20:5[/link], three generations of Joram's descendants were cut off from the genealogy of Christ.

verse.text: And Uzziah begot Jotham, and Jotham begot Ahaz, and Ahaz begot Hezekiah,
And Hezekiah begot Manasseh, and Manasseh begot Amon, and Amon begot Josiah.
And [note]1[/note]Josiah begot [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jeconiah and his [note]3[/note]brothers at the time of the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]deportation to Babylon.
verse.note: The genealogy here records that "Josiah begot Jeconiah." However, [link]1 Chron. 3:15-16[/link] says, "The sons of Josiah...the second Jehoiakim...and the son of Jehoiakim: Jeconiah his son." One generation — Jehoiakim — was omitted from the genealogy of Christ. This must have been because he was made king by Pharaoh of Egypt and collected taxes for Pharaoh ([link]2 Kings 23:34-35[/link]).

Jeconiah was not reckoned a king in the genealogy, because he was born during the captivity and was a captive ([link]2 Chron. 36:9-10[/link] — Jehoiachin is Jeconiah). According to the prophecy in [link]Jer. 22:28-30[/link], none of Jeconiah's descendants would inherit the throne of David. If Christ had been a direct descendant of Jeconiah, He would not have been entitled to the throne of David. Although [link]Jer. 22:28-30[/link] says that all the descendants of Jeconiah are excluded from the throne of David, [link]Jer. 23:5[/link] says that God would raise up a Shoot to David, a King who would reign and prosper. This Shoot is Christ. This prophecy confirms that Christ would be the descendant of David, although not a direct descendant of Jeconiah, and would inherit the throne of David.
In this genealogy there is no mention of the brothers of any kings. However, here the brothers of Jeconiah are mentioned, proving that Jeconiah was not reckoned a king in this genealogy of Christ.
Referring to the carrying away of the children of Israel into captivity in Babylon. So in [link]v. 17[/link].

verse.text: And after the [note]1[/note]deportation to Babylon, Jeconiah begot [xref]a[/xref]Salathiel, and Salathiel begot [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zerubbabel,
verse.note: Even those who were carried away as captives to Babylon were included in this sacred record of Christ's genealogy because they had an indirect relationship with Christ through Mary, the wife of one of their descendants and the mother of Jesus.

"Jeconiah begot Salathiel, and Salathiel begot Zerubbabel." Compare this record with [link]1 Chron. 3:17-19[/link], which says, "The sons of Jeconiah...Shealtiel [i.e., Salathiel]...and Pedaiah... and the sons of Pedaiah were Zerubbabel," showing that Zerubbabel was the son of Pedaiah, Salathiel's brother. Zerubbabel was not Salathiel's son but was his nephew, and he became his heir. Perhaps this was a case in accordance with [link]Deut. 25:5-6[/link]. Even that word in Deuteronomy is related to the genealogy of Christ.[br][br]Zerubbabel was one of the leaders who returned to Jerusalem from the captivity in Babylon ([link]Ezra 5:1-2[/link]). He was also a leader in the rebuilding of God's temple ([link]Zech. 4:7-10[/link]). The Old Testament predicted that Christ, as a descendant of David, would be born in Bethlehem ([link]Micah 5:2[/link]; [link]Matt. 2:4-6[/link]). Without the return from captivity, it would not have been possible for Christ to be born in Bethlehem. God's command that the captives return was not only for the rebuilding of the temple of God but also to prepare for Christ to be born in Bethlehem. Christ needed some people to be in the proper place to bring Him to earth the first time. Similarly, for His second coming Christ needs some of His people to return from their captivity to the proper church life.

verse.text: And Zerubbabel begot Abiud, and Abiud begot Eliakim, and Eliakim begot Azor,
And Azor begot Zadok, and Zadok begot Achim, and Achim begot Eliud,
And Eliud begot Eleazar, and Eleazar begot Matthan, and Matthan begot Jacob,

And [note]1[/note]Jacob begot [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Joseph the husband of [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Mary, of whom was [xref]c[/xref]born [xref]d[/xref]Jesus, who is called [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: Here the genealogy says that "Jacob begot Joseph," but [link]Luke 3:23[/link] says, "Joseph, the son of Heli." Luke's record was "according to law" (a literal translation of "so it was thought" in [link]Luke 3:23[/link]), indicating that Joseph was not actually the son of Heli but was reckoned his son according to the law. Joseph was the son-in-law of Heli, Mary's father. This may be a case according to [link]Num. 27:1-8[/link] and [link]36:1-12[/link], in which a regulation was made by God that if any parents had only daughters as heirs, the inheritance would go to the daughters, who would then have to marry a man of their own tribe in order to keep their inheritance within that tribe. Even such a regulation in the Old Testament is related to the genealogy of Christ, showing that all Scripture is a record of Christ.

At this point the record of this genealogy does not say, "Joseph begot Jesus," which is similar to what is said of all the foregoing persons; it says, "Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus." Jesus was born of Mary, and not of Joseph, since it was prophesied that Christ would be the seed of the woman and would be born of a virgin ([link]Gen. 3:15[/link]; [link]Isa. 7:14[/link]). Christ could not have been born of Joseph because Joseph was a man and a descendant of Jeconiah, none of whose descendants could inherit the throne of David ([link]Jer. 22:28-30[/link]). However, Mary was a virgin and a descendant of David ([link]Luke 1:27[/link], [link]31-32[/link]); as such, she was the right person of whom Christ should be born. The marriage of Joseph and Mary brought Joseph into relationship with Christ and united into one the two lines of Christ's genealogy for the bringing in of Christ, as shown in this chart.[br][br]This chart shows that the generation of Jesus Christ begins from God and continues until it reaches Jesus. It proceeds from God to Adam, from Adam to Abraham, from Abraham through Isaac and Jacob, and on to David. After David it divides into two lines, the first running from Nathan to Mary and the second from Solomon to Joseph. Eventually, these two lines are brought together by the marriage of Mary and Joseph, to bring in Jesus Christ. In this way Christ was apparently a descendant of Jeconiah, who seemed to be in the line of the royal family; actually, He was not a descendant of Jeconiah, Joseph's forefather, but a descendant of David, Mary's forefather, so that He could qualify to inherit the throne of David.

This genealogy first mentions four women who were either remarried or sinful. In addition, here it mentions a chaste virgin. This indicates that all the persons named in this genealogy were born in sin, except Christ, who was born in holiness.[br][br]Abraham, David, and Mary were the three persons crucial to the bringing in of Christ. Abraham represents a life by faith; David, a life under the dealing of the cross; and Mary, a life of absolute surrender to the Lord. It was through these three kinds of lives that Christ was brought forth into humanity.
[i]Christ[/i] is emphasized here to prove that Jesus is the very Messiah (Christ) prophesied in the Old Testament.

verse.text: Thus [note]1[/note]all the generations from Abraham [note]2[/note]until David are fourteen generations, and from David [note]3[/note]until the deportation to Babylon, fourteen generations, and from the deportation to Babylon [note]4[/note]until the Christ, fourteen generations.
verse.note: This genealogy is divided into three ages: (1) from Abraham until David, fourteen generations, the age before the establishing of the kingdom; (2) from David until the deportation to Babylon, fourteen generations, the age of the kingdom; (3) from the deportation to Babylon until the Christ, again fourteen generations, the age after the fall of the kingdom. According to history, there were actually forty-five generations. By deducting from these generations the three cursed generations and the one improper generation, and then adding one by making David two generations (one, the age before the establishing of the kingdom, and the other, the age of the kingdom), the generations total forty-two, being divided into three ages of fourteen generations each. The number fourteen is composed of ten plus four. Four signifies creatures ([link]Rev. 4:6[/link]); ten signifies fullness ([link]25:1[/link]). Hence, fourteen signifies the creatures in full. Fourteen generations being multiplied by three indicates that the Triune God mingles Himself with the creatures in full.[br][br]This genealogy is of three sections: the section of the fathers, the section of the kings, and the section of the civilians, which includes the captured ones and the recovered ones. God the Father corresponds with the section of the fathers, God the Son with the section of the kings, and God the Spirit with the section of the civilians. This too indicates the mingling of the Triune God with His human creatures.[br][br]Three times fourteen is forty-two. Forty is the number for trials, temptations, and sufferings ([link]Heb. 3:9[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:2[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:8[/link]). Forty-two signifies rest and satisfaction after trial. The children of Israel traveled through forty-two stations before they entered the good land of rest. The millennial kingdom as a rest will come after the forty-two months of the great tribulation ([link]Rev. 13:5[/link]). After all the generations of trials, temptations, and sufferings, Christ came as the forty-second generation to be our rest and satisfaction.

David is the end of the generations of the fathers and the beginning of the generations of the kings. He was the one person used by God as a landmark to conclude the section of the fathers and to begin the section of the kings.
At the time of degradation no person was there as a landmark to demarcate the generations as did Abraham and David. Thus, the deportation became a landmark, a landmark of shame.

Luke's record begins with Jesus and traces back to God. Matthew's record proceeds from Abraham to Christ. Luke goes back and up to God; Matthew comes forward and down to Christ. All the generations were directed to Christ and brought in Christ. Christ is the goal, the consummation, the conclusion, the completion, and the perfection of all the generations; as such, He fulfills their prophecies, solves their problems, and meets their needs. When Christ comes, light, life, salvation, satisfaction, healing, freedom, rest, comfort, peace, and joy all come with Him. From this point on, the whole New Testament is a full expounding of this wonderful Christ, who is everything to us. Hallelujah, Christ has come!

verse.text: Now the [xref]a[/xref]origin of Jesus Christ was in this way: His mother, [xref]b[/xref]Mary, after she had been engaged to Joseph, before they came together, was found to be with child [note]1[/note]of the [xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit.
verse.note: Lit., out of. Although Christ was born of Mary ([link]v. 16[/link]), He was a child of the Holy Spirit. The birth of Christ was directly of the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 20[/link]). His source was the Holy Spirit and His element was divine. Through the virgin Mary He put on flesh and blood, the human nature, taking the likeness of the flesh ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), the likeness of men ([link]Phil. 2:7[/link]).

verse.text: And Joseph her husband, being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteous and not willing to [xref]b[/xref]disgrace her openly, intended to [note]2[/note]send her away secretly.
verse.note: A righteous man at that time was one walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord ([link]Luke 1:6[/link]), i.e., one who was living according to the law of God with the expiation made by the offerings.
Lit., release her.

verse.text: But while he pondered these things, behold, an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord appeared to him in a [xref]b[/xref]dream, saying, Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary your wife, for that which has been [note]1[/note]begotten in her is [note]2[/note]of the [xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit.
verse.note: God was first born into Mary through His Spirit; after the conception was completed, He, with the human nature, was born to be a God-man, possessing both divinity and humanity. This is the origin of Christ.
Lit., out of.

verse.text: And she will bear a [xref]a[/xref]son, and you shall call His name [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jesus, for [i]it is[/i] He [i]who[/i] will [xref]c[/xref]save His people from their sins.
verse.note: [i]Jesus[/i] is the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew name [i]Joshua[/i] ([link]Num. 13:16[/link]), which means [i]Jehovah the Savior,[/i] or [i]the salvation of Jehovah.[/i] Hence, Jesus is not only a man but Jehovah, and not only Jehovah but Jehovah becoming our salvation. Thus, He is our Savior. He is also our Joshua, the One who brings us into rest ([link]Heb. 4:8[/link]; [link]Matt. 11:28-29[/link]), which is Himself as the good land to us.

verse.text: Now all this has happened so that what was spoken by the Lord through the [note]1[/note]prophet might be [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled, saying,
verse.note: One who is commonly considered a foreteller. But in the Scriptures a prophet is one who speaks for God, speaks forth God, and predicts.

verse.text: "Behold, the [xref]a[/xref]virgin shall be with child and shall bear a [note]1[/note]son, and they shall call His name [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Emmanuel" (which is translated, [xref]c[/xref]God [note]3[/note]with us).
verse.note: This son of the virgin is the seed of the woman prophesied in [link]Gen. 3:15[/link].

Jesus was the name given by God, whereas Emmanuel, meaning [i]God with us,[/i] was the name by which man called Him. Jesus the Savior is God with us. He is God, and He is also God incarnated to dwell among us ([link]John 1:14[/link]). He is not only God but God with us.

Christ as the very Emmanuel not only was with us when He was on earth, but also is with us, since His ascension, whenever we are gathered into His name ([link]18:20[/link]). Moreover, He will be with us all the days until the consummation of the age ([link]28:20[/link]).

verse.text: And when Joseph awoke from his sleep, he did as the angel of the Lord commanded him and took to himself his wife.
And he did not know her until she [note]1[/note]bore a son. And he called His name [xref]a[/xref]Jesus.
verse.note: The birth of Christ was prepared and accomplished by God's sovereignty. By His sovereignty God brought back to Judea from the captivity in Babylon the ancestors of both Joseph and Mary under the leadership of their forefather Zerubbabel ([link]v. 12[/link]; [link]Ezra 5:1-2[/link]). Again by His sovereignty God placed both Joseph and Mary in the same city, Nazareth ([link]Luke 1:26[/link]; [link]2:4[/link]). Even more, by His sovereignty God brought Joseph and Mary together in marriage so that Christ could be brought in as the legal heir to the throne of David.

verse.text: Now after Jesus was [xref]a[/xref]born in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Bethlehem of Judea in the days of [xref]c[/xref]Herod the king, behold, [xref]d[/xref]magi from the [xref]e[/xref]east arrived in Jerusalem,
verse.note: Meaning [i]house of bread.[/i]

verse.text: Saying, Where is He who has been born [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]King of the Jews? For we saw His [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]star at its rising and have come to [xref]c[/xref]worship Him.
verse.note: Luke's record concerning the youth of Jesus proves that He is a proper man ([link]Luke 2:15-52[/link]), whereas Matthew's record, very different from Luke's, testifies that Christ is the proper King, the Christ prophesied in the Scriptures.

The Jews had the Scriptures concerning Christ. The magi from the east saw Christ's star ([link]Num. 24:17[/link]). The Jews had mental knowledge in dead letters concerning Christ, whereas the magi received a living vision concerning Him. After receiving the living vision, the magi were misled by their human concept and went to Jerusalem, the capital of the Jewish nation, where its king was presumed to be. Their being misled caused many young boys to be killed ([link]v. 16[/link]). After the magi were corrected by the Scriptures ([link]vv. 4-6[/link]), they went to Bethlehem ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]), and the star appeared to them again and led them to the place where Christ was ([link]vv. 9-10[/link]).

verse.text: And when Herod the king heard [i]this,[/i] he was troubled and all Jerusalem with him.
And gathering together all the chief [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]priests and [xref]b[/xref]scribes of the people, he inquired of them where the Christ was to be born.
verse.note: The priests were those who taught people the law ([link]Mal. 2:7[/link]), and the scribes were those who knew the Scriptures ([link]Ezra 7:6[/link]). Both the priests and the scribes had knowledge concerning the birth of Christ ([link]vv. 5-6[/link]), but, unlike the magi from the east, they did not see the vision, nor did they have the heart to seek after Christ.

verse.text: And they said to him, In [xref]a[/xref]Bethlehem of Judea, for so it is written through the prophet:

[xref]a[/xref]"And you, Bethlehem, land of Judah, by no means are you the least among the [note]1[/note]princes of Judah; for out of you shall come forth a [xref]b[/xref]Ruler, One who will [xref]c[/xref]shepherd My people Israel."
verse.note: Signifying cities.

verse.text: Then Herod, secretly calling the magi, determined accurately from them the time that the star appeared.
And sending them to Bethlehem, he said, Go and find out accurately about the child. And when you find [i]Him,[/i] report to me, so that I also may come and worship Him.

And after they heard the king, they went their way, and behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]star which they saw at its rising led them until it came and stood over [i]the place[/i] where the child was.
verse.note: When the magi were corrected by the Scriptures and restored to the right track, the star appeared to them again. Living vision always accompanies the Scriptures.

verse.text: And when they saw the star, they rejoiced exceedingly [i]with[/i] great joy.

And they came into the [note]1[/note]house and saw the [xref]a[/xref]child with [xref]b[/xref]Mary His mother. And falling down, they [note]2[/note]worshipped Him; and opening their treasures, they offered [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]gifts to Him, [xref]d[/xref]gold and [xref]e[/xref]frankincense and [xref]f[/xref]myrrh.
verse.note: The shepherds found the baby Jesus still in a manger ([link]Luke 2:16[/link]); after this, the magi from the east saw the child in the house.
They worshipped Him as they would worship God ([link]4:10[/link]).

The gifts offered to Christ by the magi were gold, frankincense, and myrrh. In figure, gold signifies the divine nature; frankincense, the fragrance of resurrection; and myrrh, the fragrance of death. The offering of these gifts by the magi was undoubtedly under the inspiration of God's Spirit, to indicate the worth of Christ's divine nature and the preciousness of His resurrection and death. In the four Gospels, which are the biographies of Jesus, the things signified by these treasures are seen throughout Jesus' life. Moreover, these precious treasures offered by the magi might have provided for the Lord's journeys from Judea to Egypt and from Egypt to Nazareth.

verse.text: And because they had been divinely instructed in a [xref]a[/xref]dream not to [note]1[/note]return to Herod, they departed by [note]2[/note]another way to their country.
verse.note: Lit., turn back.
Once we have seen Christ, we never take the same way but always take another way.

verse.text: Now when they had departed, behold, an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord appeared in a [xref]b[/xref]dream to Joseph, saying, Arise, take the child and His mother and flee into [xref]c[/xref]Egypt, and stay there until I tell you; for Herod is going to seek the child to destroy Him.
And he arose and took the child and His mother by night and departed into Egypt,

And was there until the death of Herod, in order that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fulfilled, saying, [xref]b[/xref]"Out of Egypt I called My [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Son."
verse.note: This fulfillment of the prophecy concerning Christ in [link]Hosea 11:1[/link] was carried out by God through the magi's mistake in going to Jerusalem. God is sovereign, even over our mistakes.
This prophecy joins Christ to Israel.

verse.text: Then Herod, seeing that he had been mocked by the magi, became greatly enraged, and sending out [i]men,[/i] he [note]1[/note]did away with all the boys who were in Bethlehem and in all its borders from two years old and under, according to the time that he had accurately determined from the magi.
verse.note: This was the first martyrdom in the New Testament related to Christ.

verse.text: At that time what was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled, saying,
[xref]a[/xref]"A voice in Ramah was heard, weeping and great lamentation: [note]1[/note]Rachel weeping for her children, and she would not be comforted, because they are no more."
verse.note: Rachel was buried on the way to Bethlehem ([link]Gen. 35:19[/link]; [link]48:7[/link]). Ramah, located in the territory of Benjamin ([link]Josh. 18:21-28[/link]), the son of Rachel ([link]Gen. 35:15-18[/link]), was not far from the site of Rachel's tomb. The young boys killed by Herod are considered the children of Rachel in this poetic prophecy.

verse.text: And when Herod had died, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a [xref]a[/xref]dream to Joseph in Egypt,
Saying, Arise, take the child and His mother and go into the land of Israel, for those who seek the [note]1[/note]life of the child have [xref]a[/xref]died.
verse.note: Lit., soul.

verse.text: And he arose and took the child and His mother and entered into the land of Israel.

But because he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there; and having been divinely instructed in a [xref]a[/xref]dream, he departed into the regions of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Galilee.
verse.note: Galilee was of the Gentiles ([link]4:15[/link]) and was despised by the people ([link]John 7:41[/link], [link]52[/link]). Christ was born in honored Judea but was raised in despised Galilee.

verse.text: And he came and settled in a city called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nazareth, so that what was spoken through the [note]2[/note]prophets might be [xref]b[/xref]fulfilled, He shall be called a [note]3[/note]Nazarene.
verse.note: Under God's sovereign arrangement Caesar Augustus ordered the first census of the Roman Empire ([link]Luke 2:1-3[/link]). It was through that census that Christ was born in Bethlehem ([link]Luke 2:4-7[/link]) to fulfill the prophecy concerning His birth ([link]Micah 5:2[/link]). He stayed there a short time. Then, because of Herod's persecution He was taken to Egypt ([link]vv. 13-15[/link]), and subsequently He was brought back to the land of Israel ([link]vv. 19-21[/link]). Because of Archelaus's reigning over Judea in the place of his father, Herod, Christ was brought to Nazareth, a despised city of Galilee ([link]vv. 22-23[/link]; [link]John 1:45-46[/link]), and was raised there. He was born in the esteemed town of Bethlehem but grew up in the despised city of Nazareth. Hence, He was called a Nazarene. To follow Christ requires that we heed not only the Scriptures concerning Him but also the instant leadings, such as those Joseph had in his dreams. Caring only for the Scriptures while neglecting the instant leadings may cause us to miss Christ, as did the Jewish priests and scribes. Heeding the instant leadings requires a seeking heart.
See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

The word [i]prophets,[/i] in plural, indicates that this is not a particular prophecy but a summary of the significance of several prophecies, such as the one in [link]Psa. 22:6-7[/link]. The title [i]Nazarene[/i] may refer to the branch in [link]Isa. 11:1[/link], which in Hebrew is [i]netzer.[/i] The branch there, signifying Christ, is a sprout from the stump of Jesse, the father of David. By the time Jesus was born, the throne of David had been overthrown. This means that the royal stem of David had been cut off. Now a new sprout came forth from the stump of Jesse and grew out of his roots. The emerging and growing of this sprout were in a situation of humiliation. Jesus was not born in a recognized and honored royal home, nor did He grow up in a renowned city such as Jerusalem. Rather, He was born in a poor home and grew up in a despised town. All this made Him a Nazarene, a branch — not a lofty branch of a stately tree, but a seemingly insignificant sprout from the stump of Jesse.

verse.text: Now in those days [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]John the Baptist appeared, preaching in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]wilderness of Judea
verse.note: The dispensation of law was terminated by the coming of John the Baptist ([link]11:13[/link]; [link]Luke 16:16[/link]). After the baptism by John, the preaching of the gospel of peace began ([link]Acts 10:36-37[/link]). John's preaching was the beginning of the gospel ([link]Mark 1:1-5[/link]). Hence, the dispensation of grace began with John.

John the Baptist's preaching was the initiation of God's New Testament economy. He did this preaching not in the holy temple within the holy city, where the religious and cultured people worshipped God according to their scriptural ordinances, but in the wilderness, in a "wild" way, not keeping any old regulations. This indicates that the old way of worshipping God according to the Old Testament had been repudiated and that a new way was about to be brought in. [i]Wilderness[/i] here indicates that the new way of God's New Testament economy is contrary to religion and culture. It indicates further that nothing old was left and that something new was going to be built up.

verse.text: And saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Repent, for the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of the heavens has [note]3[/note]drawn near.
verse.note: To repent is to have a change of mind issuing in regret, to have a turn in purpose.

In John the Baptist's preaching, repentance, as the opening of God's New Testament economy, involved making a turn for the kingdom of the heavens. This indicates that God's New Testament economy is focused on His kingdom. For this we should repent, change our mind, make a turn in our life-pursuit. The goal of our pursuing has been other things; now our pursuing must turn toward God and His kingdom, which in Matthew (cf. [link]Mark 1:15[/link]) is specifically and purposefully called "the kingdom of the heavens." According to the Gospel of Matthew as a whole, the kingdom of the heavens is different from the Messianic kingdom. The Messianic kingdom will be the restored kingdom of David (the rebuilt tabernacle of David — [link]Acts 15:16[/link]), made up of the children of Israel, and will be earthly and physical in nature; whereas the kingdom of the heavens is constituted of regenerated believers and is heavenly and spiritual. (See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].)

This clearly indicates that before the coming of John the Baptist, the kingdom of the heavens was not there. Even after his appearing, during his preaching, the kingdom of the heavens was still not there; it had only drawn near. At the time the Lord began His ministry, and even at the time He sent His disciples to preach, the kingdom of the heavens had still not come ([link]4:17[/link]; [link]10:7[/link]). Hence, in the first parable in [link]ch. 13[/link], the parable of the seed ([link]13:3-9[/link]), which indicates the Lord's preaching, the Lord did not say, "The kingdom of the heavens is (or, has become) like..." Not until the second parable, the parable of the tares ([link]13:24[/link]), which indicates the establishing of the church on the day of Pentecost, did the Lord say this. [link]Matthew 16:18-19[/link], in which the terms [i]church[/i] and [i]kingdom of the heavens[/i] are used interchangeably, proves that the kingdom of the heavens came when the church was established.

verse.text: For this is he who was spoken of through Isaiah the prophet, saying, [xref]a[/xref]"A voice of one crying in the [note]1[/note]wilderness, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Prepare the way of the Lord; [note]2[/note]make straight His paths."
verse.note: It was according to prophecy that John the Baptist began his ministry in the wilderness. This indicates that John's introducing of God's New Testament economy was not accidental but had been planned by God and foretold by Him through Isaiah the prophet. This implies that God intended His New Testament economy to begin in an absolutely new way.

The way, similar to a street, and the paths, similar to lanes, are a portrait of man's heart with all its parts. To repent unto the Lord with our whole being and with our whole heart and to let the Lord come in is to prepare the way of the Lord. To allow the Lord to further occupy every part of our heart, including the mind, the emotion, and the will, is to make straight the paths of the Lord. Hence, to prepare the way of the Lord and make His paths straight is to change our mind, to turn our mind toward the Lord and make our heart right, that through repentance every part and avenue of our heart may be straightened by the Lord for the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Luke 1:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: Now this John had his garment of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]camel's hair and a [xref]b[/xref]leather girdle around his loins, and his food was [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]locusts and wild honey.
verse.note: John was born a priest ([link]Luke 1:5[/link], [link]13[/link]). According to the regulations of the law, he should have worn the priestly garment, which was made mainly of fine linen ([link]Exo. 28:4[/link], [link]40-41[/link]; [link]Lev. 6:10[/link]; [link]Ezek. 44:17-18[/link]), and he should have eaten the priestly food, which was composed mainly of fine flour and the meat of the sacrifices offered to God by His people ([link]Lev. 2:1-3[/link]; [link]6:16-18[/link], [link]25-26[/link]; [link]7:31-34[/link]). However, John did altogether differently. He wore a garment of camel's hair and a leather girdle, and he ate locusts and wild honey. All these things were uncivilized, uncultured, and not according to the religious regulations. For a priestly person to wear camel's hair was an especially drastic blow to the religious mind, for the camel was considered unclean according to the Levitical regulations ([link]Lev. 11:4[/link]). In addition, John did not live in a civilized place but in the wilderness ([link]Luke 3:2[/link]). All this indicates that he had wholly abandoned the Old Testament dispensation, which had degraded into a religion mixed with human culture. His intention was to introduce God's New Testament economy, which is constituted solely of Christ and the Spirit of life.

verse.text: At that time [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem and all Judea and all the surrounding region of the [xref]b[/xref]Jordan went out to him,
And they were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized by him in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jordan River as they [xref]c[/xref]confessed their sins.
verse.note: To baptize people is to immerse them, to bury them, in water, which signifies death. John the Baptist did this to indicate that he who repents is good for nothing but burial. Further, this signifies that the old person has been terminated so that a new beginning can be realized in resurrection, to be brought in by Christ as the Life-giver. Hence, after John's ministry, Christ came. John's baptism not only terminated those who repented but also ushered them to Christ for life. Baptism in the Bible implies death and resurrection. To be baptized into water is to be put into death and buried. To be raised up from the water means to be resurrected from death.

The Jordan River was the water in which twelve stones, representing the twelve tribes of Israel, were buried and from which another twelve stones, again representing the twelve tribes of Israel, were resurrected and brought up ([link]Josh. 4:1-18[/link]). Hence, to baptize people in the Jordan River implied the burial of their old being and the resurrection of the new. Just as the crossing of the Jordan River by the children of Israel ushered them into the good land, so baptism brings people into Christ, the reality of the good land.

verse.text: But when he saw many of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pharisees and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sadducees coming to his [xref]c[/xref]baptism, he said to them, Offspring of [xref]d[/xref]vipers, who prompted you to flee from the coming [xref]e[/xref]wrath?
verse.note: The Pharisees were the strictest religious sect of the Jews ([link]Acts 26:5[/link]). This sect was formed about 200 B.C. They were proud of their superior religious living, devotion to God, and knowledge of the Scriptures. Actually, they had degraded into pretension and hypocrisy ([link]23:2-33[/link]).

The Sadducees were another sect within Judaism ([link]Acts 5:17[/link]). They did not believe in the resurrection, in angels, or in spirits ([link]22:23[/link]; [link]Acts 23:8[/link]). Both the Pharisees and the Sadducees were denounced as a brood of vipers by John the Baptist and the Lord Jesus ([link]v. 7[/link]; [link]12:34[/link]; [link]23:33[/link]). The Lord Jesus warned His disciples against their doctrines ([link]16:6[/link], [link]12[/link]). The Pharisees were considered orthodox, whereas the Sadducees were the ancient modernists.

verse.text: Produce then fruit [xref]a[/xref]worthy of your repentance.

And do not presume to say within yourselves, We have [xref]a[/xref]Abraham as [i]our[/i] father; for I tell you that God is able, out of these [xref]b[/xref]stones, to [note]1[/note]raise up [xref]c[/xref]children to Abraham.
verse.note: Because of the impenitence of the Jews, both this word and the word in [link]v. 10[/link] have been fulfilled. God has cut off the Jews and has raised up the believing Gentiles to be descendants of Abraham in faith ([link]Rom. 11:15a[/link], [link]19-20[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]28-29[/link]). John's word in this verse clearly indicates that the kingdom of the heavens preached by him is constituted not of the children of Abraham by birth but of the children of Abraham by faith; thus, it is a heavenly kingdom, not the earthly kingdom of the Messiah.

verse.text: And already the axe is laid at the root of the trees. Every [xref]a[/xref]tree therefore that does not produce good fruit is cut down and cast into the [xref]b[/xref]fire.

I baptize you in [xref]a[/xref]water unto [xref]b[/xref]repentance, but [xref]c[/xref]He who is coming after me is stronger than I, whose [xref]d[/xref]sandals I am not worthy to carry. He Himself will baptize you in the Holy [xref]e[/xref]Spirit and [note]1[/note][xref]f[/xref]fire,
verse.note: According to the context, the fire here is not the fire in [link]Acts 2:3[/link], which is related to the Holy Spirit, but is the same fire as in [link]vv. 10[/link] and [link]12[/link], the fire in the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:15[/link]), where the unbelievers will suffer eternal perdition. John's word spoken here to the Pharisees and Sadducees means that if the Pharisees and Sadducees would genuinely repent and believe in the Lord, the Lord would baptize them in the Holy Spirit that they might have eternal life; otherwise, the Lord will baptize them in fire, putting them into the lake of fire for eternal punishment. John's baptism was only for repentance, to usher people to faith in the Lord. The Lord's baptism is either for eternal life in the Holy Spirit or for eternal perdition in fire. The Lord's baptism in the Holy Spirit initiated the kingdom of the heavens, bringing His believers into the kingdom of the heavens, whereas His baptism in fire will terminate the kingdom of the heavens, putting the unbelievers into the lake of fire. Hence, the Lord's baptism in the Holy Spirit, which is based on His redemption, is the beginning of the kingdom of the heavens, whereas His baptism in fire, which is based on His judgment, is the ending of that kingdom. Thus, in this verse there are three kinds of baptisms: the baptism in water, the baptism in the Spirit, and the baptism in fire. The baptism in water by John introduced people to the kingdom of the heavens. The baptism in the Spirit by the Lord Jesus commenced and established the kingdom of the heavens on the day of Pentecost and will carry it on to its consummation at the end of this age. The baptism in fire by the Lord according to the judgment at the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]) will conclude the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: Whose [xref]a[/xref]winnowing fan is in His hand. And He will thoroughly cleanse His threshing floor and will [xref]b[/xref]gather His [note]1[/note]wheat into the barn, but the [note]1[/note]chaff He will burn up with unquenchable [xref]c[/xref]fire.
verse.note: Those typified by the wheat have life within. The Lord will baptize them in the Holy Spirit and, by rapture, gather them into the barn in the air. Those typified by the chaff, like the tares in [link]13:24-30[/link], are without life. The Lord will baptize them in fire, putting them into the lake of fire. The chaff here refers to the impenitent Jews, whereas the tares in [link]ch. 13[/link] refer to the nominal Christians. The eternal destiny of both will be the same — perdition in the lake of fire ([link]13:40-42[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus came from [xref]a[/xref]Galilee to the Jordan to John to be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]baptized by him.
verse.note: As a man, the Lord Jesus came to John the Baptist to be baptized according to God's New Testament way. Of the four Gospels, only John's does not give a record of the Lord's baptism, because John testifies that the Lord is God.

verse.text: But John tried to prevent Him, saying, It is I [i]who[/i] have need of being baptized by You, and You come to me?
But Jesus answered and said to him, Permit it for now, for it is fitting for us in this way to [xref]a[/xref]fulfill all [note]1[/note]righteousness. Then he permitted Him.
verse.note: Righteousness is to be right by living, walking, and doing things in the way God has ordained. In the Old Testament, to be righteous was to keep the law that God had given. Now God sent John the Baptist to institute baptism. To be baptized also is to fulfill righteousness before God, that is, to fulfill the requirement of God. The Lord Jesus came to John not as God but as a typical man, a real Israelite. Hence, He had to be baptized in order to keep this dispensational practice of God; otherwise, He would not have been right with God.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]having been baptized, Jesus went up immediately from the water, and behold, the [note]2[/note]heavens were [xref]a[/xref]opened to Him, and He saw the [note]3[/note]Spirit of God descending like a [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]dove and coming [xref]c[/xref]upon Him.
verse.note: The Lord was baptized not only to fulfill all righteousness according to God's ordination, but also to allow Himself to be put into death and resurrection that He might minister not in a natural way but in the way of resurrection. By being baptized, He was able to live and minister in resurrection even before His actual death and resurrection three and a half years later.

The Lord's being baptized to fulfill God's righteousness and to be put into death and resurrection brought Him three things: the open heavens, the descending Spirit of God, and the speaking of the Father. It is the same with us today.

Before the Spirit of God descended and came upon Him, the Lord Jesus was born of the Holy Spirit ([link]Luke 1:35[/link]). This proves that at the time of His baptism He already had the Spirit of God within Him. The Spirit's being within Him was for His birth. Now for His ministry the Spirit of God descended upon Him. This was the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 61:1[/link]; [link]42:1[/link]; and [link]Psa. 45:7[/link], and was carried out to anoint the new King and introduce Him to His people.

A dove is gentle, and its eyes can see only one thing at a time. Hence, it signifies gentleness and singleness in sight and purpose. By the descending of the Spirit of God like a dove upon Him, the Lord Jesus ministered in gentleness and singleness, focusing solely on the will of God.

verse.text: And behold, a [xref]a[/xref]voice out of the heavens, saying, [note]1[/note]This is My [xref]b[/xref]Son, the Beloved, in whom I have found My [xref]c[/xref]delight.
verse.note: The Spirit's descending was the anointing of Christ, whereas the Father's speaking was a testimony to Him as the beloved Son. This is a picture of the Divine Trinity: the Son rose up from the water, the Spirit descended upon the Son, and the Father spoke concerning the Son. This proves that the Father, the Son, and the Spirit exist simultaneously. This is for the accomplishing of God's economy.

verse.text: Then [note]1[/note]Jesus was led up into the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness by the Spirit to be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]tempted by the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]devil.
verse.note: After being baptized in water and anointed with the Spirit of God, Jesus as a man moved according to the leading of the Spirit. This indicates that His kingly ministry in His humanity was according to the Spirit.
First, the Spirit led the anointed King to be tempted by the devil. This temptation was a test to prove that He was qualified to be the King for the kingdom of the heavens.
The Greek word means [i]accuser, slanderer[/i] ([link]Rev. 12:9-10[/link]). The devil, Satan, accuses us before God and slanders us before men.

verse.text: And when He had [xref]a[/xref]fasted [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]forty days and forty nights, afterward He became [xref]c[/xref]hungry.
verse.note: Forty days and forty nights is a time of testing and suffering ([link]Deut. 9:9[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:8[/link]). The newly anointed King was led by the Spirit to fast for this period of time that He might enter into His kingly ministry.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tempter came and said to Him, If You are the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of God, speak that these [note]3[/note]stones may become loaves of bread.
verse.note: The tempter is the devil ([link]v. 1[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 3:5[/link]).

The newly anointed King fasted in His humanity, standing on the ground of man. On the other hand, He was also the Son of God, as God the Father had declared at His baptism ([link]3:17[/link]). For Him to accomplish His ministry for the kingdom of the heavens, He had to defeat God's enemy, the devil, Satan. This He had to do as a man. Hence, He stood as a man to confront the enemy of God. The devil, knowing this, tempted Him to leave the standing of man and assume His position as the Son of God. Forty days before, God the Father had declared from the heavens that He was the beloved Son of the Father. The subtle tempter took that declaration of God the Father as the ground from which to tempt Him. If He had assumed His position as the Son of God before the enemy, He would have lost the standing to defeat him. (See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup][/link].)

To make the stones become loaves of bread would certainly have been a miracle. This was proposed by the devil as a temptation. Many times the thought of having a miracle performed in certain situations is a temptation from the devil. The devil's temptation of the first man, Adam, concerned the matter of eating ([link]Gen. 3:1-6[/link]). His temptation here of the second man, Christ, also concerned the matter of eating. Eating is always a trap used by the devil to ensnare man, causing man to be tempted in a personal way.

verse.text: But He answered and said, [note]1[/note]It is written, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]"Man shall not live on [note]3[/note]bread alone, but on every [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]word that proceeds out through the [note]5[/note]mouth of God."
verse.note: The newly anointed King confronted the enemy's temptation not by His own word but by the word of the Scriptures.

The tempter tempted the new King to take His position as the Son of God. But He answered with the word of the Scriptures, "Man...," indicating that He stood in the position of man to deal with the enemy. The demons address Jesus as the Son of God ([link]8:29[/link]), but the evil spirits do not confess that Jesus came in the flesh ([link]1 John 4:3[/link]), because in confessing Jesus as a man they admit that they are defeated. Although the demons confess Jesus as the Son of God, the devil will not allow people to believe that He is the Son of God, because in so doing they would be saved ([link]John 20:31[/link]).
This word indicates that the Lord Jesus took the word of God in the Scriptures as His bread and lived on it.

Gk. [i]rhema,[/i] the instant word, differing from [i]logos,[/i] the constant word. In this temptation all the words quoted by the Lord from Deuteronomy were [i]logos,[/i] the constant word in the Scriptures. But when He quoted them, they became [i]rhema,[/i] the instant word applied to His situation.
All Scripture is God-breathed ([link]2 Tim. 3:16[/link]). Hence, the words in the Scriptures are the words that proceed out through the mouth of God.

verse.text: Then the devil took Him into the [xref]a[/xref]holy city and set Him on the [note]1[/note]wing of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]temple,
verse.note: The protruding parts, resembling wings, on the left and right sides of the temple's front portico; these parts were more elevated than the temple itself.

The devil's first temptation of the new King was regarding the matter of human living. Defeated in this, he turned in his second temptation to religion, tempting the new King to demonstrate that He was the Son of God by casting Himself down from the wing of the temple.

verse.text: And said to Him, If You are the [xref]a[/xref]Son of God, [note]1[/note]cast Yourself down; for [note]2[/note]it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"To His angels He shall give charge concerning You, and on [i]their[/i] hands they shall bear You up, lest You strike Your foot against a stone."
verse.note: There was no need for the Lord Jesus to do this. It was simply a temptation enticing Him to show that as the Son of God He was able to act miraculously. Any thought of doing miraculous things in religion is a temptation of the devil.
Because the Lord Jesus had defeated him by quoting the Scriptures, the tempter imitated His way and tempted Him by quoting the Scriptures, albeit in a subtle way.

verse.text: Jesus said to him, [note]1[/note]Again, it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not [note]2[/note]test the Lord your God."
verse.note: To quote the Scriptures concerning one aspect of something requires us to take into account the other aspects as well, in order to be safeguarded from the deception of the tempter. This was what the new King did here to counter the tempter's second temptation. Many times we need to tell the tempter, [i]"Again,[/i] it is written."
The Greek word means [i]try exceedingly, test thoroughly.[/i]

verse.text: Again, the devil took Him to a very high mountain and showed Him all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdoms of the [xref]b[/xref]world and their [xref]c[/xref]glory.
verse.note: Defeated in his temptation in the religious sphere, the devil presented his third temptation to the new King, this time in the realm of the glory of this world. He showed Him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. The sequence of the subtle one's temptations — first, in regard to human living; second, in regard to religion; and third, in regard to worldly glory — is especially seductive in relation to the practical affairs of human life.

verse.text: And he said to Him, [note]1[/note]All these will I give You if You will fall down and [xref]a[/xref]worship me.
verse.note: [link]Luke 4:6[/link] says that the kingdoms of the world and their glory were delivered to the devil; hence, to whomever he wills he gives them. Before his fall, Satan as the archangel was appointed by God to be the ruler of the world ([link]Ezek. 28:13-14[/link]). Hence, he is called "the ruler of this world" ([link]John 12:31[/link]) and holds all the kingdoms of this world and their glory in his hand. Seeking to be worshipped, he presented all these to tempt the newly anointed King. The heavenly King overcame this temptation, but the coming Antichrist will not ([link]Rev. 13:2[/link], [link]4[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus said to him, Go away, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Satan! For it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]only shall you serve."
verse.note: [i]Satan,[/i] from Hebrew, means [i]adversary.[/i] Satan is not only God's enemy outside God's kingdom but also God's adversary within God's kingdom, where he rebels against God.

The new King rebuked the devil for his presentation and defeated him by standing on the ground of man to worship and serve only God. To worship or to serve anything other than God for gain is always a temptation from the devil, that he may secure worship.

verse.text: Then the devil [note]1[/note]left Him, and behold, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]angels came and ministered to Him.
verse.note: The devil's temptation of the first man, Adam, was a success; his temptation of the second man, Christ, was an absolute failure. This indicates that he will have no place in the new King's kingdom of the heavens.
The angels came and ministered to the tempted King, who was here a suffering man (cf. [link]Luke 22:43[/link]).

verse.text: Now when He heard that [xref]a[/xref]John was delivered up, He [note]1[/note]withdrew into [xref]b[/xref]Galilee.
verse.note: John the Baptist ministered in the wilderness, not in the holy temple in the holy city; still, his ministry was in Judea, not far from the "holy" things. Because of the people's rejection of John, the Lord Jesus withdrew into Galilee to begin His ministry, far away from the holy temple and the holy city. This occurred sovereignly to fulfill the prophecy in [link]Isa. 9:1-2[/link].

verse.text: And leaving [xref]a[/xref]Nazareth, He came and dwelt in [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum, which is beside the sea in the borders of [xref]c[/xref]Zebulun and [xref]d[/xref]Naphtali,
In order that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled, saying,
[xref]a[/xref]"Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the way to the sea, beyond the Jordan, [note]1[/note]Galilee of the Gentiles:
verse.note: Galilee was a place with a mixed population of Jews and Gentiles. Hence, it was called "Galilee of the Gentiles" and was despised by the orthodox Jews ([link]John 7:41[/link], [link]52[/link]). The newly appointed King began His kingly ministry for the kingdom of the heavens in such a despised place, far from the capital of the country, dignified Jerusalem, with its sacred temple, the center of the orthodox religion. This implied that the ministry of the newly anointed King was for a heavenly kingdom that was different from the earthly kingdom of David (the Messianic kingdom).

verse.text: The people sitting in darkness have seen a [note]1[/note]great [xref]a[/xref]light; and to those sitting in the region and shadow of death, to them light has risen."
verse.note: The new King's ministry for the kingdom of the heavens began not with earthly power but with heavenly light, which was the King Himself as the light of life shining in the shadow of death.

verse.text: From that time Jesus began to proclaim and to say, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Repent, for the kingdom of the heavens has drawn near.
verse.note: The new King continued the preaching of His forerunner, John the Baptist ([link]3:2[/link]).

verse.text: And while He was walking [xref]a[/xref]beside the [note]1[/note]Sea of Galilee, He saw two brothers, [xref]b[/xref]Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother, [note]2[/note]casting a [note]3[/note]net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
verse.note: The new King's ministry was not in the capital but beside the sea. His forerunner's ministry began by the riverside and consisted of burying the religious and terminating their religion. The new King's ministry began by the seashore and consisted of catching men who were not very religious, men who lived around the sea instead of in the holy place, and making them fishers of men for the establishing of the kingdom of the heavens.

When Peter and Andrew were called by the Lord, they were casting a net into the sea. They were made fishers of men ([link]v. 19[/link]). Eventually, Peter became the first great fisher for the establishing of the kingdom of the heavens on the day of Pentecost ([link]Acts 2:37-42[/link]; [link]4:4[/link]).
Lit., arc-shaped net.

verse.text: And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Come after Me, and I will make you fishers of men.
And immediately leaving the nets, they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]followed Him.
verse.note: Prior to this time, in the place where John had preached, Andrew, one of the two disciples there of John the Baptist, had brought Peter to the Lord ([link]John 1:35-36[/link], [link]40-42[/link]). That was the first time Andrew and Peter had met the Lord. Here the Lord met them the second time, this time at the Sea of Galilee. They were attracted by the Lord as the great light shining in the darkness of death and followed Him for the establishing of the kingdom of the heavens in the light of life.

verse.text: And going on from there, He saw another two brothers, James the [i]son[/i] of Zebedee and [xref]a[/xref]John his brother, in the boat with Zebedee their father, [note]1[/note]mending their nets; and He [xref]b[/xref]called them.
verse.note: When James and John were called by the Lord, they were in a boat, mending their nets. Eventually, John became a real mender, mending the rents in the church by his ministry of life. (See his three Epistles and [link book="Rev."]chs. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link] of Revelation.)

verse.text: And immediately leaving the boat and their father, they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]followed Him.
verse.note: One of the two disciples of John the Baptist in [link]John 1:40[/link] was John the apostle. Thus, he must have met the Lord before, in the place where Peter first met the Lord. Here at the Sea of Galilee was the second meeting. Like Peter and Andrew, John and his brother were attracted by the Lord and followed Him.

verse.text: And Jesus went about in all of Galilee, teaching in their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]synagogues and proclaiming the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]gospel of the kingdom and [xref]c[/xref]healing every disease and every sickness among the people.
verse.note: A synagogue is a place where the Jews read and learn the Scriptures ([link]Luke 4:16-17[/link]; [link]Acts 13:14-15[/link]).

Or, good news, glad tidings. In this book the gospel is called "the gospel of the kingdom." It includes not only forgiveness of sins (cf. [link]Luke 24:47[/link]) and the imparting of life (cf. [link]John 20:31[/link]) but also the kingdom of the heavens ([link]24:14[/link]) with the power of the coming age ([link]Heb. 6:5[/link]), the power to cast out demons and heal diseases ([link]Isa. 35:5-6[/link]; [link]Matt. 10:1[/link]). Both forgiveness of sins and the imparting of life are for the kingdom.

verse.text: And the report concerning Him went out into all of Syria; and they brought to Him all who were ill, those afflicted with various diseases and torments and those [xref]a[/xref]possessed by demons and epileptics and paralytics; and He healed them.
And great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]crowds followed Him from Galilee and [note]2[/note]Decapolis and Jerusalem and Judea and [i]from[/i] beyond the Jordan.
verse.note: Under the shining of the new King as the great light shining in the darkness, great crowds were attracted to follow Him for the kingdom of the heavens.
A district of ten cities.

verse.text: And when He saw the [xref]a[/xref]crowds, He [note]1[/note]went up to the [xref]b[/xref]mountain. And after He sat down, His [note]2[/note]disciples came to Him.
verse.note: The new King called His followers by the seashore, but to give them the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens, He went up to the mountain. This indicates that for the realization of the kingdom of the heavens, we need to go higher with Him.

When the new King sat down on the mountain, His disciples, not the crowds, came to Him to be His audience. Eventually, not only the believing Jews but also the discipled nations (the Gentiles — [link]28:19[/link]) became His disciples. Later the disciples were called Christians ([link]Acts 11:26[/link]). Hence, the word the new King spoke on the mountain in [link]chs. 5-7[/link], concerning the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens, was spoken to the believers of the New Testament, not to the Jews of the Old Testament.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]opening His mouth, He taught them, saying,
[note]1[/note]Blessed are the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]poor in [note]3[/note]spirit, for theirs is the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of the heavens.
verse.note: The Greek word implies [i]happy.[/i] It may also be rendered [i]blessed and happy.[/i] So in succeeding verses. The word spoken by the new King, being the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens, is a revelation of the spiritual living and heavenly principles of the kingdom of the heavens. It is composed of seven sections. The first section, [link]vv. 3-12[/link], depicts the nature of the people of the kingdom of the heavens, who are under nine blessings. They are people who are poor in spirit, who mourn for the present situation, who are meek in suffering opposition, who are hungry and thirsty for righteousness, who are merciful toward others, who are pure in heart, who make peace, who suffer persecution for righteousness, and who are reproached and evilly spoken of because of the Lord.

To be poor in spirit is not only to be humble but also to be emptied in our spirit, in the depth of our being, not holding on to the old things of the old dispensation but unloaded to receive the new things, the things of the kingdom of the heavens.

[i]Spirit[/i] here refers not to the Spirit of God but to our human spirit, the deepest part of our being, the organ by which we contact God and realize spiritual things. We need to be poor, emptied, unloaded, in this part of our being that we may realize and possess the kingdom of the heavens. This implies that the kingdom of the heavens is spiritual, not material.

[i]Kingdom of the heavens[/i] is a term used exclusively by Matthew, indicating that the kingdom of the heavens differs from the kingdom of God (see chart on pp. 22-23 in the printed edition), the latter being mentioned in the other three Gospels. The kingdom of God is God's general reign from eternity past to eternity future. It comprises eternity without beginning before the foundation of the world, the chosen patriarchs (including the paradise of Adam), the nation of Israel in the Old Testament, the church in the New Testament, the coming millennial kingdom (including its heavenly part, the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, and its earthly part, the Messianic kingdom), and the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem in eternity without end. The kingdom of the heavens is a specific section within the kingdom of God, a section composed only of the church today and the heavenly part of the coming millennial kingdom. Hence, in the New Testament, especially in the other three Gospels, the kingdom of the heavens, a section of the kingdom of God, is also called "the kingdom of God." In the Old Testament the kingdom of God, generally, already existed with the nation of Israel ([link]21:43[/link]); the kingdom of the heavens, specifically, had still not come, and it only drew near when John the Baptist came ([link]3:1-2[/link]; [link]11:11-12[/link]).[br][br]According to Matthew there are three aspects concerning the kingdom of the heavens: the reality, the appearance, and the manifestation. The reality of the kingdom of the heavens is the inward content of the kingdom of the heavens in its heavenly and spiritual nature, as revealed by the new King on the mountain in [link]chs. 5-7[/link]. The appearance of the kingdom of the heavens is the outward state of the kingdom of the heavens in name, as revealed by the King on the seashore in [link]ch. 13[/link]. The manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens is the practical coming of the kingdom of the heavens in power, as unveiled by the King on the Mount of Olives in [link]chs. 24-25[/link]. Both the reality and the appearance of the kingdom of the heavens are with the church today. The reality of the kingdom of the heavens is the proper church life ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), which exists in the appearance of the kingdom of the heavens, known as Christendom. The manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens is the heavenly part of the coming millennial kingdom, which is referred to as the kingdom of the Father in [link]13:43[/link]; the earthly part of the millennial kingdom is the Messianic kingdom, which is referred to as the kingdom of the Son of Man in [link]13:41[/link], and which is the restored tabernacle of David, the kingdom of David ([link]Acts 15:16[/link]). In the heavenly part of the millennial kingdom, which is the kingdom of the heavens manifested in power, the overcoming believers will reign with Christ for a thousand years ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]); in the earthly part of the millennial kingdom, which is the Messianic kingdom on earth, the saved remnant of Israel will be the priests and will teach the nations to worship God ([link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]).[br][br]If we are poor in spirit, the kingdom of the heavens is ours: we are in its reality now in the church age, and we will share in its manifestation in the kingdom age.

verse.text: Blessed are those who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mourn, for they shall be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]comforted.
verse.note: The entire situation of the world is negative toward God's economy. Satan, sin, self, darkness, and worldliness predominate among all people on earth. God's glory is insulted, Christ is rejected, the Holy Spirit is frustrated, the church is desolate, self is corrupt, and the whole world is evil. God wants us to mourn over such a situation.
If we mourn according to God and His economy, we will be comforted by being rewarded with the kingdom of the heavens. We will see God's heavenly ruling over the entire negative situation.

verse.text: Blessed are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]meek, for they shall [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]inherit the earth.
verse.note: To be meek means not to resist the world's opposition but to suffer it willingly.
If we are meek, willing to suffer the world's opposition in this age, we will inherit the earth in the coming age, as revealed in [link]Heb. 2:5-8[/link] and [link]Luke 19:17[/link], [link]19[/link].

verse.text: Blessed are those who hunger and [xref]a[/xref]thirst for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness, for they shall be [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]satisfied.
