verse.note: Righteousness here denotes our being right in our behavior. We need to hunger and thirst for this righteousness, to seek after such righteousness, that we may enter into the kingdom of the heavens ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]20[/link]).
If we hunger and thirst for righteousness, God will grant us the very righteousness we seek, that we may be satisfied.

verse.text: Blessed are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]merciful, for they shall be [note]2[/note]shown mercy.
verse.note: To be righteous is to give one what he deserves, whereas to be merciful is to give one what he does not deserve. For the kingdom of the heavens we need to be not only righteous but also merciful.

To receive mercy is to receive what we do not deserve. If we are merciful to others, the Lord will give us mercy ([link]2 Tim. 1:16[/link], [link]18[/link]), especially at His judgment seat ([link]James 2:12-13[/link]).

verse.text: Blessed are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pure in heart, for they shall [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]see God.
verse.note: To be pure in heart is to be single in purpose, to have the single goal of accomplishing God's will for God's glory ([link]1 Cor. 10:31[/link]). This is for the kingdom of the heavens. Our spirit is the organ by which we receive Christ ([link]John 1:12[/link]; [link]3:6[/link]), whereas our heart is the ground where Christ as the seed of life grows ([link]13:19[/link]). For the kingdom of the heavens we need to be poor in spirit, empty in our spirit, that we may receive Christ. Also, we need to be pure, single, in our heart that Christ may grow in us without frustration.
If we are pure in heart in seeking God, we will see God. Seeing God is a reward to the pure in heart. This blessing is both for today and for the coming age.

verse.text: Blessed are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peacemakers, for they shall be called the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sons of God.
verse.note: Satan, the rebellious one, is the instigator of all rebellion. For the kingdom of the heavens, under its heavenly ruling, we must be those who make peace among men ([link]Heb. 12:14[/link]).

Our Father is the God of peace ([link]Rom. 15:33[/link]; [link]16:20[/link]), having a peaceful life with a peaceful nature. As those born of Him, if we would be peacemakers, we must walk in His divine life and according to His divine nature. In this way we will express His life and nature and be called the sons of God.

verse.text: Blessed are those who are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]persecuted for the sake of [xref]b[/xref]righteousness, for [note]2[/note]theirs is the [xref]c[/xref]kingdom of the heavens.
verse.note: The whole world lies in the evil one ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]) and is filled with unrighteousness. If we hunger and thirst for righteousness, we will be persecuted for the sake of righteousness. For the sake of the kingdom of the heavens, we need to pay a price for the righteousness that we seek.
If we seek for righteousness at a cost, the kingdom of the heavens becomes ours: we are in its reality now, and we will be rewarded with its manifestation in the coming age.

verse.text: Blessed are you when they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reproach and [xref]b[/xref]persecute you, and while speaking lies, say every [xref]c[/xref]evil thing against you [note]2[/note]because of Me.
verse.note: When we live a life for the kingdom of the heavens, in the spiritual nature of the kingdom and according to the heavenly principles of the kingdom, we are reproached, persecuted, and evilly spoken of, mostly by the religious people, who hold to their traditional religious concepts. The Jewish religionists did all these things to the apostles in the early days of the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Acts 5:41[/link]; [link]13:45[/link], [link]50[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:8[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:8[/link]).

The persecution in [link]v. 10[/link] is for the sake of righteousness, i.e., is due to our seeking for righteousness, whereas the persecution in [link]v. 11[/link] is directly because of Christ, the new King, i.e., because of our following Him.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Rejoice and exult, for your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]reward is great in the heavens; for so they [xref]c[/xref]persecuted the [note]2[/note]prophets who were before you.
verse.note: This reward of the ninth blessing indicates that the results of the foregoing eight blessings also are rewards. This reward is great and is in the heavens; it is a heavenly reward, not an earthly one.
See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]You are the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]salt of the earth. But if the salt has become [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]tasteless, with what shall it be salted? It is [xref]c[/xref]no longer good for anything except to be [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]cast out and [note]5[/note]trampled underfoot by men.
verse.note: The second section of the new King's word given on the mountain, [link]vv. 13-16[/link], concerns the influence of the people of the kingdom of the heavens on the world. They are the salt to the corrupted earth and the light to the darkened world.

Salt, by nature, is an element that kills and eliminates the germs of corruption. To the corrupted earth the people of the kingdom of the heavens are such an element, keeping the earth from being fully corrupted.
For the kingdom people to become tasteless means that they lose their salting function. They become the same as the earthly people and are indistinguishable from the unbelievers.
To be cast out is to be put away from the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Luke 14:35[/link]).
To be trampled underfoot by men is to be treated as useless dust.

verse.text: You are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]light of the world. It is impossible for a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]city situated upon a mountain to be hidden.
verse.note: Light is the shining of a lamp to enlighten those in darkness. To the darkened world the people of the kingdom of the heavens are such a light, effacing the world's darkness. In nature they are the healing salt, and in behavior they are the shining light.

As the shining light, the kingdom people are like a city situated upon a mountain, a city that cannot be hidden. This will ultimately consummate in the holy city, the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:10-11[/link], [link]23-24[/link]).

verse.text: Nor do [i]men[/i] light a [xref]a[/xref]lamp and place it under the [note]1[/note]bushel, but on the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]lampstand; and it shines to all who are in the house.
verse.note: A bushel is an instrument for measuring grain. A lighted lamp placed under a bushel cannot shine out its light. The kingdom people as the lighted lamp should not be covered by a bushel, an item pertaining to food, concern for which causes people to be anxious ([link]6:25[/link]).

The light as a city on a mountain shines over the outsiders, whereas the lighted lamp on the lampstand shines over those who are in the house. As a city on a mountain, the light cannot be hidden, and as the lamp on the lampstand, the light should not be hidden.

verse.text: In the same way, let your light [xref]a[/xref]shine before men, so that they may see your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]good works and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glorify your [note]3[/note]Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: Good works constitute the behavior of the kingdom people; through such works men can see God and be brought to Him.
To glorify God the Father is to give Him the glory. Glory is God expressed. When the kingdom people express God in their behavior and good works, men see God and give the glory to God.
The title [i]your Father[/i] proves that the disciples, who were the new King's audience, were regenerated children of God ([link]John 1:12[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:6[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do not think that I have come to abolish the [xref]a[/xref]law or the prophets; I have not come to abolish, but to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fulfill.
verse.note: The third section of the King's word on the mountain, [link]vv. 17-48[/link], concerns the law of the people of the kingdom of the heavens.

Here for Christ to fulfill the law means (1) that, on the positive side, He kept the law, (2) that, on the negative side, through His substitutionary death on the cross He fulfilled the requirement of the law, and (3) that in this section He complemented the old law with His new law, as repeatedly expressed by the word "But I say to (or, tell) you" ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]32[/link], [link]34[/link], [link]39[/link], [link]44[/link]). Christ's keeping of the law qualified Him to fulfill the requirement of the law through His substitutionary death on the cross. Christ's fulfilling of the requirement of the law through His substitutionary death on the cross brought in the resurrection life to complement the law, to fill the law to the full. The old law, the lower law, with the demand that it be kept and the requirement that man be punished, is over. The kingdom people, as the children of the Father, now need to fulfill only the new law, the higher law, by the resurrection life, which is the eternal life of the Father. The old law was given through Moses, whereas the new law was decreed by Christ personally.[br][br]Concerning the law there are two aspects: the commandments of the law and the principle of the law. The commandments of the law were fulfilled and complemented by the Lord's coming, whereas the principle of the law was replaced by the principle of faith according to God's New Testament economy.

verse.text: For truly I say to you, Until [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heaven and earth pass away, one [note]2[/note]iota or one [note]3[/note]serif shall by no means pass away from the law until all come to pass.
verse.note: After the millennial kingdom the old heaven and old earth will pass away when the new heaven and new earth come in ([link]Rev. 21:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:11-12[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:10-13[/link]). What is covered by the law extends only to the end of the millennial kingdom, whereas what is covered by the prophets extends to the new heaven and new earth ([link]Isa. 65:17[/link]; [link]66:22[/link]). This is why both the law and the prophets are referred to in [link]v. 17[/link], but only the law, not the prophets, is mentioned in [link]v. 18[/link].
The Greek equivalent of the Hebrew [i]yod,[/i] the smallest Hebrew letter, which is shaped like a comma.
Gk. [i]keraia,[/i] a horn, a projection; referring to a mark used with the Hebrew letters.

verse.text: Therefore whoever annuls one of the [xref]a[/xref]least of these [note]1[/note]commandments, and teaches men so, shall be called the [xref]b[/xref]least in the [xref]c[/xref]kingdom of the heavens; but whoever practices and teaches [i]them,[/i] he shall be called [xref]d[/xref]great in the kingdom of the heavens.
verse.note: [i]Commandments[/i] here refers to the law in [link]v. 18[/link]. The kingdom people not only fulfill the law but also complement it. Hence, they actually do not annul any commandments of the law.

verse.text: For I say to you that unless your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteousness surpasses that of the [note]2[/note]scribes and Pharisees, you shall by no means [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]enter into the kingdom of the heavens.
verse.note: Righteousness here does not refer only to objective righteousness, which is the Christ whom we receive when we believe in Him and are thus justified before God ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:26[/link]); it refers even more to subjective righteousness, which is the indwelling Christ lived out of us as our righteousness that we may live in the reality of the kingdom today and enter into its manifestation in the future. This subjective righteousness is obtained not by merely the fulfilling of the old law, but by the complementing of the old law through the fulfilling of the new law of the kingdom of the heavens given by the new King here in this section of the Word. This righteousness of the kingdom people, which is according to the new law of the kingdom, surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, which is according to the old law. It is impossible for our natural life to gain this surpassing righteousness; it can be produced only by a higher life, the resurrection life of Christ. This righteousness, which is likened to the wedding garment ([link]22:11-12[/link]), qualifies us to participate in the wedding of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 19:7-8[/link]) and inherit the kingdom of the heavens in its manifestation, that is, to enter into the kingdom of the heavens in the future.[br][br]The righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees is the righteousness of letters, which they practiced by their own life according to the old law of letters; the surpassing righteousness of the kingdom people is the righteousness of life, which they live out by taking Christ as their life according to the new law of life. Both in nature and in standard, the righteousness of life far surpasses the lifeless righteousness practiced by the scribes and Pharisees.
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

Entrance into the kingdom of God requires regeneration as a new beginning of our life ([link]John 3:3[/link], [link]5[/link]), but entrance into the kingdom of the heavens demands surpassing righteousness in our living after regeneration. To enter into the kingdom of the heavens is to live in its reality today and to participate in its manifestation in the future.

verse.text: You have heard that it was said to the ancients, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not murder, and whoever murders shall be liable to the [xref]b[/xref]judgment."

But [note]1[/note]I say to you that everyone who is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]angry with his [note]3[/note]brother shall be liable to the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]judgment. And whoever says to his [note]3[/note]brother, [note]5[/note]Raca, shall be liable to [i]the judgment of[/i] the [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]Sanhedrin; and whoever says, [note]7[/note]Moreh, shall be liable to the [note]8[/note][xref]d[/xref]Gehenna of fire.
verse.note: The words that "you have heard" ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]33[/link], [link]38[/link], [link]43[/link]) are the law of the old dispensation, whereas the words that "I say to (or, tell) you" ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]32[/link], [link]34[/link], [link]39[/link], [link]44[/link]) are the new law of the kingdom, which complements the law of the old dispensation.

The law of the old dispensation deals with the act of murder ([link]v. 21[/link]), but the new law of the kingdom deals with anger, the motive of murder. Hence, the demand of the new law of the kingdom is deeper than the requirement of the law of the old dispensation. To meet the demand of the new law of the kingdom, the higher life of the new creation is needed.
The word [i]brother[/i] proves that the King's word here is spoken to believers.

In this verse there are three kinds of judgments. The first is the judgment at the gate of the city, which is the district judgment. The second is the judgment by the Sanhedrin, which is a higher judgment. The third is the judgment by God through the Gehenna of fire, which is the highest judgment. These three kinds of judgments were mentioned here by the new King, who used figures from the Jewish background because His entire audience was Jewish. However, in regard to the kingdom people, the believers of the New Testament, all these judgments refer to the judgment of the Lord at the judgment seat of Christ, as revealed in [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 4:4-5[/link]; [link]3:13-15[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]; and [link]Heb. 10:27[/link], [link]30[/link]. This clearly reveals that the New Testament believers, although forgiven by God forever, are still liable to the Lord's judgment, a judgment not for perdition but for discipline, if they sin against the new law of the kingdom as given here. However, when we sin against the new law of the kingdom, we will be forgiven and cleansed by the blood of the Lord Jesus if we repent and confess our sins ([link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]9[/link]).
I.e., stupid, good-for-nothing. An expression of contempt.

The Sanhedrin was a council composed of the chief priests, the elders, the lawyers, and the scribes. It was the highest court of the Jews ([link]Luke 22:66[/link]; [link]Acts 4:5-6[/link], [link]15[/link]; [link]5:27[/link], [link]34[/link], [link]41[/link]).
I.e., fool. A Hebrew expression of condemnation indicating a rebel ([link]Num. 20:10[/link]). This expression is more serious than "Raca," an expression of contempt.

[i]Gehenna,[/i] valley of Henna, is equivalent to the Hebrew [i]Ge Hinnom,[/i] valley of Hinnom. Also called Tophet, or Topheth ([link]2 Kings 23:10[/link]; [link]Isa. 30:33[/link]; [link]Jer. 19:13[/link]), it is a deep valley near Jerusalem and was the refuse-place of the city, where all kinds of filth and the bodies of criminals were cast for burning. Because of its continual fire, it became the symbol of the place of eternal punishment, the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:15[/link]). This word is used also in [link]vv. 29-30[/link]; [link]10:28[/link]; [link]18:9[/link]; [link]23:15[/link], [link]33[/link]; [link]Mark 9:43[/link], [link]45[/link], [link]47[/link]; [link]Luke 12:5[/link]; and [link]James 3:6[/link].

verse.text: Therefore if you are offering your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gift at the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]altar and there you remember that your [xref]c[/xref]brother has [note]3[/note]something against you,
verse.note: A sacrifice, such as the sacrifice for sin, is for dealing with sin, whereas a gift is for fellowship with God.

The altar was a piece of furniture ([link]Exo. 27:1-8[/link]) in the outer court of the temple ([link]1 Kings 8:64[/link]). On the altar all the sacrifices and gifts were offered ([link]Lev. 1:9[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]17[/link]). In decreeing the new law of the kingdom, the King referred here to the gift and altar of the old dispensation because during the period of His ministry on earth, a transitional period, the ritual law of the old dispensation had not yet come to an end.[br][br](In the four Gospels, before His death and resurrection, in matters regarding the outward circumstances, the Lord treated His disciples as Jews according to the old law, whereas in matters concerning spirit and life, He considered them believers, constituents of the church, according to the New Testament economy.)
[i]Something against you[/i] here must refer to an offense caused by the anger or scolding in [link]v. 22[/link].

verse.text: Leave your gift there before the altar, and [note]1[/note]first go and [note]2[/note]be [xref]a[/xref]reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.
verse.note: We must first be reconciled to our brother so that our remembrance of the offense can be removed and our conscience can be void of offense. Then we can come and offer our gift to the Lord and fellowship with Him with a pure conscience. The King of the kingdom will never allow two brothers who are not reconciled to each other either to share the kingdom in its reality or to reign in its manifestation.
Or, placate.

verse.text: Be well disposed [note]1[/note]quickly toward your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]opponent at law, while you are with him [note]3[/note]on the way, lest the opponent [note]4[/note]deliver you to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you be thrown into prison.
verse.note: Be well disposed quickly, lest you die, your opponent die, or the Lord come back, thus leaving you no opportunity to be reconciled to your opponent.
I.e., a plaintiff.
[i]On the way[/i] signifies that we are still living in this life.

This will take place at the judgment seat of Christ when He comes back ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link]). The judge will be the Lord, the officer will be the angel, and the prison will be the place of discipline.

verse.text: Truly I say to you, You shall by no means [note]1[/note]come out from there until you [xref]a[/xref]pay the last [note]2[/note]quadrans.
verse.note: [i]Come out from there[/i] (prison) refers to being forgiven in the coming age, the millennium.

A Roman quadrans was a small brass coin equal to a quarter of an assarion, which was equal to one cent. The meaning here is that regarding even the smallest matter we need to make a thorough clearance. This shows the strictness of the new law.

verse.text: You have heard that it was said, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not commit adultery."
But I say to you that everyone who [xref]a[/xref]looks at a woman in order to lust after her has already committed [xref]b[/xref]adultery with her in his [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]heart.
verse.note: The law of the old dispensation deals with the outward act of adultery, whereas the new law of the kingdom deals with the inward motive of the heart.

verse.text: So if your right [xref]a[/xref]eye stumbles you, [note]1[/note]pluck it out and cast [i]it[/i] from you; for it is more profitable for you that one of your members perish than for your whole body to be cast into [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Gehenna.
verse.note: The emphasis of the new law of the kingdom in this verse and in [link]v. 30[/link] indicates the seriousness of sin in relation to the kingdom of the heavens and the need to put away the motive of sin at any cost. The actions described in these verses were not meant to be carried out literally; they can be carried out only spiritually, as revealed in [link]Rom. 8:13[/link] and [link]Col. 3:5[/link].
See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup][/link]. So in the next verse.

verse.text: And if your right [xref]a[/xref]hand stumbles you, [note]1[/note]cut it off and cast [i]it[/i] from you, for it is more profitable for you that one of your members perish than for your whole body to pass away into [xref]b[/xref]Gehenna.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And it was said, [xref]a[/xref]Whoever [note]1[/note]divorces his wife, let him give her a certificate of divorce.
verse.note: Lit., releases. So in the next verse.

verse.text: But I say to you that [note]1[/note]everyone who [xref]a[/xref]divorces his wife, except for the cause of [note]2[/note]fornication, causes her to commit adultery, and whoever marries her who has been divorced commits adultery.
verse.note: What the King decreed in [link]vv. 21-30[/link] as the new law of the kingdom complemented the law of the old dispensation, whereas what the King proclaimed in [link]vv. 31-48[/link] as the new law of the kingdom changed the law of the old dispensation. In the old dispensation the law concerning divorce was ordained because of the people's hardness of heart; that law was not according to God's design in the beginning ([link]19:7-8[/link]). The King's new decree recovered marriage back to the beginning, back to God's design for it ([link]19:4-6[/link]).
The marriage tie can be broken only by death ([link]Rom. 7:3[/link]) or fornication. Hence, to divorce for any other reason is to commit adultery.

verse.text: Again, you have heard that it was said to the ancients, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"You shall not break an oath, but you shall [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]render to the Lord your oaths."
verse.note: Or, You shall not swear falsely.
Lit., repay. An oath includes a vow that needs to be repaid. Hence, to repay what is vowed is to render our oaths.

verse.text: But I tell you [xref]a[/xref]not to swear at all; neither by [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]heaven, because it is the throne of God;
verse.note: The new law of the kingdom forbids the kingdom people to swear in any manner — by heaven, by the earth, unto Jerusalem, or by their head — because heaven, the earth, Jerusalem, and their head are not under their control but under God's.

verse.text: Nor by the [xref]a[/xref]earth, because it is the footstool of His feet; nor unto Jerusalem, because it is the [xref]b[/xref]city of the great King;
Neither shall you swear by your head, because you cannot make one hair white or black.
But let your word be, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Yes, yes; No, no; for anything more than these is [note]2[/note]of [note]3[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]evil one.
verse.note: The word of the kingdom people should be simple and true: "Yes, yes; No, no." They should not try to convince others with many words; they should be those who are true and of few words.
Lit., out of.
Or, evil.

verse.text: You have heard that it was said, [xref]a[/xref]"An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth."
But I tell you [xref]a[/xref]not to resist him who is evil; rather whoever [xref]b[/xref]slaps you on your right cheek, [note]1[/note]turn to him the other also.
verse.note: Turning to the striker the other cheek also, yielding to the suer the cloak also ([link]v. 40[/link]), and going with the compeller the second mile ([link]v. 41[/link]) prove that the kingdom people have the power to suffer instead of resisting, and the power to walk not in the flesh or the soul for their own interests but in the spirit for the kingdom.

verse.text: And to him who wishes to [xref]a[/xref]sue you and take your [note]1[/note]tunic, yield to him your cloak also;
verse.note: A shirt-like undergarment. So throughout the book.

verse.text: And whoever compels you to go one [note]1[/note]mile, go with him two.
verse.note: An ancient Roman mile, equal to a thousand paces.

verse.text: To him who asks of you, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]give; and from him who wants to [xref]b[/xref]borrow from you, do not turn away.
verse.note: Giving to one who asks and not turning away from a borrower prove that the kingdom people do not care for material things and are not possessed by them.

verse.text: You have heard that it was said, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall love your neighbor and hate your [xref]b[/xref]enemy."
But I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]Love your enemies, and [xref]b[/xref]pray for those who [xref]c[/xref]persecute you,

So that you may become [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sons of your Father who is in the heavens, because He causes His sun to [xref]b[/xref]rise on the evil and the good and [note]2[/note]sends [xref]c[/xref]rain on the just and the unjust.
verse.note: The title [i]sons of your Father[/i] is a strong proof that the kingdom people, who are the audience here for the new King's decree on the mountain, are the regenerated believers of the New Testament.
The sending of rain on the just and the unjust occurs in the age of grace, but in the coming age, the age of the kingdom, no rain will come on the unjust ([link]Zech. 14:17-18[/link]).

verse.text: For if you [xref]a[/xref]love those who love you, what [note]1[/note]reward do you have? Do not even the [note]2[/note]tax collectors do the same?
verse.note: The kingdom people who observe the new law of the kingdom in the kingdom's reality will be given a reward in the manifestation of the kingdom. The reward differs from salvation. A person can be saved yet not be rewarded. (See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link].)

Those who collected the taxes levied by the Romans. Nearly all of them abused their office by making excessive demands based on false accusation ([link]Luke 3:12-13[/link]; [link]19:2[/link], [link]8[/link]). Paying taxes to the Romans was very bitter to the Jews. Those engaged in collecting taxes were despised by the people and counted unworthy of respect ([link]Luke 18:9-10[/link]). Hence, they were classed with sinners ([link]9:10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And if you greet only your brothers, what better thing are you doing? Do not even the [xref]a[/xref]Gentiles do the same?
You therefore shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]perfect [xref]b[/xref]as your heavenly Father is perfect.
verse.note: For the kingdom people to be perfect as their heavenly Father is perfect means that they are perfect in His love. They are the Father's children, having the Father's divine life and divine nature. Hence, they can be perfect as their Father is. The demand of the new law of the kingdom is much higher than the requirement of the law of the old dispensation. This higher demand can be met only by the Father's divine life, not by the natural life. The kingdom of the heavens is the highest demand, and the divine life of the Father is the highest supply to meet that demand. First, the gospel presents in the Gospel of Matthew the kingdom of the heavens as the highest demand, and last, it affords us in the Gospel of John the divine life of the heavenly Father as the highest supply, by which we can have the highest living of the kingdom of the heavens. The demand of the new law of the kingdom in [link]chs. 5-7[/link] is actually the expression of the new life, the divine life, which is within the regenerated kingdom people. This demand opens up the inner being of the regenerated people, showing them that they are able to attain to such a high level and to have such a high living.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But take care not to do your [note]2[/note]righteousness [note]3[/note]before men in order to be [xref]a[/xref]gazed at by them; otherwise, you have no reward with your [note]4[/note]Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: The fourth section of the King's decree on the mountain, [link]vv. 1-18[/link], concerns the righteous deeds of the kingdom people.
Righteousness here denotes righteous deeds, such as giving alms ([link]vv. 2-4[/link]), praying ([link]vv. 5-15[/link]), and fasting ([link]vv. 16-18[/link]).

Man's flesh, seeking to glorify itself, always wants to do good deeds before men in order to gain men's praise. But the kingdom people, who live in an emptied and humbled spirit and walk in a pure and single heart under the heavenly ruling of the kingdom, are not allowed to do anything in the flesh to gain the praise of men, but must do all things in the spirit to please their heavenly Father.

To the kingdom people God is not only their God but also their Father; they are not only created by God but also regenerated by the Father. They have not only the created, natural human life but also the uncreated, spiritual divine life. Hence, the new law of the kingdom, decreed by the King on the mountain, is given to them with the intention that they should keep it not by their fallen human life but by the Father's eternal, divine life, not to gain man's glory but to receive the Father's reward.

verse.text: Therefore when you [xref]a[/xref]give alms, do not [note]1[/note]sound a trumpet before you as the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]hypocrites do in the [note]3[/note]synagogues and in the streets, so that they may be [xref]c[/xref]glorified by men. Truly I say to you, They have their reward in full.
verse.note: Surely the heaven-ruled spirit of the kingdom people restricts them from such fleshly boasting.

A stage actor, an impersonator. It was a custom for Greek and Roman actors to wear large masks with mechanical devices that increased the force of their voice. Hence, a dissembler. So in the succeeding verses.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]. So throughout the book.

verse.text: But you, when you give alms, do not let your [note]1[/note]left hand know what your right hand is doing,
verse.note: Indicating that, as much as possible, the righteous deeds of the kingdom people should be kept secret. What they do in their spirit under the heavenly rule to please solely their Father must not be interfered with by their flesh in its lusting for man's glory.

verse.text: So that your alms may be in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]secret; and your Father who [note]2[/note]sees in secret will [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]repay you.
verse.note: The kingdom people live by the Father's divine life and walk according to their spirit. Thus, they are required to do good things in secret, not in public. Public exhibition does not correspond with the mysterious, hidden nature of the divine life.

The kingdom people, as children of the heavenly Father, must live in the presence of the Father and care for the Father's presence. Whatever they do in secret for the Father's kingdom is seen in secret by the Father, and He will repay them. Their heavenly Father's seeing in secret must be an incentive to doing their righteous deeds in secret. So in [link]vv. 6[/link] and [link]18[/link].
This may occur in this age ([link]2 Cor. 9:10-11[/link]) or as a reward in the coming age ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]).

verse.text: And when you pray, you shall not be like the [xref]a[/xref]hypocrites, because they love to [xref]b[/xref]pray standing in the synagogues and on the street corners, so that they may be seen by men. Truly I say to you, They have [note]1[/note]their reward in full.
verse.note: Prayer that seeks man's praise may gain a reward from men, but it will not receive an answer from the Father; thus, it is vain prayer.

verse.text: But you, when you pray, enter into your [note]1[/note]private room, and [xref]a[/xref]shut your door and pray to your Father who is in secret; and your Father who sees in [xref]b[/xref]secret will repay you.
verse.note: The kingdom people must have some experience of praying in their private room, through which they contact their heavenly Father in secret, experience some secret enjoyment of the Father, and receive some secret answer from Him.

verse.text: And in praying do [note]1[/note]not babble empty words as the Gentiles do; for they suppose that in their [xref]a[/xref]multiplicity of words they will be heard.
verse.note: This does not mean that we should not repeat our prayer. The Lord repeated His prayer three times in Gethsemane ([link]26:44[/link]), the apostle Paul prayed the same prayer three times ([link]2 Cor. 12:8[/link]), and the great multitude in heaven praised God repeatedly with hallelujahs ([link]Rev. 19:1-6[/link]). It means that we should not repeat empty words, words spoken in vain.

verse.text: Therefore do not be like them, for your Father [xref]a[/xref]knows the things that you have need of before you [note]1[/note]ask Him.
verse.note: Although God our Father knows our need, we still must ask Him, because he who asks receives ([link]7:8[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]You then pray [note]1[/note]in this way: Our [xref]b[/xref]Father who is in the heavens, [note]2[/note]Your name be [xref]c[/xref]sanctified;
verse.note: [i]In this way[/i] does not mean that we should recite this prayer. In the Acts and the Epistles there is no example of such reciting.

In the example of prayer given as a pattern by the Lord, the first three petitions imply the Trinity of the Godhead: "Your name be sanctified" is related mainly to the Father; "Your kingdom come," to the Son; and "Your will be done," to the Spirit. This is being fulfilled in this age, and it will be ultimately fulfilled in the coming kingdom age, when the name of God will be excellent in all the earth ([link]Psa. 8:1[/link]), the kingdom of the world will become the kingdom of Christ ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), and the will of God will be accomplished.

verse.text: Your [xref]a[/xref]kingdom come; Your [xref]b[/xref]will be done, as in heaven, [i]so[/i] also on [note]1[/note]earth.
verse.note: After the rebellion of Satan ([link]Ezek. 28:17[/link]; [link]Isa. 14:13-15[/link]), the earth fell into his usurping hand. Thus, the will of God could not be done on earth as in heaven. Hence, God created man with the intention of recovering the earth for Himself ([link]Gen. 1:26-28[/link]). After the fall of man, Christ came to bring the heavenly rule to earth so that the earth could be recovered for God's interest, so that the will of God could be done on earth as in heaven. This is why the new King established the kingdom of the heavens with His followers. The kingdom people must pray for this until the earth is fully recovered for God's will in the coming kingdom age.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Give us [note]2[/note]today our [note]3[/note]daily bread.
verse.note: This prayer, as a pattern, cares first for God's name, God's kingdom, and God's will, and second, for our need.
The King does not want His people to worry about tomorrow ([link]v. 34[/link]); He wants them to pray only for today's needs.

Or, bread until tomorrow, bread for this day. [i]Daily bread[/i] indicates a living that is by faith. The kingdom people should not live on what they have stored; rather, they should live, by faith, on the Father's daily supply.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgive us our debts, as we also have [note]1[/note]forgiven our debtors.
verse.note: This prayer, as a pattern, cares, third, for the kingdom people's failures before God and for their relationship with others. The kingdom people should ask the Father to forgive their debts, their failures, their trespasses, as they forgive their debtors to maintain peace.

verse.text: And do [note]1[/note]not bring us into [xref]a[/xref]temptation, but [xref]b[/xref]deliver us from [note]2[/note]the [xref]c[/xref]evil one. [note]3[/note]For Yours is the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]kingdom and the [xref]e[/xref]power and the [xref]f[/xref]glory forever. [note]5[/note][xref]g[/xref]Amen.
verse.note: The King had been led by the Spirit to be tempted by the devil ([link]4:1[/link]).

Or, evil. This prayer, as a pattern, cares, fourth, for the kingdom people's deliverance from the evil one and from evil things. The kingdom people should ask the Father not to bring them into temptation but to deliver them from the evil one, the devil, and from the evil that is out of him.
This sentence is omitted in the earliest MSS.
The kingdom is the realm in which God exercises His power so that He can express His glory.
[i]Amen,[/i] from Hebrew, means [i]firm, steadfast,[/i] or [i]trustworthy.[/i]

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For if you [xref]a[/xref]forgive men their offenses, your heavenly Father will forgive you also;
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that the word in [link]vv. 14-15[/link] is an explanation of why the kingdom people must forgive their debtors ([link]v. 12[/link]). If they do not forgive man's offenses, neither will their heavenly Father forgive their offenses. In such a case, their prayer will be frustrated.

verse.text: But if you do [xref]a[/xref]not forgive men their offenses, neither will your Father forgive your offenses.

And when you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fast, do not be like the sullen-faced hypocrites, for they disfigure their faces so that they may [xref]b[/xref]appear to men to be fasting. Truly I say to you, They have their reward in full.
verse.note: To fast is not to refrain from eating; it is to be unable to eat because of a desperate burden to pray for certain things. It is also an expression of self-humbling in seeking God's mercy. To give alms is to give what we have the right to possess, whereas to fast is to give up what we have the right to enjoy.

verse.text: But you, when you fast, [xref]a[/xref]anoint your head and wash your face,
So that you may not appear to men to be fasting, but to your Father who is in [xref]a[/xref]secret; and your Father who sees in secret will repay you.
[note]1[/note]Do [xref]a[/xref]not store up for yourselves treasures on the earth, where [xref]b[/xref]moth and rust consume and where thieves dig through and steal.
verse.note: The fifth section of the King's decree, [link]vv. 19-34[/link], concerns the riches of the kingdom people.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]store up for yourselves [xref]a[/xref]treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust consumes and where thieves do not [xref]b[/xref]dig through nor steal.
verse.note: To store up treasures in heaven is to give material things to the poor ([link]19:21[/link]) and to care for the needy saints ([link]Acts 2:45[/link]; [link]4:34-35[/link]; [link]11:29[/link]; [link]Rom. 15:26[/link]) and the Lord's servants ([link]Phil. 4:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: For where your treasure is, there will your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heart be also.
verse.note: The kingdom people must send their treasure to heaven so that their heart also can be in heaven.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]lamp of the body is the eye. If therefore your eye is [note]1[/note]single, your whole body will be full of light;
verse.note: Our two eyes can focus on only one thing at a time. If we endeavor to see two things at once, our vision will be blurred. If we focus our eyes on one thing, our vision will be single and our whole body will be full of light. If we store up our treasure both in heaven and on earth, our spiritual vision will be blurred. For our vision to be single, we must store up our treasure in one place.

verse.text: But if your eye is [note]1[/note]evil, your whole body will be dark. If then the [note]2[/note]light that is in you is [xref]a[/xref]darkness, how great is the darkness!
verse.note: To look at two objects at the same time, not focusing on one object alone, is to make our eye evil (cf. [link]20:15[/link]; [link]Deut. 15:9[/link]; [link]Prov. 28:22[/link]). In such a case, our whole body will be dark.
If our heart is fixed on treasure laid up on earth, the light that is in us will become darkness, and great will be the darkness.

verse.text: No one can [note]1[/note]serve [xref]a[/xref]two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will [note]2[/note]hold to one and despise the other. You cannot [note]1[/note]serve God and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]mammon.
verse.note: Lit., serve as a slave.
In Greek, [i]hold to one and despise the other[/i] means to be devoted to one and be against the other.
An Aramaic word signifying wealth, riches. Mammon stands in opposition to God, indicating that wealth, or riches, is the opponent of God, robbing God's people of their service to Him.

verse.text: Because of this, I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]Do not be [xref]b[/xref]anxious for your [note]1[/note]life, what you should eat or what you should drink; nor for your body, what you should put on. Is not the [note]1[/note]life [note]2[/note]more than food, and the body than clothing?
verse.note: Lit., soul. Referring to the soul-life, where the desire, the appetite, for food and clothing resides ([link]Isa. 29:8[/link]).

Our life is more than food, and our body is more than clothing. Both our life and our body were brought into existence by God, not by our anxiety. Since God created us with a life and a body, surely He will care for their needs. The kingdom people do not need to be anxious about this.

verse.text: Look at the [xref]a[/xref]birds of heaven. They do not sow nor reap nor gather into barns, yet your heavenly Father nourishes them. Are you not of more value than they?
Who among you by being anxious can add one cubit to [note]1[/note]his stature?
verse.note: Or, the length of his life (similar to [i]lifetime[/i] in [link]Psa. 39:5[/link]).

verse.text: And why are you [xref]a[/xref]anxious concerning [xref]b[/xref]clothing? Consider well the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]lilies of the field, how they grow. They do not toil, neither do they spin [i]thread.[/i]
verse.note: Lilies signify people under the care of God ([link]S.S. 2:1-2[/link]).

verse.text: But I tell you that not even [xref]a[/xref]Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these.

And if God so arrays the [xref]a[/xref]grass of the field, which is [i]here[/i] today and tomorrow is cast into the furnace, [i]will He[/i] not much more [xref]b[/xref][i]clothe[/i] you, you of [xref]c[/xref]little faith?
Therefore do not be [xref]a[/xref]anxious, saying, What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? or, With what shall we be clothed?
For all these things the Gentiles are anxiously seeking. For your [note]1[/note]heavenly Father knows that you [xref]a[/xref]need all these things.
verse.note: The kingdom people have the divine life of their heavenly Father as their strength to keep the new law of the kingdom. They also have their heavenly Father as the One who cares for their material need, so that they do not need to be anxious about it. Their heavenly Father is the source of their strength and supply. Hence, they need not be weak or wanting.

verse.text: But seek first His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom and His [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
verse.note: The Father's kingdom is the reality of the kingdom of the heavens today, the reality of the church life today, and will be the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens in the coming age. The Father's righteousness is the righteousness expressed by the keeping of the new law of the kingdom, as mentioned in [link]5:20[/link]. This righteousness is Christ, who is lived out by the kingdom people. Since the kingdom people seek first the kingdom and the righteousness of their heavenly Father, not only will His kingdom and His righteousness be given to them, but also all that they need will be added to them.

verse.text: Therefore do not be [xref]a[/xref]anxious for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tomorrow, for tomorrow will be anxious for itself; sufficient for the day is its [i]own[/i] [note]2[/note]evil.
verse.note: The kingdom people should never live in tomorrow but always in today.

Not the same Greek word as for [i]evil[/i] in note [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link]. [i]Evil[/i] here denotes trouble and affliction. This indicates that the King of the kingdom has made it clear to the kingdom people that their days on earth for the kingdom will be days of trouble and affliction, not of ease and comfort.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Do [note]2[/note]not judge, that you be not judged.
verse.note: The sixth section of the new King's decree on the mountain, [link]vv. 1-12[/link], concerns the principles of the kingdom people in their dealings with others.
The kingdom people, living in a humble spirit under the heavenly ruling of the kingdom, always judge themselves, not others.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]with what judgment you judge, you shall be judged; and with what [xref]a[/xref]measure you measure, it shall be measured to you.
verse.note: Under the heavenly ruling of the kingdom, the kingdom people will be judged with what they judge others. If they judge others with righteousness, they will be judged with righteousness by the Lord; if they judge others with mercy, they will be judged with mercy by the Lord. Mercy triumphs over judgment ([link]James 2:13[/link]).

verse.text: And why do you look at the [xref]a[/xref]splinter which is in your brother's eye, but the beam in your eye you do not [note]1[/note]consider?
verse.note: As the kingdom people, living in a humble spirit under the heavenly ruling of the kingdom, we must consider the beam in our own eye whenever we look at the splinter in our brother's eye. The splinter in our brother's eye must remind us of the beam in our own eye.

verse.text: Or how can you say to your brother, Let me remove the splinter from your eye, and behold, the beam is in your eye?
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hypocrite, first remove the beam from your eye, and then you will [note]2[/note]see clearly to remove the splinter from your brother's eye.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
As long as the beam remains in our eye, our vision is blurred and we cannot see clearly.

verse.text: Do not give [note]1[/note]that which is [xref]a[/xref]holy to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]dogs, neither cast your [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]pearls before the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]hogs, lest they trample them with their feet, and turn and tear you.
verse.note: [i]That which is holy[/i] must refer to the objective truth, which belongs to God; [i]your pearls[/i] must refer to the subjective experiences, which are ours.

Dogs do not have hoofs, nor do they chew the cud; hogs have divided hoofs but do not chew the cud. Thus, both are unclean ([link]Lev. 11:27[/link], [link]7[/link]). According to the revelation in [link]2 Pet. 2:12[/link], [link]19-22[/link], and [link]Phil. 3:2[/link], [i]dogs[/i] and [i]hogs[/i] here refer to people who are religious but not clean.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ask and it shall be given to you; [xref]b[/xref]seek and you shall find; knock and it shall be opened to you.
verse.note: First ask, then seek, and last knock. To ask is to pray in a common way, to seek is to supplicate in a specific way, and to knock is to demand in the most intimate and most earnest way.

verse.text: For everyone who [note]1[/note]asks receives, and he who [note]2[/note]seeks finds, and to him who [note]3[/note]knocks it shall be opened.
verse.note: This part of the King's promise in this verse is applicable to the prayer of the kingdom people concerning their keeping of the new law of the kingdom. They ask for this and will receive it.
This part of the King's promise is applicable to [link]6:33[/link]. The kingdom people seek the Father's kingdom and His righteousness and will find them.
This part of the King's promise can be applied to [link]v. 14[/link]. The narrow gate will be opened to the kingdom people as a result of their knocking.

verse.text: Or what man is there among you who, when his son asks him for a [xref]a[/xref]loaf, will give him a stone?
Or also when he asks for a [xref]a[/xref]fish, will give him a serpent?

If you then being [xref]a[/xref]evil know [i]how[/i] to give good gifts to your children, [note]1[/note]how much more will your Father who is in the heavens give [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]good things to those who ask Him!
verse.note: This is a great promise. Such a promise affirms that the kingdom people are being cared for and supplied by their Father who is in the heavens. Thus, they are well able to fulfill the new law of the kingdom and live in the kingdom's reality that they may enter into its manifestation.

In the parallel verse, [link]Luke 11:13[/link], it is [i]the Holy Spirit[/i] instead of [i]good things,[/i] because Luke emphasizes the blessing of the gospel, the center of which is the Spirit ([link]Gal. 3:8[/link], [link]14[/link]). Since Matthew stresses the kingdom of the heavens, [i]good things[/i] should refer to the blessings of the reality of the kingdom, as revealed in [link]chs. 5-7[/link], blessings to be given as gifts to the kingdom people.

verse.text: Therefore all that you wish men would [xref]a[/xref]do to you, so also you do to them; for this is the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]law and the prophets.
verse.note: The new law of the kingdom does not contradict the law and the prophets; rather, it fulfills them and even complements them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Enter in through the [xref]a[/xref]narrow gate, for wide is the gate and broad is the way that [note]2[/note]leads to [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]destruction, and many are those who enter through it.
verse.note: The seventh and last section of the King's decree, [link]vv. 13-29[/link], concerns the ground of the kingdom people's living and work.
Lit., leads away. So in the next verse.
[i]Destruction[/i] here does not refer to the perishing of the person himself, but to the destruction of a person's deeds and work ([link]1 Cor. 3:15[/link]).

verse.text: Because [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]narrow is the [xref]b[/xref]gate and constricted is the [xref]c[/xref]way that leads to [note]2[/note]life, and [xref]d[/xref]few are those who find it.
verse.note: The gate is narrow and the way is constricted because the new law of the kingdom is stricter and the demand of the kingdom higher than the law and the demand of the old covenant. The narrow gate deals not only with outward conduct but also with inward motive. The old man, the self, the flesh, the human concept, and the world with its glory are all excluded; only that which corresponds with God's will can enter in. The kingdom people need first to enter in through such a narrow gate, and then to walk on such a constricted way. It is not that they first walk the way and then enter in through the gate. To enter in through the gate is simply to begin walking on the way, a way that is lifelong.

[i]Life[/i] here refers to the ever-blessed condition of the kingdom, which is filled with the eternal life of God. This life is in the reality of the kingdom today and will be in the manifestation of the kingdom in the coming age ([link]19:29[/link]; [link]Luke 18:30[/link]).

verse.text: Beware of [xref]a[/xref]false prophets, who come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are [note]1[/note]ravenous [xref]b[/xref]wolves.
verse.note: Lit., extortionate.

verse.text: By their [xref]a[/xref]fruits you will recognize them. Do [i]men[/i] gather grapes from thorns, or [xref]b[/xref]figs from thistles?
Even so every [xref]a[/xref]good tree produces [xref]b[/xref]good fruit, but the corrupt tree produces [xref]c[/xref]bad fruit.
A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, neither can a corrupt tree produce good fruit.
Every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and [xref]a[/xref]cast into the fire.
So then, by their [xref]a[/xref]fruits you will recognize them.

Not everyone who says to Me, [xref]a[/xref]Lord, Lord, will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]enter into the kingdom of the heavens, but he who [xref]c[/xref]does the [xref]d[/xref]will of My Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: To enter into the kingdom of the heavens, we need to do two things: call on the Lord and do the will of the heavenly Father. To call on the Lord suffices for us to be saved ([link]Rom. 10:13[/link]), but to enter into the kingdom of the heavens, we also need to do the will of the heavenly Father. Hence, not everyone who says, "Lord, Lord," will enter into the kingdom of the heavens; but those who call on the Lord and do the will of the heavenly Father will enter in.[br][br]Since entering into the kingdom of the heavens requires doing the will of the heavenly Father, it is clearly different from entering into the kingdom of God through regeneration ([link]John 3:3[/link], [link]5[/link]). The latter entrance is gained through being born of the divine life; the former, through the living of that life.

verse.text: Many will say to Me in [note]1[/note]that day, Lord, Lord, [i]was it[/i] not in Your name [i]that[/i] we prophesied, and in Your name [xref]a[/xref]cast out demons, and in Your name did many [xref]b[/xref]works of power?
verse.note: [i]That day[/i] refers to the day of the judgment seat of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 3:13[/link]; [link]4:5[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]).

verse.text: And then I will declare to them: I never [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]knew you. [xref]b[/xref]Depart from Me, you workers of [xref]c[/xref]lawlessness.
verse.note: [i]Knew[/i] here means [i]approved.[/i] The same word in [link]Rom. 7:15[/link] is translated [i]acknowledge.[/i] The Lord never approved those who, in His name, prophesied, cast out demons, and did many works of power ([link]v. 22[/link]), but did those things not according to the will of the heavenly Father ([link]v. 21[/link]). The Lord did not deny that they did those things, but He considered those things lawlessness because they were not done according to the will of the heavenly Father; they were not done in line with the divine will. Thus, those who do such things, even in the Lord's name, will not enter into the kingdom of the heavens, but will depart from the Lord, that is, be excluded from the manifestation of the kingdom in the coming age.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Everyone therefore who hears these words of Mine and [xref]b[/xref]does them shall be likened to a [xref]c[/xref]prudent man who built his house upon the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]rock.
verse.note: [i]Rock[/i] does not refer to Christ but to His wise word, the word that reveals the will of His Father who is in the heavens. The living and work of the kingdom people must be founded on the word of the new King for the accomplishing of the will of the heavenly Father. This is to enter in through the narrow gate and walk the constricted way that leads to life.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]rain descended, and the rivers came, and the winds blew, and they beat against that house; and it did [note]2[/note]not fall, for it was founded on the rock.
verse.note: The rain, which descends from the heavens, is of God; the rivers, which come from the earth, are of man; and the winds, which blow from the air, are of Satan. All these will test the living and work of the kingdom people.
The house built on the rock, a house that does not fall, is like the work that is built with gold, silver, and precious stones, a work that can stand the testing fire ([link]1 Cor. 3:12-13[/link]).

verse.text: And everyone who hears these words of Mine and does [xref]a[/xref]not do them shall be likened to a foolish man who built his house upon the [note]1[/note]sand.
verse.note: [i]Sand[/i] refers to human concepts and natural ways. If we live and work according to our human concepts and natural ways, our living and work will be founded on sinking sand. This is to enter in through the wide gate and walk the broad way that leads to destruction.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]rain descended, and the rivers came, and the winds blew, and they dashed against that house; and it [note]1[/note]fell, and its fall was great.
verse.note: The house built on sand, a house that falls, is like the work that is built with wood, grass, and stubble, a work that will be burned by the testing fire. However, the builder himself will be saved ([link]1 Cor. 3:12-15[/link]).

verse.text: And when Jesus finished these words, the crowds were [xref]a[/xref]astounded at His teaching,
For He taught them [xref]a[/xref]as One having [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]authority and not like their scribes.
verse.note: Christ, as the new King of the kingdom of the heavens, spoke with authority in decreeing the new law of the kingdom.

verse.text: And when He [note]1[/note]came down from the [xref]a[/xref]mountain, great [xref]b[/xref]crowds followed Him.
verse.note: After decreeing the new law of the kingdom, the new King came down from the mountain to carry on His kingly ministry. The first things He did were to cleanse the unclean, heal the sick, and cast the demons out of the possessed that they might become people of the kingdom of the heavens ([link]vv. 2-17[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And behold, a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]leper, coming near, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]worshipped Him, saying, Lord, if You are willing, You can cleanse me.
verse.note: The first class of people saved by the kingly Savior to be the people of the kingdom is represented by a leper. According to the examples in the Scriptures, leprosy results from rebellion and disobedience. Miriam became leprous because of her rebellion against God's deputy authority ([link]Num. 12:1-10[/link]). Naaman's leprosy was cleansed because of his obedience ([link]2 Kings 5:1[/link], [link]9-14[/link]). All fallen human beings have become leprous in the eyes of God because of their rebellion. The kingly Savior came to save men from their rebellion and to cleanse them from their leprosy that they might become His kingdom people.
The leper worshipped the new King and called Him "Lord," recognizing that He is the Lord God. In reality the new King is Jehovah the Savior — Jesus. (See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].)

verse.text: And stretching out His hand, He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]touched him, saying, I am willing; be cleansed! And immediately his leprosy was cleansed.
verse.note: According to the law, a leper was to be isolated from the people because of his uncleanness. No one was allowed to touch him ([link]Lev. 13:45-46[/link]). But the new King, as a man and as the kingly Savior, touched this leper. What mercy and sympathy! By His one touch, his leprosy was immediately cleansed. What wonderful cleansing!

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, See that you tell [xref]a[/xref]no one; but go, [note]1[/note]show yourself to the [xref]b[/xref]priest, and offer the [xref]c[/xref]gift which Moses commanded, for a testimony to them.
verse.note: The new King told the cleansed leper that for his cleansing he should continue to do things according to the regulations of the old law, because the transitional period still remained, the old law having not yet been fulfilled by His redeeming death.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And when He entered into [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum, a [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]centurion came to Him, beseeching Him
verse.note: An officer over one hundred soldiers in the Roman army. The leper in [link]vv. 2-4[/link] represents the Jews, whereas the centurion in [link]vv. 5-13[/link] represents the Gentiles. Before God, the Jews had become leprous, unclean, because of their rebellion and disobedience, whereas the Gentiles had become paralyzed, dead in function, because of their sinfulness. The kingly Savior came first to the Jews and then to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 3:26[/link]; [link]13:46[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:16[/link]; [link]11:11[/link]). The believing Jews were saved by His direct touch ([link]v. 3[/link]), whereas the believing Gentiles are saved through faith in His word ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]13[/link]).

verse.text: And saying, Lord, my servant is lying in the house paralyzed, terribly tormented.
And He said to him, I will come and heal him.
But the centurion answered and said, Lord, I am not fit for You to enter under my roof; but only speak a [xref]a[/xref]word, and my servant will be healed.

For I also am a man under [note]1[/note]authority, having soldiers under me. And I say to this one, Go, and he goes; and to another, Come, and he comes; and to my slave, Do this, and he does [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The centurion, a Gentile, recognized the authority of the kingly Savior and realized that His word had the authority to heal. Thus, he believed not only in the kingly Savior but also in His word, asking Him not to go in person but only to speak the word. This was stronger faith, and it was marveled at by the Savior ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: Now when Jesus heard [i]this,[/i] He marveled and said to those who followed, Truly I say to you, [note]1[/note]With no one in Israel have I found such great faith.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS read, Not even in Israel have I found such great faith.

verse.text: But I say to you that many will come [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]from the east and the west and will recline [i]at table[/i] with Abraham and Isaac and Jacob in the [note]2[/note]kingdom of the heavens,
verse.note: This indicates that the Gentiles will participate in the gospel of the kingdom ([link]Eph. 3:6[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:8-9[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:13-16[/link]).
This refers to the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens. In the manifestation of the kingdom the overcoming Gentile believers will feast with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]sons of the kingdom will be [xref]a[/xref]cast out into the [note]2[/note]outer darkness. In that place there will be the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: The sons of the kingdom are the saved Jews, who are the good seed ([link]13:38[/link]) but whose faith is not strong enough to enable them to enter in through the narrow gate and walk the constricted way ([link]7:13-14[/link]). They will miss the feast in the manifestation of the kingdom ([link]Luke 13:24-30[/link]).

The outer darkness is the darkness outside the bright glory in the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens ([link]16:28[/link]; [link]25:30[/link]). Being cast out into the outer darkness in the coming kingdom age differs from being cast into the lake of fire after the millennium and for eternity ([link]Rev. 20:15[/link]).
Weeping indicates regret, and gnashing of teeth indicates self blame.

verse.text: And Jesus said to the centurion, Go; as you have believed, [i]so[/i] be it [xref]a[/xref]done to you. And his servant was healed in that [xref]b[/xref]hour.
[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus, coming into Peter's house, saw [note]1[/note]his [xref]b[/xref]mother-in-law lying down and in a fever.
verse.note: Peter's mother-in-law in [link]vv. 14-15[/link] represents the Jews living at the end of this age, who will be saved by receiving the kingly Savior ([link]Rom. 11:25-26[/link]). At that time, during the great tribulation, the Jews in the eyes of God will be "in a fever" ([link]v. 14[/link]), "hot" in things other than God. After the fullness of the salvation of the Gentiles, the kingly Savior will come back to this remnant of the Jews that they may be saved ([link]Rom. 11:25-26[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:10[/link]). Peter's mother-in-law was healed in Peter's house. At the end of this age all the remnant of the Jews will be saved in the house of Israel. Furthermore, they will be saved by the kingly Savior's direct touch ([link]v. 15[/link]), as was the Jewish leper ([link]v. 3[/link]).

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]touched her hand, and the fever left her. And she arose and served Him.
And when evening fell, they brought to Him [note]1[/note]many who were demon-possessed, and He cast out the spirits with a [xref]a[/xref]word, and [note]1[/note]all those who were ill He healed,
verse.note: [i]Many who were demon-possessed[/i] and [i]all those who were ill[/i] represent all the people on earth in the millennium. The millennium is the last dispensation of the old heaven and old earth; thus, it is considered the "evening" of the old heaven and old earth. In the millennium the power to cast out demons and heal illnesses will be manifested to the uttermost. Hence, all the demon-possessed and all the sick will be healed. Such extensive power is the power of the coming age ([link]Heb. 6:5[/link]). The casting out of demons and the healing of the sick in this age are only a foretaste of the extensive power of the coming age. The signs recorded in [link]vv. 2-17[/link] bear a dispensational significance and show the coming kingdom in miniature.[br][br]The order of the four incidents recorded in [link]vv. 2-16[/link] differs from that in [link]Mark 1:29-2:1[/link] and [link]Luke 4:38-41[/link]; [link]5:12-14[/link]; and [link]7:1-10[/link]. In Mark's record, which shows that Jesus is the Servant of God, the order is according to history. In Matthew's record, which proves that Christ is the King of the kingdom of the heavens, the order is according to doctrine; i.e., Matthew puts certain incidents together to present a doctrine. In Luke's record, which reveals that Jesus is the proper man to be man's Savior, the order is according to morality. In John's record, which testifies that Christ is the Son of God and even God Himself, the order is somewhat according to history.

verse.text: So that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]"He Himself took away our infirmities and [xref]c[/xref]bore our diseases."
verse.note: All healings accomplished on fallen people are a result of the Lord's redemption. On the cross He took away our infirmities, bore our diseases, and accomplished full healing for us. However, in this age the application of this divine healing power can be only a foretaste to us; in the coming age we will experience the full taste.

verse.text: Now when Jesus saw a crowd around Him, He gave orders to [note]1[/note]depart to the other side.
verse.note: In His ministry as recorded in the four Gospels, the Lord always withdrew from the crowds; He did not want the curious ones to be with Him. He did not care for crowds but cared only for those who sought Him sincerely.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And a scribe came near and said to Him, Teacher, I will [note]1[/note]follow You wherever You [note]2[/note]go.
verse.note: In saying this he did not consider the cost. Hence, the King answered in [link]v. 20[/link] in a way that caused him to consider the cost.
Lit., depart.

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, The foxes have holes, and the birds of heaven [i]have[/i] roosts, but the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of Man has [note]2[/note]nowhere to lay His head.
verse.note: In His kingly ministry the new King continually took the standing of the Son of Man, until [link]16:13-17[/link].

Even the foxes and the birds have a resting place, but the King of the kingdom did not have a resting place. This proves that the kingdom He was establishing was not material, not of an earthly nature, but was spiritual, of a heavenly nature.

verse.text: And another of the disciples said to Him, Lord, [xref]a[/xref]permit me first to [note]1[/note]go and bury my father.
verse.note: In so saying, this disciple, who was not a scribe, overly considered the cost of following the King of the heavenly kingdom. Hence, the King answered him by encouraging him to follow Him, to drop his consideration of the cost, and to leave the burial of his father to others.

verse.text: But Jesus said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Follow Me, and let the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]dead bury their own [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]dead.
verse.note: The first [i]dead[/i] refers to those who are dead spiritually, as mentioned in [link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link]; the second [i]dead[/i] refers to the disciple's father, who was dead physically.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And when He stepped into the boat, His disciples followed Him.
And behold, there arose a great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tempest in the sea, so that the boat was covered by the waves; but He was sleeping.
verse.note: Lit., quaking, or, shaking.

verse.text: And they came near and roused Him, saying, Lord, [xref]a[/xref]save [i]us;[/i] we are perishing!

And He said to them, Why are you [xref]a[/xref]cowardly, you of [xref]b[/xref]little [note]1[/note]faith? Then He arose and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was a [note]3[/note]great [xref]d[/xref]calm.
verse.note: Faith comes from and depends on the word of the Lord ([link]Rom. 10:17[/link]). In [link]v. 18[/link] the Lord gave them a word, telling them to depart to the other side. If they had believed that word, they would not have needed to pray as they did in [link]v. 25[/link]. They did not have a full realization concerning the Lord's word; thus, their faith was little.

A rebuke is not given to lifeless things but to things with personality. The King rebuked the winds and the sea because in the winds were the fallen angels of Satan ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]) and in the sea were the demons ([link]v. 32[/link]). The fallen angels in the air and the demons in the water collaborated to frustrate the King from going to the other side of the sea because they knew He would cast out the demons there ([link]vv. 28-32[/link]).
[i]Great[/i] is in contrast to [i]little[/i] in the first part of this verse.

verse.text: And the men marveled, saying, What kind of man is this that even the winds and the sea [note]1[/note]obey Him?
verse.note: Actually, it was not the winds and the sea that obeyed the King's authority but the fallen angels above the winds and the demons under the sea.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And when He came to the other side, into the region of the Gadarenes, two possessed by demons met Him, as they were coming out of the tombs, so exceedingly fierce that no one was able to pass by on that road.

And behold, they cried out, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]What do we have to do with You, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of God? Have You come here [note]3[/note]before the [xref]c[/xref]time to torment us?
verse.note: Lit., What to us and to You? (a Hebrew idiom).

The King called Himself the Son of Man ([link]v. 20[/link]), but the demons called Him the Son of God, tempting Him to deviate from His standing as the Son of Man. (See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].)

[i]Before the time[/i] implies that God has appointed a time for the demons to be tormented and that the demons know that time, which will be after the millennium and for eternity. (See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 20[/link].)

verse.text: Now there was, a good way off from them, a herd of many hogs feeding.
And the demons [note]1[/note]entreated Him, saying, If You cast us out, send us into the herd of hogs.
verse.note: This indicates that the demons were under the power and authority of the King.

verse.text: And He said to them, [note]1[/note]Go! And they came out and went into the hogs. And behold, the whole herd [note]2[/note]rushed down the steep slope into the sea, and they died in the waters.
verse.note: This was the King's authoritative order, and the demons obeyed it. The King complied with the demons' entreaty and allowed them to enter into the hogs because hogs are unclean in the eyes of God ([link]Lev. 11:7[/link]).

The hogs would not tolerate being possessed by the demons, and they rushed into the sea. The demons consented because the water is their lodging place ([link]12:43-44[/link]; see [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Two).

verse.text: And those who were feeding [i]them[/i] fled and went away into the city and reported everything, including what [i]had happened to[/i] those possessed by demons.
And behold, the whole city came out to meet Jesus; and when they saw Him, they entreated [i]Him[/i] to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]depart from their borders.
verse.note: The people of the city, having lost their hogs, rejected the King. They wanted their unclean hogs but did not want the King of the heavenly kingdom. They probably were Gentiles. (Gadara was on the shore of the Sea of Galilee, across from Galilee of the Gentiles — [link]4:15[/link].) They rejected the heavenly King because of their unclean way of making a living.

verse.text: And stepping into a boat, He crossed over and came to His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]own city.
verse.note: Capernaum, where the Lord now dwelt ([link]4:13[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And behold, they brought to Him a paralytic, lying on a bed. And Jesus, [note]1[/note]seeing their [xref]b[/xref]faith, said to the paralytic, Take [xref]c[/xref]courage, child; your [note]2[/note]sins are [xref]d[/xref]forgiven.
verse.note: They dug through the roof of the house where the Lord was ([link]Mark 2:4[/link]). By this the Lord saw their faith.
This indicates that the paralytic was sick because of his sins.

verse.text: And behold, some of the [note]1[/note]scribes said within themselves, This man [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]blasphemes.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

The scribes, confident that they knew the Scriptures, thought that only God had authority to forgive sins and that Jesus, who in their eyes was only a man, had blasphemed God when He said, "Your sins are forgiven." This indicates that they did not realize that the Lord was God. By uttering such a word they rejected the King of the heavenly kingdom. This was the first rejection by the leaders of the Jewish religion.

verse.text: And Jesus, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]knowing their [note]2[/note]thoughts, said, Why are you [xref]b[/xref]thinking evil things in your hearts?
verse.note: Some ancient MSS read, seeing. This was the Lord's perception in His spirit ([link]Mark 2:8[/link]).
Or, cogitations, inward reasonings. Evil surmisings with strong feeling or passion.

verse.text: For which is [note]1[/note]easier, to say, Your sins are forgiven, or to say, [note]2[/note]Rise and walk?
verse.note: The Lord did not ask, "Which is more difficult?" because to Him nothing is difficult. For Him to say, "Your sins are forgiven," was easier than to say, "Rise and walk."

In the Lord's salvation He not only forgives our sins but also causes us to rise and walk. It is not that we first rise and walk and then are forgiven of our sins; such a salvation would be by works. Rather, we first are forgiven of our sins and then rise and walk; such a salvation is by grace.

verse.text: But that you may know that the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man has [note]1[/note]authority on earth to [xref]b[/xref]forgive sins — then He said to the paralytic, Rise, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]take up your bed and [note]3[/note]go to your house.
verse.note: To forgive sins is a matter of having authority on earth. Only this kingly Savior, who had been authorized by God and who would die to redeem sinners, had such authority ([link]Acts 5:31[/link]; [link]10:43[/link]; [link]13:38[/link]). This authority was for the establishing of the kingdom of the heavens ([link]16:19[/link]).
The Lord enabled the paralytic not only to walk but also to take up his bed and walk. Formerly, the bed had borne him; now he bore it. This is the power of the Lord's salvation.

This paralytic was brought to the Lord by others, but he went home by himself. This indicates that it is not that the sinner can go to the Lord, but that the sinner can go from the Lord by the Lord's salvation.

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note]rose and went away to his house.
verse.note: The paralytic's rising and going proved that he was healed, and his being healed proved that his sins were forgiven.

verse.text: And when the crowds saw [i]this,[/i] they [xref]a[/xref]feared and [xref]b[/xref]glorified God, who had given such authority to men.

[xref]a[/xref]And as Jesus passed on from there, He saw a man sitting at the tax office, called [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Matthew, and He said to him, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Follow Me. And he rose and [note]3[/note]followed Him.
verse.note: Matthew was also called Levi ([link]Mark 2:14[/link]; [link]Luke 5:27[/link]). He was a tax collector ([link]10:3[/link]) who, after being saved, became an apostle by God's grace ([link]10:2-3[/link]; [link]Acts 1:13[/link]). He was the writer of this Gospel.

Following the Lord includes believing in Him. No one follows Him unless he believes in Him. To believe in the Lord is to be saved ([link]Acts 16:31[/link]), and to follow Him is to enter in through the narrow gate and walk the constricted way to participate in the kingdom of the heavens ([link]7:13-14[/link]).

According to the record in this verse, it seems that this was the first time the Lord met Matthew. There must have been some attracting power, either in the Lord's word or in His appearance, that caused Matthew to follow Him.

verse.text: And as He was reclining [i]at table[/i] in the [note]1[/note]house, behold, many [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]tax collectors and [xref]b[/xref]sinners came and reclined together with Jesus and His disciples.
verse.note: This was Matthew's house ([link]Luke 5:29[/link]; [link]Mark 2:15[/link]). As the writer of this Gospel, Matthew purposely did not say that it was his house or that it was he who had made a great feast for the Lord. This displayed his humility.
See note [link]46[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And when the [note]1[/note]Pharisees saw [i]it,[/i] they said to His disciples, [note]2[/note]Why does your Teacher eat with the tax collectors and sinners?
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

This question indicates that the self-righteous Pharisees did not know the grace of God. They thought that God deals with man only according to righteousness. By asking this, they were exposed as dissenting from the heavenly King, and thus as those who had rejected Him. This was a continuation of the rejection of the heavenly King, begun in [link]v. 3[/link], by the leaders of the Jewish religion.

verse.text: Now when He heard [i]this,[/i] He said, Those who are strong have no need of a [note]1[/note]physician, but those who are [note]2[/note]ill.
verse.note: In calling people to follow Him for the kingdom, the King of the heavenly kingdom ministered as a Physician, not as a Judge.
