A judge's judgment is according to righteousness, whereas a physician's healing is according to mercy and grace. Those whom He made people of His heavenly kingdom were lepers ([link]8:2-4[/link]), paralytics ([link]8:5-13[/link]; [link]9:2-8[/link]), the fever-ridden ([link]8:14-15[/link]), the demon-possessed ([link]8:16[/link], [link]28-32[/link]), those ill with all kinds of diseases ([link]8:16[/link]), despised tax collectors, and sinners ([link]vv. 9-11[/link]). If He had visited these pitiful people as a Judge, all would have been condemned and rejected, and none would have been qualified, selected, and called to be the people of His heavenly kingdom. However, He came to minister as a Physician, to heal, recover, enliven, and save them that they might be reconstituted to be His new and heavenly citizens, with whom He could establish His heavenly kingdom on this corrupted earth.

The Lord's word here implies that the self-righteous Pharisees did not realize that they needed Him as a Physician. They considered themselves strong; hence, blinded by their self-righteousness, they did not know that they were ill.

verse.text: But go and [note]1[/note]learn what [i]this[/i] means, [xref]a[/xref]"I desire [note]2[/note]mercy and not [xref]b[/xref]sacrifice," for I did not come to call the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]righteous, but [xref]d[/xref]sinners.
verse.note: The self-righteous Pharisees were confident that they knew all things concerning God. In order to humble them, the Lord told them to learn more.

Mercy is part of the grace that man receives from God. (See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].) But self-righteous men do not like to receive mercy or grace from God; they prefer to give something to God. This is contrary to God's way in His economy. Just as God desires to show mercy to pitiful sinners, so He wants us to show mercy in love to others ([link]Micah 6:6-8[/link]; [link]Mark 12:33[/link]).

There is none righteous, not even one ([link]Rom. 3:10[/link]). All the "righteous" are self-righteous, as were the Pharisees ([link]Luke 18:9[/link]). The kingly Savior did not come to call these, but sinners.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then the [xref]b[/xref]disciples of John came to Him, saying, [note]1[/note]Why do we and the Pharisees [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fast [note]3[/note]much, but Your [xref]d[/xref]disciples do [note]4[/note]not fast?
verse.note: [link]Verses 10-13[/link] record the Lord's dealing with the question from the Pharisees, who were of the old religion. Here in [link]vv. 14-17[/link] the Lord dealt with the problem of John's disciples, who were of the new religion. John the Baptist had dropped the old religion and had begun his ministry in the wilderness, outside religion. (See notes [link chapter="3"]1[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].) However, after a short time his disciples formed a new religion that frustrated people from enjoying Christ, just as the Pharisees of the old religion had done. John the Baptist's ministry was to introduce people to Christ that Christ might become their Redeemer, their life, and their all. However, some of John's disciples drifted away from his goal, Christ, to some of his practices, and made those practices a religion. To be religious is to do something for God, without Christ. To do anything, even if it is scriptural and fundamental, without the presence of Christ is to be religious. Both John's disciples, who were of the new religion, and the Pharisees, who were of the old religion, fasted much, but without Christ. Meanwhile, they condemned the disciples of Christ, who did not fast but had Christ with them and lived in His presence.
See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
Some ancient authorities omit, much.

The self-righteous Pharisees, who were of the old religion, were bothered when Christ made Himself a companion of tax collectors and sinners, whom the Pharisees condemned ([link]v. 11[/link]). The fasting disciples of John, who were of the new religion, were troubled by the feasting of Christ and His disciples ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, The [note]1[/note]sons of the bridechamber cannot mourn as long as the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]bridegroom is with them, can they? But [xref]b[/xref]days will come when the bridegroom will be [note]3[/note]taken away from them, and then they will [xref]c[/xref]fast.
verse.note: The disciples of the Lord. In the transitional period of the Lord's ministry on earth, His disciples were the sons of the bridechamber. Later, they will become the bride ([link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:7[/link]).

In dealing with the self-righteous and dissenting Pharisees, who were of the old religion, the kingly Savior indicated that He was a Physician who had come to heal the sick ([link]v. 12[/link]). In dealing with the fasting and dissenting disciples of John, who were of the new religion, He revealed Himself as the Bridegroom who had come to take the bride. John the Baptist had told his disciples that Christ was the Bridegroom who had come to take the bride ([link]John 3:25-29[/link]). Now Christ, the kingly Savior, reminded some of them of this. Both a physician and a bridegroom are pleasant persons. The kingly Savior first healed His followers, and then made them the sons of the bridechamber; eventually, He will make them His bride. They should have laid hold of Him not only as their Physician, that their life might be recovered, but also as their Bridegroom, that they might have the enjoyment of living in His presence. They were with Him at a joyful wedding, not without Him at a mournful funeral. How then could they fast and not feast before Him? The dissenting question from John's disciples indicated that some of them had fallen into a new religion and had rejected the kingly Savior.[br][br]The question from John's disciples seemed to relate to doctrine. However, the Lord answered not with a doctrine but with a person, the most pleasant person, the Bridegroom. The religious people always care for their doctrine, asking "why" in a doctrinal way. But Christ cares only for Himself. The living and walk of His followers should be regulated and directed only by Himself and His presence, not by any doctrine.
This took place when the kingly Savior was taken up from the disciples into heaven ([link]Acts 1:11[/link]). After that, they fasted ([link]Acts 13:2-3[/link]; [link]14:23[/link]).

verse.text: No one puts a patch of [note]1[/note]unfulled cloth on an [note]2[/note]old garment, for that which fills it up pulls away from the garment, and a worse tear is made.
verse.note: Or, new, raw, unwrought. The Greek word is formed with [i]not[/i] and [i]to card or comb wool.[/i] Thus, the word means [i]uncarded, unsteamed and unwashed, unfinished, unfulled, untreated.[/i] The unfulled cloth signifies Christ from His incarnation to His crucifixion, as a piece of new cloth, untreated, unfinished; whereas the new garment in [link]Luke 5:36[/link] signifies Christ as a new robe after He was "treated" in His crucifixion. (The Greek word for [i]new[/i] in [link]Luke 5:36[/link] is the same as for [i]fresh[/i] in [link]Matt. 9:17[/link].) Christ first was the unfulled cloth for making a new garment, and then through His death and resurrection was made a new garment to cover us as our righteousness before God that we might be justified by God and be acceptable to Him ([link]Luke 15:22[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). A patch of unfulled cloth sewn on an old garment pulls away from the garment because of the strength of its shrinking, thus making the tear worse. To sew a patch of unfulled cloth on an old garment means to imitate what Christ did in His human life on earth. This is what today's modernists are attempting to do. They only imitate Jesus' human deeds to improve their behavior; they do not believe in the crucified Jesus as their Redeemer or in the resurrected Christ as their righteousness that they may be justified by God and acceptable to Him. Their imitating of Christ's human living "pulls away" from their "old garment," their behavior produced by their old, natural life. The kingdom people would not do this; they take the crucified and resurrected Christ as their new garment to cover them as their righteousness before God.
The old garment signifies the good behavior, good deeds, and religious practices produced by man's old, natural life.

verse.text: Neither do they put [note]1[/note]new wine into [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]old wineskins; otherwise, the wineskins burst, and the wine pours out, and the wineskins are ruined; but they put new wine into [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]fresh wineskins, and both are preserved.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]new[/i] means [i]new in time, recent, newly possessed.[/i] The new wine here signifies Christ as the new life, full of vigor, stirring people to excitement. The kingly Savior is not only the Bridegroom to the kingdom people for their enjoyment but also their new garment for them to be equipped outwardly that they may be qualified to attend the wedding. Furthermore, He is their new life to stir them up inwardly to enjoy Him as their Bridegroom. He, as the heavenly King, is the Bridegroom for the kingdom people's enjoyment, and His heavenly kingdom is His wedding feast ([link]22:2[/link]), at which they will enjoy Him. To enjoy Him as the Bridegroom in the kingdom feast, they need Him as their new garment outwardly and their new wine inwardly.

The old wineskins signify religious practices, such as the fasting maintained by the Pharisees, who were of the old religion, and by the disciples of John, who were of the new religion. All religions are old wineskins. New wine put into old wineskins bursts the wineskins by the power of its fermenting. To put new wine into old wineskins is to put Christ as the exciting life into any kind of religion. This is what the so-called fundamentalists and Pentecostalists are practicing today. They attempt to squeeze Christ into their different modes of religious ritual, formality, and practice. The kingdom people should never do this. They must put the new wine into fresh wineskins.

The Greek word for [i]fresh[/i] means [i]new in nature, quality, or form; unaccustomed, unused;[/i] hence, fresh. The fresh wineskins signify the church life in the local churches as the container of the new wine, which is Christ Himself as the exciting life. The kingdom people are built into the church ([link]16:18[/link]), and the church is expressed through the local churches in which the kingdom people live ([link]18:15-20[/link]). They are regenerated persons who constitute the Body of Christ and become the church ([link]Rom. 12:5[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]). The Body of Christ as His fullness is also called "the Christ" ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]), referring to the corporate Christ. The individual Christ is the new wine, the inward exciting life, and the corporate Christ is the fresh wineskin, the outward container that holds the new wine. With the kingdom people it is not a matter of fasting or any other religious practice, but a matter of the church life with Christ as their content. Christ came to establish not an earthly religion of rituals but a heavenly kingdom of life. He is establishing such a kingdom not with any dead religious practices but with Himself, the living person, as the Savior, the Physician, the Bridegroom, the unfulled cloth, and the new wine to His followers for their full enjoyment, that they may be the fresh wineskin to contain Him and may become the constituents of His kingdom.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]As He was speaking these things to them, behold, a [note]2[/note]ruler came and [xref]b[/xref]worshipped Him, saying, My daughter has just died, but come and lay Your hand on her, and she will live.
verse.note: [link]Verses 18-34[/link] give a brief picture of this age and the coming age. Hence, the record in this section has a dispensational significance, as did the record in [link]8:1-17[/link]. The daughter of the ruler of the synagogue represents the Jews, and the woman with the hemorrhage represents the Gentiles. When the daughter died, the woman was healed. After the woman was healed, the daughter was revived. Subsequently, two blind men and one dumb man were healed. This is a type, showing that when the Jews were cut off, the Gentiles were saved, and that after the fullness of the salvation of the Gentiles, the Jews will be saved ([link]Rom. 11:15[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]23-26[/link]). After that, the millennium will begin, in which all the blind and dumb will be healed ([link]Isa. 35:5-6[/link]).

Jairus, a ruler of the synagogue ([link]Mark 5:22[/link]; [link]Luke 8:41[/link]). His name means [i]he will enlighten,[/i] or [i]enlightened,[/i] signifying that the Lord will enlighten the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:46-48[/link]) and that the Jews also will be enlightened.

verse.text: And Jesus rose and followed him, and [i]so did[/i] His disciples.

And behold, a woman who had been suffering from a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]hemorrhage for [note]2[/note]twelve years [note]3[/note]approached from behind and touched the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]fringe of His garment,
verse.note: A bloody flux, a flow or issue of blood ([link]Lev. 15:25[/link]). The life of the flesh is in the blood ([link]Lev. 17:11[/link]). Hence, this disease signifies a life that cannot be retained.
The woman had been sick for twelve years, the age of the ruler's dead daughter ([link]Luke 8:42[/link]).

The woman here and the centurion in [link]8:5-10[/link], both representing the Gentiles, came to contact the Lord in the same way — with faith. The woman was healed while the Lord was on the way to the ruler's house. This signifies that the Gentiles are saved while Christ is on the way to the house of Israel.

Christ's garment signifies His righteous deeds, and the fringe signifies the heavenly ruling ([link]Num. 15:38-39[/link]). Out of Christ's heaven-ruled deeds issues the virtue that becomes the healing power ([link]14:36[/link]).

verse.text: For she said within herself, If only I [xref]a[/xref]touch His garment, [note]1[/note]I will be [note]2[/note]healed.
verse.note: This was her faith.
Or, saved. So in the next verse.

verse.text: And Jesus, turning and seeing her, said, Take [xref]a[/xref]courage, daughter; your [xref]b[/xref]faith has healed you. And the woman was healed from that hour.
And when Jesus came to the ruler's [note]1[/note]house and saw the flute players and the crowd making a commotion,
verse.note: The daughter here and Peter's mother-in-law in [link]8:14-15[/link], both representing the Jews at the end of this age, were healed in a house by the Lord's coming and His direct touch. This indicates that at the end of this age all the remnant of the Jews will be saved in the house of Israel by the Lord's coming and His direct touch ([link]Rom. 11:25-26[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:10[/link]).

verse.text: He said, Depart, for the girl has not died but is [xref]a[/xref]sleeping. And they laughed scornfully at Him.
But when the [note]1[/note]crowd had been [xref]a[/xref]put out, He entered and [xref]b[/xref]took hold of her hand, and the girl [note]2[/note]rose up.
verse.note: In His ministry the Lord never cared to have a crowd. See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
Lit., was roused.

verse.text: And this [xref]a[/xref]report went out into all that land.
[xref]a[/xref]And as Jesus passed on from there, two [note]1[/note]blind men followed Him, crying out and saying, Have mercy on us, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of David!
verse.note: Blindness signifies the lack of inward sight, the inability to see God and the things related to Him ([link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:18[/link]).

In the millennial kingdom, that is, in the restored tabernacle of David ([link]Acts 15:16[/link]), the Messianic kingdom, the Jews will recognize Christ as the Son of David, and their blindness will be healed. This is typified by the two blind men recognizing Christ as the Son of David.

verse.text: And when He came into the [note]1[/note]house, the blind men came to Him; and Jesus said to them, Do you believe that I am able to do this? They said to Him, Yes, Lord.
verse.note: Like the ruler's daughter ([link]v. 23[/link]) and Peter's mother-in-law ([link]8:14[/link]), the two blind men were healed in the house by the Lord's direct touch ([link]v. 29[/link]).

verse.text: Then He [xref]a[/xref]touched their eyes, saying, According to your [xref]b[/xref]faith, let it be [xref]c[/xref]done to you.
And their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eyes were opened. And Jesus sternly charged them saying, [xref]b[/xref]See that no one knows!
verse.note: The opening of the blind men's eyes signifies the recovery of inward sight, by which we see God and spiritual things ([link]Acts 9:18[/link]; [link]26:18[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:18[/link]).

verse.text: But they went out and [xref]a[/xref]spread reports about Him in all that land.
And as they were going out, behold, they brought to Him a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dumb man possessed with a demon.
verse.note: Dumbness caused by demon possession signifies man's inability to speak for God ([link]Isa. 56:10[/link]) and praise God ([link]Isa. 35:6[/link]) because of his worshipping of dumb idols ([link]1 Cor. 12:2[/link]).

verse.text: And when the demon was cast out, the dumb man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spoke. And the crowds marveled, saying, Never has [i]anything[/i] like this been [xref]b[/xref]seen in Israel.
verse.note: The dumb man's speaking signifies that our speaking and praising ability is recovered by our being filled with the Lord in the spirit ([link]Eph. 5:18-19[/link]).

verse.text: But the Pharisees said, By the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ruler of the demons He casts out the demons.
verse.note: The ruler of the demons is the devil, who was called Beelzebul ([link]12:24[/link]). This blaspheming word by the Pharisees was a strong continuation of the rejection of the heavenly King by the leaders of Judaism.

verse.text: And Jesus went about all the cities and the [xref]a[/xref]villages, [xref]b[/xref]teaching in their synagogues and preaching the [note]1[/note]gospel of the kingdom and healing [note]2[/note]every disease and every sickness.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].
[i]Every disease and every sickness[/i] signifies spiritual illness.

verse.text: And seeing the crowds, He was moved with [xref]a[/xref]compassion for them, because they were [note]1[/note]harassed and cast away like [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sheep not having a [note]2[/note]shepherd.
verse.note: In Greek [i]harassed[/i] refers to the sheep's being skinned by a cruel shepherd and thus suffering pain. [i]Cast away[/i] refers to the sheep's being abandoned by a wicked shepherd and falling into a distressed condition in which they are homeless, wandering from place to place, and helpless. The Lord Jesus' word here depicts a situation in which the pitiful Israelites were afflicted and in anguish under the hands of the chief priests and scribes, the evil shepherds.

This indicates that the heavenly King considered the Israelites sheep and Himself their Shepherd. When Christ came to the Jews the first time, they were like lepers, paralytics, the demon-possessed, and all manner of pitiful persons because they had no shepherd to care for them. Now in His kingly ministry for the establishing of His heavenly kingdom, He ministered to them not only as a Physician but also as a Shepherd, as prophesied in [link]Isa. 53:6[/link] and [link]40:11[/link].

verse.text: Then He said to His disciples, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]harvest is great, but the workers few;
verse.note: The heavenly King considered the people not only sheep but also the harvest. The sheep needed shepherding and the harvest needed reaping. Although the leaders of the nation of Israel had rejected the heavenly King, there were still a good number among the people who needed reaping.

verse.text: Therefore [note]1[/note]beseech the [note]2[/note]Lord of the harvest that He would thrust out [xref]a[/xref]workers [note]3[/note]into His harvest.
verse.note: First, in His economy God has a plan to accomplish; then there is the need for His people to beseech Him, to pray to Him, concerning it. In answering their prayer, He will accomplish what they have prayed concerning His plan.

The King of the heavenly kingdom considered Himself not only the Shepherd of the sheep but also the Lord of the harvest. His kingdom is established with things of life that can grow and multiply. He is the Lord who owns this crop.
I.e., to participate in His harvest.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And He called His [note]1[/note]twelve disciples to [i]Him[/i] and gave them [note]2[/note]authority over unclean spirits, so that they would cast them out and [xref]b[/xref]heal every disease and every sickness.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]. So also in [link book="Matt." chapter="10"]v. 2[/link].

The authority to cast out unclean spirits and heal diseases is a foretaste of the power of the coming age ([link]Heb. 6:5[/link]), that is, of the millennium, in which all demons will be cast out and all diseases will be healed ([link]Isa. 35:5-6[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the names of the twelve [note]1[/note]apostles are these: first, [xref]b[/xref]Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; and [xref]c[/xref]James the [i]son[/i] of Zebedee, and John his brother;
verse.note: An apostle is a sent one. Now the twelve disciples ([link]v. 1[/link]) were to be sent; thus they became the twelve apostles.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Philip and Bartholomew; [xref]b[/xref]Thomas and [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Matthew the [note]2[/note]tax collector; James the [i]son[/i] of Alphaeus, and [note]3[/note]Thaddaeus;
verse.note: Mark and Luke listed Matthew before Thomas ([link]Mark 3:18[/link]; [link]Luke 6:15[/link]), but Matthew, the writer of this book, listed himself after Thomas, showing his humility.

Here Matthew specifically designated himself "the tax collector," perhaps remembering his salvation with gratitude. Even a despised and sinful tax collector could become an apostle of the King of the heavenly kingdom. What a salvation!
Thaddaeus here is Judas ([link]Luke 6:16[/link]; [link]Acts 1:13[/link]; [link]John 14:22[/link]).

verse.text: Simon the [note]1[/note]Cananaean, and Judas [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Iscariot, who also [note]3[/note]betrayed Him.
verse.note: From the Hebrew word [i]kanna,[/i] meaning [i]zealous;[/i] referring not to the land of Canaan but to a Galilean sect known as the Zealots. (See [link]Luke 6:15[/link]; [link]Acts 1:13[/link].)
This word, probably from Hebrew, means [i]a man of Kerioth.[/i] Kerioth was in Judah ([link]Josh. 15:25[/link]). Among the apostles, only Judas was from Judea; all the rest were Galileans.
Lit., delivered Him up. So throughout the book.

verse.text: These twelve Jesus [xref]a[/xref]sent forth, charging them,[separator]saying, Do not go into the way of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Gentiles, and do not enter into any city of the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Samaritans.
verse.note: The Samaritans were a mixture of Gentile and Jewish blood ([link]2 Kings 17:24[/link]; [link]Ezra 4:10[/link]; [link]John 4:9[/link]). The twelve apostles were sent to the house of Israel ([link]v. 6[/link]) and were charged not to go to the Gentiles or to the Samaritans.

verse.text: But go rather to the lost [xref]a[/xref]sheep of the house of [xref]b[/xref]Israel.
And as you go, proclaim, saying, The [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of the heavens has [note]1[/note]drawn near.
verse.note: Even by that time the kingdom of the heavens had not yet come but had only drawn near.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse the lepers, cast out demons. [xref]b[/xref]Freely you have received; freely give.
[xref]a[/xref]Do [note]1[/note]not acquire for yourselves gold nor silver nor copper for your belts;
verse.note: The twelve apostles (sent to the house of Israel, not to the Gentiles), as workers worthy of their food, did not need to bring their necessities with them. (However, the Lord's workers sent to the Gentiles should take nothing from the Gentiles — [link]3 John 7[/link].) This principle was changed after the Lord had been fully rejected by the house of Israel ([link]Luke 22:35-38[/link]).

verse.text: No bag for the journey nor two tunics nor sandals nor a staff; for the [xref]a[/xref]worker is worthy of his food.
And into whatever city or village you enter, find out who in it is worthy; and there remain until you depart.
And as you enter into the house, greet it.
And if the house is worthy, let your peace come upon it; but if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.
And whoever does not receive you nor hear your words, as you go out of that house or city, [xref]a[/xref]shake off the dust from your feet.
Truly I say to you, It will be [note]1[/note]more tolerable for the land of [xref]a[/xref]Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city.
verse.note: Indicating that the punishment resulting from God's judgment is in varying degrees. Rejecting the Lord's apostles and their words ([link]v. 14[/link]) will bring more punishment than will the sin of Sodom and Gomorrah.

verse.text: Behold, I send you forth as [xref]a[/xref]sheep in the midst of [xref]b[/xref]wolves. Be therefore [note]1[/note]prudent as [xref]c[/xref]serpents and guileless as [xref]d[/xref]doves.
verse.note: As sheep in the midst of wolves, the Lord's apostles, although not serpents, need to be prudent as serpents to escape being hurt by the wolves, and guileless as doves, not mixed with any evil intention and not hurting others.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]beware of men, for they will [note]1[/note]deliver you up to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanhedrins, and in their synagogues they will [xref]c[/xref]scourge you.
verse.note: The heavenly King's prediction here concerning the persecution of His apostles by Judaism indicated that the kingdom He was establishing through His apostles' preaching would be rejected by Judaism. This too proves that His kingdom is not earthly but heavenly.
See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And you will also be brought before [note]1[/note]governors and [xref]a[/xref]kings for My sake, for a [xref]b[/xref]testimony to them and to the Gentiles.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]princes[/i] in [link]2:6[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]But when they deliver you up, do not be [xref]b[/xref]anxious about how or what you should speak, for it will be given to you in that hour what you should speak;
For you are not the ones speaking, but the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of your Father is the One speaking in you.
verse.note: The apostles have not only the authority of the heavenly King ([link]v. 1[/link]) but also the Spirit of their Father. The King's authority deals with unclean spirits and diseases; the Father's Spirit deals with the opposers' persecution.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]brother will deliver up brother to death, and father [i]his[/i] child; and [xref]a[/xref]children will rise up against [i]their[/i] parents and put them to death.
verse.note: Those who would be the heavenly King's apostles for the preaching of the gospel of the kingdom must suffer the breaking of the closest human ties.

verse.text: And you will be [xref]a[/xref]hated by all because of My name. But he who has [xref]b[/xref]endured to the end, this one shall be [note]1[/note]saved.
verse.note: Here, to be saved may mean to be saved from those who hate us; eventually, it will mean to be saved into the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, a reward to the overcoming believers. This differs from eternal salvation as revealed in [link]Eph. 2:8[/link].

verse.text: And when they persecute you in this [xref]a[/xref]city, [xref]b[/xref]flee into another. For truly I say to you, You shall by no means [note]1[/note]finish the cities of Israel until the [xref]c[/xref]Son of Man comes.
verse.note: This word was not fulfilled by the twelve apostles' preaching before Christ's crucifixion. It will not be fulfilled until the great tribulation ([link]24:21[/link]). The prediction in [link]vv. 17-23[/link] is very similar to that in [link]24:9-13[/link]. Here the heavenly King sent the apostles to preach the gospel of the kingdom to the Jews. After His resurrection He sent His apostles to preach the gospel to the Gentiles. After the fullness of the salvation of the Gentiles, He will send His apostles to preach the gospel of the kingdom again to the Jews. At that time, this word will be fulfilled, and He will come.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]disciple is not [note]1[/note]above the teacher, nor a [xref]b[/xref]slave above his master.
verse.note: According to the context, the word here means that in suffering persecution His apostles cannot be above Him, because He was persecuted to the uttermost.

verse.text: It is sufficient for the disciple that he become like his teacher, and the slave like his master. If they have called the Master of the house [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beelzebul, how much more those of His household!
verse.note: Beelzebub, meaning [i]the lord of flies,[/i] was the name of the god of the Ekronites ([link]2 Kings 1:2[/link]). It was changed contemptuously by the Jews to Beelzebul, which means [i]the lord of the dunghill,[/i] and was used for the ruler of the demons ([link]12:24[/link], [link]27[/link]; [link]Mark 3:22[/link]; [link]Luke 11:15[/link], [link]18-19[/link]). In [link]9:34[/link] the Pharisees, the leading ones of the Jewish religion, reviled the heavenly King by saying that He cast out demons by the ruler of demons. In using this most blasphemous name, they expressed their strongest objection and rejection.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Therefore do not fear them; for there is nothing [xref]b[/xref]covered which will not be revealed, and [xref]c[/xref]hidden which will not be made known.
What I say to you in the darkness, speak in the light; and what you hear in the ear, proclaim on the [xref]a[/xref]housetops.

And do not [xref]a[/xref]fear those who kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul; but rather [xref]b[/xref]fear [note]1[/note]Him who is able to [xref]c[/xref]destroy both soul and body in [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]Gehenna.
verse.note: God is the only One who is able to destroy both man's soul and man's body in Gehenna. This word implies that if the apostles sent by the Lord fail to suffer persecution, they will be disciplined by God. This discipline will take place in the coming age, after the judgment at the judgment seat of Christ, when the believers will receive reward or punishment ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]).
See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: Are not two sparrows sold for an [note]1[/note]assarion? And not one of them will fall to the earth apart from your Father.
verse.note: An ancient Roman coin equal to one-sixteenth of a denarius. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: But even the [xref]a[/xref]hairs of your head are all numbered.
Therefore do not fear; you are of [xref]a[/xref]more value than many sparrows.
Everyone therefore who will [xref]a[/xref]confess [note]1[/note]in Me before men, I also will [xref]b[/xref]confess [note]2[/note]in him before My Father who is in the heavens;
verse.note: Implying his union with the Lord.
Implying the Lord's union with him.

verse.text: But whoever will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]deny Me before men, I also will [note]1[/note]deny him before My Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: This word was spoken by the heavenly King to His apostles, who were sent by Him to preach the gospel of the kingdom. He foretold that they would be persecuted ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]21-23[/link]). If anyone under persecution denies Him, He will deny him at His coming back ([link]16:27[/link]). Their being denied or confessed by Him at that time will determine whether His apostles are worthy to enter the kingdom of the heavens as a reward in the coming age.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Do not think that I have come to bring peace on the earth; I have not [note]1[/note]come to bring peace, but a sword.
verse.note: The whole earth is under Satan's usurpation ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]). The heavenly King came to call some out from that usurpation. This certainly aroused Satan's opposition. He instigated the people under his usurpation to fight against the heavenly King's called ones. Thus, His coming did not bring peace but a sword.

verse.text: For I have come to set [i]men[/i] at variance: a man against his [xref]a[/xref]father, and a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law;
And a man's [xref]a[/xref]enemies will be those of his [note]1[/note]household.
verse.note: The fighting instigated by the usurping Satan against the heavenly King's called ones is waged even in their own household. The heavenly called ones are attacked in their homes by their kindred who remain under the evil one's usurping hand.

verse.text: He who loves [xref]a[/xref]father or mother [note]1[/note]above Me is not worthy of Me; and he who loves son or daughter above Me is not worthy of Me;
verse.note: Our love for the Lord must be absolute. We should love nothing above Him. He is the One most worthy of our love, and we must be worthy of Him.

verse.text: And he who does not [note]1[/note]take his [xref]a[/xref]cross and [xref]b[/xref]follow after Me is not worthy of Me.
verse.note: Christ took the Father's will and was crucified ([link]26:39[/link], [link]42[/link]). When He was baptized, He was counted as crucified, and from that time He bore His cross to do the will of God. His called ones were identified with Him. He asked them to take their cross and follow after Him, that is, to take the will of God by putting themselves aside. This demanded that at any cost they first give their love to Him that they might be worthy of Him.

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note]finds his [xref]a[/xref]soul-life shall [note]1[/note]lose it, and he who loses his soul-life for My sake shall find it.
verse.note: To find the soul-life is to allow the soul to have its enjoyment and to escape suffering. To lose the soul-life is to cause the soul to lose its enjoyment and thereby to suffer. If the heavenly King's followers allow their soul to have its enjoyment in this age, they will cause their soul to suffer the loss of its enjoyment in the coming kingdom age. If they allow their soul to suffer the loss of its enjoyment in this age for the King's sake, they will enable their soul to have its enjoyment in the coming kingdom age, that is, to share the King's joy in ruling over the earth ([link]25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]).

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]receives you receives Me, and he who [xref]b[/xref]receives Me receives Him who has sent Me.
verse.note: The apostles sent by the heavenly King, having been entrusted with His authority ([link]v. 1[/link]) and peace ([link]v. 13[/link]), and having been indwelt by the Spirit of the Father and identified with the King in His suffering ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]24-25[/link]) and death ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]34-39[/link]), were one with Him. Thus, he who received them received Him. To participate in such an identification with the heavenly King requires us to love Him above all, at any cost, and to follow Him by taking the narrow way of the cross, as revealed in [link]vv. 37-39[/link].

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]receives a [note]2[/note]prophet in the name of a prophet shall receive a prophet's reward, and he who [note]1[/note]receives a [note]2[/note]righteous man in the name of a righteous man shall receive a righteous man's reward.
verse.note: One who receives a prophet is joined to the prophet's word, and one who receives a righteous man is joined to the righteousness of the righteous man. Thus, these two will receive the reward of a prophet and of a righteous man, respectively.

A prophet is one who speaks for God and speaks forth God. A righteous man is one who seeks after righteousness, who practices righteousness, and who is persecuted for the sake of righteousness for the kingdom ([link]5:6[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]6:1[/link]). The heavenly King was such, a Prophet sent by God ([link]Deut. 18:15[/link]) and a righteous man ([link]Acts 3:14[/link]). His apostles, sent by Him, were identified with Him and thus also were prophets and righteous men. Hence, whoever received them received Him and will receive a reward.

verse.text: And whoever gives to one of these [xref]a[/xref]little ones only a [xref]b[/xref]cup of cold water to drink in the name of a disciple, truly I say to you, he shall by no means lose his [note]1[/note]reward.
verse.note: This reward will be given in the coming kingdom age ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]).

verse.text: And when Jesus had finished giving instructions to His twelve disciples, He departed from there to [xref]a[/xref]teach and to preach in their cities.
[xref]a[/xref]Now when John heard in the [xref]b[/xref]prison of the [xref]c[/xref]works of the Christ, he sent [i]word[/i] through his disciples
And said to Him, [note]1[/note]Are You the [xref]a[/xref]Coming One, or should we expect [note]2[/note]another?
verse.note: John the Baptist's word here does not mean that he was in doubt concerning Christ. He questioned Christ in this way in order to provoke Him to deliver him. He knew that Christ was the Coming One, and he had strongly recommended Him to the people ([link]John 1:26-36[/link]). After that, John was put into prison ([link]4:12[/link]), where he waited, expecting that Christ would do something to deliver him. However, Christ did nothing for him, although He did much to help others. When John heard of this, it might have been that he was about to be stumbled ([link]v. 6[/link]). Hence, he sent his disciples with such a question to provoke Christ.
The Greek word means [i]a different one.[/i]

verse.text: And Jesus answered and said to them, Go, report to John the things that you hear and see:

The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blind receive their sight and the [note]2[/note]lame walk; the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]lepers are cleansed and the [note]4[/note]deaf hear; and the [note]5[/note]dead are raised and the [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]poor have the gospel announced to them;
verse.note: The Lord mentioned first the blind's receiving of sight, because there had been no such miracle in the Old Testament. By this He gave clear evidence to John that none other than the Messiah could have done such a miracle ([link]Isa. 35:5[/link]). In the spiritual sense also, the blind's receiving of sight comes first. In the Lord's salvation, first He opens our eyes ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]); then we can receive Him and walk to follow Him.
The lame signify those who cannot walk in God's way. After being saved, they can walk by a new life ([link]9:5-6[/link]; [link]John 5:8-9[/link]).
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
The deaf signify those who cannot hear God. After being saved, they can hear the Lord's voice ([link]John 10:27[/link]).
The dead signify those who are dead in sins ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link]), unable to contact God. After being regenerated, they can fellowship with God by means of their regenerated spirit.

The poor signify all who are without Christ and without God and who have no hope in the world ([link]Eph. 2:12[/link]). Upon receiving the gospel, they are made rich in Christ ([link]2 Cor. 8:9[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:8[/link]).

verse.text: And blessed is he who is not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stumbled because of Me.
verse.note: This word implies that John the Baptist might have been stumbled because of the Lord, because the Lord did not act on his behalf according to his way. Here the Lord encouraged him to take the way He had ordained for him, that he might be blessed. This blessing is very much related to participation in the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: And as these went away, Jesus began to [note]1[/note]say to the crowds concerning John, What did you go out into the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness to [note]2[/note]look at? A [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]reed shaken by the wind?
verse.note: The Lord's reply to John implicitly indicated John's mistake. However, His words to the crowds concerning John explicitly testified for John.
The Greek word means [i]to view attentively.[/i]
A reed signifies a weak and fragile person ([link]12:20[/link]; [link]1 Kings 14:15[/link]). When John the Baptist was testifying for Christ in the wilderness, he was not such a weak person.

verse.text: But what did you go out to [note]1[/note]see? A [note]2[/note]man arrayed in soft [xref]a[/xref]clothing? Behold, those who wear soft clothing are in the houses of kings.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]perceive.[/i] So in the next verse.

In the wilderness, while he was boldly testifying for Christ, John the Baptist was not a weak person who wore soft clothing. The Lord testified that he was neither a reed shaken by the wind nor a man arrayed in soft clothing.

verse.text: But why did you go out? To see a [xref]a[/xref]prophet? Yes, I say to you, and [note]1[/note]much more than a prophet.
verse.note: The Lord testified that John was much more than a prophet.

verse.text: This is he concerning whom it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, who will prepare Your way before You."
Truly I say to you, Among those born of women there has not arisen one greater than John the Baptist, yet he who is [note]1[/note]least [note]2[/note]in the kingdom of the heavens is greater than he.
verse.note: Lit., less. All the prophets prior to John prophesied only that Christ was coming, but John testified that Christ had come. The prophets were looking forward to Christ, but John saw Christ. Hence, John was greater than all the prophets. Although John saw the incarnated Christ and introduced Him to people, he did not have the resurrected Christ indwelling him. The kingdom people do. John could say only, "Here is Christ," but the kingdom people can say, "To me, to live is Christ" ([link]Phil. 1:21[/link]). Hence, the least in the kingdom of the heavens is greater than he. Whether a person is greater or lesser depends on his relationship to Christ. Christ is the deciding factor. The closer one is to Christ, the greater one is.
This word indicates that up to that time the kingdom of the heavens had not come and that John the Baptist was not in it.

verse.text: But from the days of John the Baptist until now, the kingdom of the heavens is taken by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]violence, and violent men seize it.
verse.note: From the days of John the Baptist until that time, the Pharisees were violently frustrating people from entering the kingdom of the heavens. Hence, those who desired to enter had to do so "by violence."

verse.text: For all the [xref]a[/xref]prophets and the law prophesied [note]1[/note]until John;
verse.note: This proves that the Old Testament dispensation was terminated by the coming of John.

verse.text: And if you are willing to receive [note]1[/note][i]it,[/i] he is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Elijah, who is to come.
verse.note: Or, him.

[link]Malachi 4:5[/link] prophesies that Elijah will come. When John the Baptist was conceived, it was said that he would go before the Lord in the spirit and power of Elijah ([link]Luke 1:17[/link]). Hence, in a sense, John may be considered "Elijah, who is to come" (cf. [link]17:10-13[/link]). However, the prophecy of [link]Mal. 4:5[/link] will actually be fulfilled during the great tribulation, when the real Elijah, one of the two witnesses, will come to strengthen God's people ([link]Rev. 11:3-12[/link]).

verse.text: He who has [xref]a[/xref]ears to hear, let him hear.
But to what shall I liken this [xref]a[/xref]generation? It is like little children sitting in the marketplaces, who call to the others
And say, We have [note]1[/note]played the flute to you, and you did not dance; we have [note]1[/note]sung a dirge, and you did not mourn.
verse.note: Christ and John the Baptist "played the flute" to preach the gospel of the kingdom, but the Jewish religionists did not "dance" for the joy of salvation; John and Christ "sang a dirge" to preach repentance, but the Jewish religionists did not mourn for the grief of sin. The righteousness of God demanded that they repent, but they would not obey; the grace of God afforded them salvation, but they would not receive it.

verse.text: For John came [note]1[/note]neither [xref]a[/xref]eating nor [xref]b[/xref]drinking; and they say, He has a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]demon.
verse.note: John, coming to bring men to repentance ([link]Mark 1:4[/link]) and to cause them to grieve for sin, had no taste for eating and drinking ([link]Luke 1:15-17[/link]); whereas Christ, coming to bring salvation to sinners and to cause them to rejoice in it, had the joy of eating and drinking with them ([link]9:10-11[/link]). The kingdom people, who are under no regulation, follow the divine wisdom, concentrating on the indwelling Christ, who is their wisdom ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]), not on the outward manner of life.
Because John the Baptist lived in a strange and peculiar way, not eating or drinking in the ordinary way, the opposers said, "He has a demon," i.e., that he was demon-possessed.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man came [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]eating and drinking; and they say, Behold, a gluttonous man and a drunkard, a [note]2[/note]friend of [xref]c[/xref]tax collectors and sinners. Yet [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]wisdom is justified by her [note]4[/note]works.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Christ is not only the Savior but also the Friend of sinners, who sympathizes with their problems and senses their grief.

Wisdom is Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:24[/link], [link]30[/link]). Whatever Christ did was done by the wisdom of God, which is Christ Himself. This wisdom was justified, vindicated, by His wise works, His wise deeds.
Some ancient authorities read, children (see [link]Luke 7:35[/link]). The kingdom people are the children of wisdom, who justify Christ and His deeds and follow Him as their wisdom.

verse.text: Then He began to reproach the cities in which most of His [xref]a[/xref]works of power took place, because they did not repent:

[xref]a[/xref]Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, [xref]b[/xref]Bethsaida! For if the works of power which took place in you had taken place in [xref]c[/xref]Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in [xref]d[/xref]sackcloth and [xref]e[/xref]ashes.
But I say to you, It will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the day of judgment than for you.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link]. So in [link chapter="11"]v. 24[/link].

verse.text: And you, [xref]a[/xref]Capernaum, who have been [xref]b[/xref]exalted to heaven, [xref]c[/xref]to [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Hades you will be brought down. For if the works of power which took place in you had taken place in Sodom, it would have remained until today.
verse.note: Hades, equal to Sheol in the Old Testament ([link]Gen. 37:35[/link]; [link]Psa. 6:5[/link]), is the place where the souls and spirits of the dead are kept ([link]Luke 16:22-23[/link]; [link]Acts 2:27[/link]).

verse.text: But I say to you that it will be more tolerable for the land of [xref]a[/xref]Sodom in the day of judgment than for you.

[xref]a[/xref]At that time Jesus [note]1[/note]answered and said, I [note]2[/note]extol You, Father, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Lord of heaven and of earth, because You have hidden [note]4[/note]these things from the [note]5[/note]wise and intelligent and have revealed them to [note]6[/note]infants.
verse.note: While the Lord was rebuking the cities, He fellowshipped with the Father. At that time, answering the Father, He spoke to Him the extolment in [link]vv. 25-26[/link].

Lit., acknowledge with extolment. The Lord acknowledged with extolment the Father's way in carrying out His economy. Although people, instead of responding to His ministry, slandered Him ([link]vv. 16-19[/link]) and the leading cities rejected Him ([link]vv. 20-24[/link]), He extolled the Father, acknowledging the Father's will. He did not seek prosperity in His work but sought the Father's will; His satisfaction and rest were not in being understood and welcomed by man but in being known by the Father ([link]vv. 26-27[/link]).

In the Lord's extolling address, "Father" refers to the Father's relationship with Him, the Son, whereas "Lord of heaven and of earth" refers to God's relationship with the universe. When God's people were defeated by His enemy, God was called "the God of heaven" ([link]Ezra 5:11-12[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:18[/link], [link]37[/link]). But when there was a man standing for Him on the earth, God was called the "Possessor of heaven and earth" ([link]Gen. 14:19[/link], [link]22[/link]). Now the Lord as the Son of Man called the Father "Lord of heaven and of earth," indicating that the Lord was standing on the earth for God's interest.
The things regarding the knowledge of the Son and of the Father ([link]v. 27[/link]).

[i]The wise and intelligent[/i] refers to the people of the three cities condemned in [link]vv. 20-24[/link], people who were wise and intelligent in their own eyes. The Father's will was to hide the knowledge of the Son and of the Father from such people.
[i]Infants[/i] refers to the disciples, who were the children of wisdom (see note [link]19[sup]4[/sup][/link]). The Father was pleased to reveal both the Son and the Father to them.

verse.text: Yes, Father, for thus it has been well-pleasing [note]1[/note]in Your sight.
verse.note: Lit., before You.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one fully [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]knows the Son except the Father; neither does anyone fully [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]know the Father except the Son and him to whom the Son wills to [xref]d[/xref]reveal [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: [i]All things[/i] refers to the remnant whom the Father has given to the Son ([link]John 3:27[/link]; [link]6:37[/link], [link]44[/link], [link]65[/link]; [link]18:9[/link]). This word implies that the wise and intelligent rejected the Son because the Father was not pleased to give them to the Son.

Full knowledge, not mere objective acquaintance. Concerning the Son, only the Father has such knowledge, and concerning the Father, only the Son and he to whom the Son reveals Him have such knowledge. Hence, to know the Son requires that the Father reveal Him ([link]16:17[/link]), and to know the Father requires that the Son reveal Him ([link]John 17:6[/link], [link]26[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Come to Me all who [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]toil and are burdened, and I will give you [note]2[/note]rest.
verse.note: This refers not only to the toil of striving to keep the commandments of the law and religious regulations but also to the toil of struggling to be successful in any work. Whoever toils thus is always heavily burdened. After the Lord extolled the Father, acknowledging the Father's way and declaring the divine economy, He called this kind of people to come to Him for rest.
Rest refers not only to being set free from the toil and burden under the law or religion or under any work or responsibility, but also to perfect peace and full satisfaction.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Take My [note]2[/note]yoke upon you and [xref]a[/xref]learn from Me, for I am [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]meek and [note]3[/note]lowly in heart, and you will find [xref]c[/xref]rest for your [note]4[/note]souls.
verse.note: Lit., lift.

To take the Lord's yoke is to take the will of the Father. It is not to be regulated or controlled by any obligation of the law or religion or to be enslaved by any work, but to be constrained by the will of the Father. The Lord lived such a life, caring for nothing but the will of His Father ([link]John 4:34[/link]; [link]5:30[/link]; [link]6:38[/link]). He submitted Himself fully to the Father's will ([link]26:39[/link], [link]42[/link]). Hence, He asks us to learn from Him.

To be meek, or gentle, means not to resist opposition, and to be lowly means not to have self-esteem. Throughout all the opposition the Lord was meek, and throughout all the rejection He was lowly in heart. He submitted Himself fully to the will of His Father, not wanting to do anything for Himself or expecting to gain something for Himself. Hence, regardless of the situation He had rest in His heart; He was fully satisfied with His Father's will.
The rest that we find by taking the Lord's yoke and learning from Him is for our souls. It is an inward rest; it is not anything merely outward in nature.

verse.text: For My [note]1[/note]yoke is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]easy and My [note]1[/note]burden is light.
verse.note: The Lord's yoke is the Father's will, and His burden is the work of carrying out the Father's will. Such a yoke is easy, not bitter, and such a burden is light, not heavy.
The Greek word means [i]fit for use;[/i] hence, good, kind, mild, gentle, easy, pleasant — in contrast to hard, harsh, sharp, bitter.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]At that time Jesus went on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath through the grainfields. And His disciples became hungry and began to pick [xref]c[/xref]ears of grain and eat.
verse.note: [i]At that time[/i] joins this chapter to [link]ch. 11[/link]. At the time the Lord was calling people to rest from striving to keep the law and religious regulations, He went through the grainfields on the Sabbath, and His disciples began to pick ears of grain and eat, seemingly breaking the Sabbath.

verse.text: But the Pharisees, seeing [i]this,[/i] said to Him, Behold, Your disciples are doing what is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not lawful to do on the Sabbath.
verse.note: The Sabbath was ordained so that the Jews would remember the completion of God's creation ([link]Gen. 2:2[/link]), keep the sign of God's covenant made with them ([link]Ezek. 20:12[/link]), and remember God's redemption accomplished for them ([link]Deut. 5:15[/link]). Hence, to profane the Sabbath was a serious matter in the eyes of the religious Pharisees. To them it was not lawful, not scriptural. But they did not have adequate knowledge of the Scriptures. Based on their meager knowledge, they cared for the ritual of keeping the Sabbath, not for the hunger of the people. What folly to observe a vain ritual!

verse.text: But He said to them, Have you not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]read what [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]David did when he became hungry, and those who were with him;
verse.note: The Pharisees said that it was not lawful for the Lord's disciples to pick the ears in the grainfields and to eat; thus, they condemned the disciples for acting contrary to the Scriptures. But the Lord answered, "Have you not read...?" pointing out to them another aspect of the Scriptures that justified Him and His disciples. The Pharisees were thus condemned for lacking adequate knowledge of the Scriptures.

The Lord's word here implies that He is the real David. In the ancient time David and his followers, when rejected, entered into the house of God and ate the bread of the Presence ([link]v. 4[/link]), seemingly breaking the Levitical law. Now the real David and His followers were rejected, and the disciples took action to pick ears of grain and eat, seemingly going against the sabbatical regulation. Just as David and his followers were not held guilty, so Christ and His disciples should not have been condemned.[br][br]Furthermore, the Lord's word here implies the dispensational change from the priesthood to the kingship. In the ancient time the coming of David changed the dispensation from the age of the priests to the age of the kings, in which the kings were above the priests. In the age of the priests the leader of the people had to listen to the priest ([link]Num. 27:21-22[/link]). But in the age of the kings the priest had to submit to the king ([link]1 Sam. 2:35-36[/link]). Hence, what King David did with his followers was not illegal. Now the coming of Christ changed the dispensation again, this time from the age of the law to the age of grace, in which Christ is above all. Whatever He does is right.

verse.text: How he entered into the house of God, and they ate the [xref]a[/xref]bread of the Presence, which was not lawful for him to eat, nor for those who were with him, except for the [xref]b[/xref]priests only?
Or have you not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]read in the law that on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and are guiltless?
verse.note: Here the Lord pointed out to the Pharisees another case in the Scriptures, exposing how little they knew the Scriptures.

verse.text: But I say to you that something [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]greater than the [xref]b[/xref]temple is here.
verse.note: The Lord revealed to the Pharisees that He was greater than the temple. This indicated another turn, a type-fulfilling turn from the temple to a person. In the case of David there was a turn from one age to another. In this case, a case concerning the priests, there was a turn from the temple to a person who is greater than the temple. Since the priests were guiltless in acting on the Sabbath in the temple, how could the Lord's disciples be guilty in acting on the Sabbath in Him who is greater than the temple? In the first case the king broke the Levitical regulation; in the second case the priests broke the sabbatical regulation. According to the Scriptures neither was guilty. Hence, scripturally, what the Lord did here was right.

verse.text: But if you knew what [i]this[/i] means, [xref]a[/xref]"I desire mercy and not sacrifice," you would not have condemned the guiltless.
For the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man is [note]1[/note]Lord of the Sabbath.
verse.note: Here the Lord indicated the third turn, a right-asserting turn from the Sabbath to the Lord of the Sabbath. As the Lord of the Sabbath, He had the right to change the regulations concerning the Sabbath. Thus, the Lord gave the condemning Pharisees a threefold verdict. He was the real David, the greater temple, and the Lord of the Sabbath. Therefore, He could do whatever He liked on the Sabbath, and whatever He did was justified by Himself. He was above all rituals and regulations. Since He was there, no attention should have been paid to any ritual or regulation.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]departing from there, He came into their synagogue.
And behold, a man who had a withered [note]1[/note]hand [i]was there.[/i] And they asked Him, saying, Is it [xref]a[/xref]lawful to heal on the Sabbath? so that they might [xref]b[/xref]accuse Him.
verse.note: This chapter records the Lord's move on two Sabbaths ([link]Luke 6:1[/link], [link]6[/link]). What He did on the first Sabbath indicates that He cared for Himself as the Head of the Body. As the Head, He is everything — the real David, the greater temple, and the Lord of the Sabbath. What He did on the second Sabbath signifies that He cared for His members. On this Sabbath He healed a man's withered hand, likening this man to a sheep ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]). The hand is a member of the body, and the sheep is a member of the flock. The Lord would do anything for the healing of His members, for the rescue of His fallen sheep. Sabbath or no Sabbath, the Lord is interested in healing the dead members of His Body. To Him, regulations do not matter; the rescue of His fallen sheep means everything.

verse.text: And He said to them, What man will there be among you who will have one sheep, and if it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, will not take hold of it and [xref]a[/xref]lift [i]it[/i] out?
Of how much [xref]a[/xref]more value then is a man than a sheep! So then it is [xref]b[/xref]lawful to do well on the Sabbath.
Then He said to the man, Stretch out your hand. And he stretched [i]it[/i] out and it was [note]1[/note]restored, as sound as the other.
verse.note: The Lord gave the man the word, "Stretch out your hand." In the Lord's word was the enlivening life. By stretching out his hand the man took the Lord's life-giving word, and his withered hand was restored by the life in His word.

verse.text: But the Pharisees, going out, took [xref]a[/xref]counsel against Him [i]as to[/i] how they might [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]destroy Him.
verse.note: In the eyes of the religious Pharisees, for the Lord to break the Sabbath was to destroy God's covenant with the nation of Israel, that is, to destroy the relationship between God and Israel. Hence, they took counsel against Him as to how they might destroy Him. The breaking of the Sabbath caused the Jewish religionists to reject the heavenly King.

verse.text: But Jesus, knowing [i]it,[/i] withdrew from there. And many [xref]a[/xref]followed Him, and He healed them all;
And He charged them [xref]a[/xref]not to make Him known,
In order that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled, saying,

[xref]a[/xref]"Behold, My [note]1[/note]Servant whom I have chosen, My [xref]b[/xref]Beloved in whom My soul has found delight. I will put My [xref]c[/xref]Spirit upon Him, and He will announce [note]2[/note]justice to the [note]3[/note]Gentiles.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]boy attendant.[/i]
Or, righteousness, (righteous) judgment. So in [link]v. 20[/link].

This indicates clearly that because of the Jews' rejection, the heavenly King with His heavenly kingdom would turn to the Gentiles, and the Gentiles would receive Him and trust in Him ([link]v. 21[/link]).

verse.text: He will not strive nor cry out, nor will anyone hear His voice in the streets.
A [note]1[/note]bruised reed He will not break, and smoking [note]2[/note]flax He will not quench until He brings forth justice unto victory.
verse.note: The Jews were accustomed to making flutes of reeds. When a reed was bruised, they broke it. Also, they made torches out of flax, which can burn oil. When the oil ran out, the flax smoked and they quenched it. Some of the Lord's people are like a bruised reed, which cannot give a musical sound; others are like smoking flax, which cannot produce a shining light. Yet the Lord will not break the bruised ones or quench the smoking ones.
The Greek word refers to a torch made with flax.

verse.text: And in His name will the Gentiles [xref]a[/xref]hope."
[xref]a[/xref]Then there was brought to Him one possessed by a demon, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]blind and [xref]c[/xref]dumb, and He healed him, so that the dumb man spoke and saw.
verse.note: A blind and dumb man signifies one who is without spiritual sight, i.e., who is unable to see God and spiritual things, and who, for this reason, is unable to praise God and speak for God. This is the real condition of all fallen people.

verse.text: And all the crowds were amazed and said, Is this not the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of David?
verse.note: This indicates that they recognized Christ as their Messiah, their King.

verse.text: But the Pharisees, hearing [i]this,[/i] said, This man does not cast out the demons except by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beelzebul, [xref]b[/xref]ruler of the demons.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link]. So in [link chapter="12"]v. 27[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]But [xref]b[/xref]knowing their thoughts, He said to them, Every kingdom divided against itself becomes desolate, and every city or house divided against itself will not stand.
And if Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself. How then will his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom stand?
verse.note: Satan is the ruler of this world ([link]John 12:31[/link]) and the ruler of the authority of the air ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]). He has his authority ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]) and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]), who are his subordinates as rulers, authorities, and world-rulers of the darkness of this world ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]). Hence, he has his kingdom, the authority of darkness ([link]Col. 1:13[/link]).

verse.text: And if I, by [xref]a[/xref]Beelzebul, cast out the demons, by whom do your sons [xref]b[/xref]cast [i]them[/i] out? Therefore they shall be your judges.
But if I, by the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of God, cast out the demons, then the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God has come upon you.
verse.note: The Spirit of God is the power of the kingdom of God. Where the Spirit of God is in power, there the kingdom of God is, and there the demons have no ground.
The kingdom of God, not the kingdom of the heavens, is indicated here. Even at that time the kingdom of the heavens still had not come. The kingdom of God, however, was there already.

verse.text: Or how can anyone enter into the [note]1[/note]house of the [note]2[/note]strong man and [xref]a[/xref]plunder his [note]3[/note]goods unless he first [note]4[/note]binds the strong man? And then he will thoroughly plunder his house.
verse.note: The house here signifies the kingdom of Satan.
The strong man is Satan, the evil one.
Or, instruments, apparatus; hence, goods, stuff. The fallen people, who are under Satan, are his vessels, his instruments, and are for his use. They are his goods, kept in his house, his kingdom.
This indicates that when the Lord cast out demons, He first bound Satan.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]He who is not with Me is [xref]a[/xref]against Me, and he who does not gather with Me scatters.
verse.note: See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Therefore I say to you, Every sin and [xref]b[/xref]blasphemy will be forgiven men, but [note]1[/note]blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven.
verse.note: Blaspheming the Spirit differs from insulting the Spirit ([link]Heb. 10:29[/link]). To insult the Spirit is to disobey Him willfully. Many believers do this. If they confess this sin, they will be forgiven and cleansed by the Lord's blood ([link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]9[/link]). But to blaspheme the Spirit is to slander Him, as the Pharisees did in [link]v. 24[/link]. It was by the Spirit that the Lord cast out a demon. But the Pharisees, seeing it, said that the Lord cast out demons by Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons. This was blasphemy against the Spirit. By such blasphemy the Pharisees' rejection of the heavenly King reached its climax.

verse.text: And whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man, it will be forgiven him; but whoever [note]1[/note]speaks against the Holy Spirit, it will not be forgiven him, [xref]a[/xref]neither in this [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]age nor in the one to come.
verse.note: In the economy of the Triune God, the Father conceived the plan of redemption ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link], [link]9[/link]), the Son accomplished redemption according to the Father's plan ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:4[/link]), and the Spirit reaches sinners to apply the redemption accomplished by the Son ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]). If a sinner blasphemes the Son, as Saul of Tarsus did, the Spirit will still have the ground to work on him and cause him to repent and believe in the Son that he may be forgiven (see [link]1 Tim. 1:13-16[/link]). But if a sinner blasphemes the Spirit, the Spirit will have no ground to work on him, and there will be no one left to cause him to repent and believe. Hence, it is impossible for such a person to be forgiven. This is not only logical according to reason but also governmental according to God's administrative principle, as revealed here by the Lord's word.

In God's governmental administration His forgiveness is dispensational. For His administration He has planned different ages. The period from the first coming of Christ to eternity is divided dispensationally into three ages: (1) this age, the present one, from Christ's first coming to His second coming; (2) the coming age, the millennium, the one thousand years for restoration and heavenly reigning, from Christ's second coming to the end of the old heaven and old earth; and (3) eternity, the eternal age of the new heaven and new earth. God's forgiveness in this age is for sinners' eternal salvation. This forgiveness is given to both sinners and believers. God's forgiveness in the coming age is related to the believers' dispensational reward. If after being saved a believer commits a sin but will not make a clearance through confession and the cleansing of the Lord's blood ([link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]9[/link]) before he dies or the Lord comes back, the sin will not be forgiven in this age but will remain and will be judged at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]). In such a case, the believer will not be rewarded with the kingdom, i.e., will not participate with Christ in the glory and joy in the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, but will be disciplined so that the sin is cleared, and will be forgiven in the coming age ([link]18:23-35[/link]). This kind of forgiveness will maintain this believer's eternal salvation but will not qualify him to participate in the glory and joy of the coming kingdom.

verse.text: Either make the tree good and its [xref]a[/xref]fruit good, or make the tree corrupt and its fruit corrupt; for [note]1[/note]by the fruit the tree is known.
verse.note: Lit., from.

verse.text: Offspring of [xref]a[/xref]vipers, how can you, being evil, speak good things? For out of the abundance of the [xref]b[/xref]heart the mouth speaks.
The good man, out of his good treasure, brings forth good things, and the evil man, out of his evil treasure, brings forth evil things.
And I say to you that every [note]1[/note]idle word which men shall speak, they will render an [xref]a[/xref]account concerning it in the day of [xref]b[/xref]judgment.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]not working.[/i] An idle word is a non-working word, an inoperative word, a word that has no positive function and is useless, unprofitable, unfruitful, and barren. Those who have spoken such words will render an account concerning every one of them in the day of judgment. Since this is the case, how much more must we account for every wicked word!

verse.text: For by your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]words you shall be justified, and by your words you shall be condemned.
verse.note: What a warning this is! We must learn to control and restrict our speaking.

verse.text: Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered Him, saying, Teacher, we want to see a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sign from You.
verse.note: A sign is a miracle that has some spiritual significance. The Jews always seek signs ([link]1 Cor. 1:22[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]But He answered and said to them, An [xref]b[/xref]evil and adulterous [note]1[/note]generation seeks after a sign, and a sign shall not be given to it except the sign of Jonah the prophet.
verse.note: [i]Age[/i] in [link]v. 32[/link] refers to time; [i]generation[/i] here refers to people.

verse.text: For just as Jonah was in the belly of the great fish [xref]a[/xref]three days and three nights, so will the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man be in the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]heart of the earth [xref]d[/xref]three days and three nights.
verse.note: The heart of the earth is called "the lower parts of the earth" ([link]Eph. 4:9[/link]) and Hades ([link]Acts 2:27[/link]), where the Lord went after His death. Hades, equal to Sheol in the Old Testament (see note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]), has two sections, the section of torment and the section of comfort ([link]Luke 16:23-26[/link]). The section of comfort is Paradise, where the Lord went with the saved thief after they died on the cross ([link]Luke 23:43[/link]). Hence, [i]heart of the earth, lower parts of the earth, Hades,[/i] and [i]Paradise[/i] are synonymous terms, referring to the place where the Lord stayed for three days and three nights after His death and before His resurrection.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Ninevite men will stand up in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, because they [xref]b[/xref]repented at the preaching of Jonah, and behold, something [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]more than Jonah is here.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]more,[/i] occurring also in [link]v. 42[/link], means [i]better in quality and larger in quantity;[/i] hence, more. It differs from the word for [i]greater[/i] in [link]v. 6[/link], which means [i]greater in external size or measure.[/i] Christ, as the Prophet sent by God to His people ([link]Deut. 18:15[/link], [link]18[/link]), is more than Jonah the prophet. Jonah was the prophet who turned from Israel to the Gentiles and was put into the belly of the great fish. After remaining there for three days, he came out to become a sign to that generation for repentance ([link]Jonah 1:2[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]3:2-10[/link]). This was a type of Christ, who would turn from Israel to the Gentiles and who would be buried in the heart of the earth for three days and then be resurrected, becoming a sign to this generation for salvation.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]queen of the south will rise up in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and behold, something [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]more than Solomon is here.
verse.note: See note [link]41[sup]1[/sup][/link]. Christ, as the Son of David, as the King, is more than Solomon the king. Solomon built the temple of God and spoke the word of wisdom. To him the Gentile queen came ([link]1 Kings 6:2[/link]; [link]10:1-8[/link]). This too was a type of Christ, who is building the church, making it the temple of God, and is speaking the word of wisdom. To Him the Gentile seekers turn.[br][br]This type, and that in [link]v. 41[/link], indicate that Christ, whether as the Prophet sent by God or as the King anointed by God, would turn from Israel to the Gentiles, as prophesied in [link]vv. 18[/link] and [link]21[/link].[br][br]According to history King Solomon preceded Jonah the prophet. But according to spiritual significance Jonah came first, as recorded in Matthew. This too shows that Matthew's record is not according to the sequence of history but according to the sequence of doctrine (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 8[/link]). According to doctrine, first Christ had to die and be resurrected; then He would build the church and speak the word of wisdom. Christ's death and resurrection are the real sign to this generation, to both the Jews and the Gentiles ([link]1 Cor. 1:22[/link], [link]24[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]When the unclean spirit goes out from the man, it roams through [note]1[/note]waterless places, seeking rest, and does not find [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The unclean spirit, a demon ([link]v. 22[/link]), seeks rest but cannot find it in waterless places because the lodging place of demons, after God's judgment by water in [link]Gen. 1:2[/link], is the sea. (See [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Two.) Since a demon cannot find rest in dry places, it returns to the human body that it originally possessed and settles down there ([link]vv. 44-45[/link]).

verse.text: Then it says, I will return to my house from which I came out. And it comes and finds [i]it[/i] unoccupied, swept, and decorated.

Then it goes and takes along with itself seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter in and settle down there. And the last state of that man becomes worse than the first. Thus shall it be also with [note]1[/note]this [xref]a[/xref]evil generation.
verse.note: Doctrinally, [link]v. 43[/link] continues [link]v. 22[/link]. Between these two verses is a record of the Jews' rejection of Christ and of Christ's forsaking of them. Here the Lord likened the evil generation of the rejecting Jews to the demon-possessed man. In the eyes of the Lord the rejecting Jews were like the demon-possessed people. The signs of Jonah and Solomon indicated that the Gentiles would repent, but the case of the demon-possessed man indicated that the rejecting Jews would not repent. They would only sweep away the dirt and decorate by adding good things to beautify themselves. They would not receive Christ and allow Him to fill them. Rather, they would remain empty and unoccupied. This is the actual condition of today's Jews. Near the end of this age they will be seven times more possessed by demons, and their state will become worse than ever.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]While He was still speaking to the crowds, behold, His [xref]b[/xref]mother and His [xref]c[/xref]brothers stood outside seeking to speak to Him.
And someone said to Him, Behold, Your mother and Your brothers are standing outside seeking to speak to You.
But He answered and said to him who spoke to Him, [note]1[/note]Who is My mother, and who are My brothers?
verse.note: This indicates that the heavenly King forsook His relationship in the flesh with the Jews. In this chapter the Jews' rejection of Christ, having reached its climax, caused Christ to forsake them fully. At this point the break between them and Christ began, and they were severed from Christ ([link]Rom. 11:17[/link], [link]19-20[/link]).

verse.text: And stretching out His hand toward His disciples, He said, Behold, My mother and My brothers!
For whoever [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]does the will of My Father who is in the heavens, he is My [xref]b[/xref]brother and sister and mother.
verse.note: After breaking with the Jews, Christ turned to the Gentiles. Thenceforth His relationship with His followers was not in the flesh but in the spirit. Whoever does the will of His Father is a brother who helps Him, a sister who sympathizes with Him, and a mother who tenderly loves Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]On that day Jesus went out of the [xref]b[/xref]house and sat beside the sea.
verse.note: At the end of [link]ch. 12[/link] the heavenly King, having been fully rejected by the leaders of the Jewish religion, made a break with them. On that day He went out of the house and sat beside the sea. This is very significant. The house signifies the house of Israel ([link]10:6[/link]), and the sea signifies the Gentile world ([link]Dan. 7:3[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:15[/link]). The King's going out of the house to sit beside the sea signifies that after His break with the Jews, He forsook the house of Israel and turned to the Gentiles. It was after this, while on the seashore, that He gave the parables concerning the mysteries of the kingdom. This signifies that the mysteries of the kingdom were revealed in the church. Hence, all the parables in this chapter were spoken to His disciples, not to the Jews.

verse.text: And great crowds were gathered to Him, so that He stepped into a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]boat and sat, and all the crowd stood on the shore.
verse.note: The boat, which was in the sea but not of the sea, signifies the church, which is in the world but not of the world. It was in the boat, in the church, that the King of the heavenly kingdom, after forsaking the Jews and turning to the Gentiles, revealed in parables the mysteries of the kingdom.
