verse.text: And He spoke many things to them in parables, saying, [note]1[/note]Behold, the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sower went out to sow.
verse.note: In contrast to what He said in the other six parables ([link]vv. 24[/link], [link]31[/link], [link]33[/link], [link]44-45[/link], [link]47[/link]), at the beginning of this parable, the first of the seven parables concerning the mysteries of the kingdom, the Lord did not say, "The kingdom of the heavens is (or, has become) like...," because the kingdom of the heavens began with the second parable. In this first parable the Lord went out only to sow the seed for the kingdom. At that time the seed had not yet grown to be the crop for the formation of the kingdom. As the Lord said in His preaching at that time, the kingdom had not yet come but had only drawn near ([link]4:17[/link]).
The sower was the Lord Himself ([link]v. 37[/link]).

verse.text: And as he sowed, some [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref][i]seeds[/i] fell [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]beside the way, and the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]birds came and devoured them.
verse.note: The seeds are the word of the kingdom ([link]v. 19[/link]), the Lord being in this word as life.

[i]Beside the way[/i] refers to a place close to the way. It is hardened by the traffic of the way; thus, it is difficult for the seeds to penetrate it. The wayside signifies the heart that is hardened by worldly traffic and cannot open to understand, to comprehend, the word of the kingdom ([link]v. 19[/link]).
The birds signify the evil one, Satan, who comes and snatches away the word of the kingdom sown in the hardened heart ([link]v. 19[/link]).

verse.text: And others fell on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rocky places, where they did not have much earth, and immediately they sprang up because they had no [xref]b[/xref]depth of earth.
verse.note: The rocky places that do not have much earth signify the heart that is shallow in receiving the word of the kingdom. Deep within such a heart are rocks — hidden sins, personal desires, self-seeking, and self-pity — which hinder the seed from taking root in the depths of the heart.

verse.text: But when the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sun rose, they were scorched; and because they had no root, they withered.
verse.note: The sun with its scorching heat signifies affliction or persecution ([link]v. 21[/link]). The scorching heat of the sun causes the seed that is not rooted to wither. The heat of the sun is for the growth and ripening of the crop, which take place once the seed has been deeply rooted. But because of the seed's lack of root, the sun's heat, which should cause growth and ripening, becomes a deathblow to the seed.

verse.text: And others fell on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thorns, and the thorns came up and choked them.
verse.note: The thorns signify the anxiety of the age and the deceitfulness of riches, which utterly choke the word, preventing it from growing in the heart and causing it to become unfruitful ([link]v. 22[/link]).

verse.text: But others fell on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]good earth and yielded fruit, one a [xref]b[/xref]hundredfold, and one sixtyfold, and one thirtyfold.
verse.note: The good earth signifies the good heart that is not hardened by worldly traffic, that is without hidden sins, and that is without the anxiety of the age and the deceitfulness of riches. Such a heart gives every inch of its ground to receive the word that the word may grow, bear fruit, and produce even a hundredfold ([link]v. 23[/link]).

verse.text: He who has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ears to hear, let him hear.
verse.note: This word indicates that the opposing and rejecting Jews did not have ears to hear. Hence, they could not hear.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the disciples came and said to Him, Why do You speak in parables to them?
And He answered and said to them, Because to you it has been given to know the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mysteries of the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of the heavens, but to them it has not been given.
verse.note: The King of the heavenly kingdom used parables to reveal the things of the kingdom ([link]v. 34[/link]) in order to make them mysteries to the opposing and rejecting Jews so that they would not understand them. From the time the King came to sow the seed until He comes back to reap the harvest, everything concerning the kingdom is a mystery to the natural mind. Only the enlightened mind of a submissive heart can understand these mysteries.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]whoever has, it shall be given to him, and he will abound; but [note]2[/note]whoever does not have, even that which he has shall be taken away from him.
verse.note: This is the receiver and follower of the heavenly King; to such a one the revelation concerning the kingdom will be given in abundance.

This is the opposing and rejecting Jew, from whom what the heavenly King has spoken and done will be taken away. This is the real condition of the Jews today. They have no knowledge whatever concerning the kingdom of the heavens. It is altogether a mystery unknown to them.

verse.text: For this reason I speak to them in parables, because seeing they do [xref]a[/xref]not see, and hearing they do not hear, nor do they understand.
And in them the prophecy of Isaiah is being fulfilled, which says, [xref]a[/xref]"In hearing you shall hear and by no means understand, and seeing you shall see and by no means perceive.

For the heart of this people has become fat, and with their ears they have heard heavily, and their [xref]a[/xref]eyes they have closed, lest they perceive with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart, and they turn around, and I will heal them."
But [xref]a[/xref]blessed are your eyes because they see, and your ears because they hear.

For truly I say to you that many prophets and righteous men have desired to [xref]a[/xref]perceive the things that you [note]1[/note]see, and have not perceived [i]them,[/i] and to hear the things that you [note]1[/note]hear, and have not heard [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: What a blessing it is to see and hear the mysteries of the heavenly kingdom!

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]You therefore hear the parable of the one who sowed.

When anyone hears the word of the kingdom and does not understand, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]evil one comes and snatches away that which has been sown in his heart. This is the one sown beside the way.
verse.note: The evil one is the devil ([link]vv. 38-39[/link]).

verse.text: And the one sown on the rocky places, this is he who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy;
Yet he does not have root in himself but lasts only for a time, and when affliction or persecution occurs because of the word, immediately he is [xref]a[/xref]stumbled.

And the one sown in the thorns, this is he who hears the word, and the [xref]a[/xref]anxiety of the [xref]b[/xref]age and the deceitfulness of [xref]c[/xref]riches utterly choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
But the one sown on the good earth, this is he who hears the word and understands, who by all means bears [xref]a[/xref]fruit and produces, one a hundredfold, and one sixtyfold, and one thirtyfold.
Another parable He set before them, saying, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of the heavens has become like a [xref]b[/xref]man sowing good [xref]c[/xref]seed in his [xref]c[/xref]field.
verse.note: In this, the second, parable the Lord began to say, "The kingdom of the heavens is (or, has become) like...," because the kingdom of the heavens began to be established when this parable began to be fulfilled, i.e., on the day of Pentecost, when the church was built ([link]16:18-19[/link]). It was from that time, after the church had been founded, that the tares, the false believers, were sown among the true believers, the wheat, forming the appearance of the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: But while the [note]1[/note]men slept, his [xref]a[/xref]enemy came and sowed [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]tares in the midst of the [note]3[/note]wheat and went away.
verse.note: The men were the slaves ([link]v. 27[/link]), referring to the Lord's slaves, mainly the apostles. It was when the Lord's slaves were sleeping and were not watching that the Lord's enemy, the devil, came and sowed false believers among the true.

A tare is a kind of darnel, a weed resembling wheat. Its seeds are poisonous and can cause sleepiness, nausea, convulsions, and even death. The sprout and leaves of tares look the same as those of wheat. It is impossible to distinguish wheat from tares until the fruit is produced. The fruit of the wheat is golden yellow, but that of the tares is black.

In the Old Testament the children of Israel, who were in the kingdom of God, were likened to grapes growing in the vineyard ([link]21:33-34[/link]), whereas in the New Testament the kingdom people, who are in the kingdom of the heavens, are likened to wheat growing in the field. The vineyard was fenced, limited, and included only the Jews, whereas the field is worldwide, open, unlimited, and includes all peoples.

verse.text: And when the blade sprouted and produced fruit, then the tares appeared also.
And the slaves of the master of the house came and said to him, Sir, did you not sow good seed in your field? Where then did the tares come from?
And he said to them, An enemy has done this. And the slaves said to him, Do you want us then to go and [note]1[/note]collect them?
verse.note: Root out in order to collect. So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: But he said, No, lest while [note]1[/note]collecting the tares, you uproot the wheat along with them.
verse.note: Both the tares and the wheat grow in the field, and the field is the world ([link]v. 38[/link]). The false believers and the true live in the world. To collect the tares from the field means to take away the false believers from the world. The Lord did not want His slaves to do this, because while taking away the false believers from the world, they might also take the true ones away. The Catholic Church did this very much and by so doing killed many true believers.

verse.text: Let both [note]1[/note]grow together until the [xref]a[/xref]harvest, and at the time of the harvest I will say to the reapers, [xref]b[/xref]Collect first the tares and bind them into bundles to [xref]c[/xref]burn them up, but the [xref]d[/xref]wheat gather into my barn.
verse.note: To grow together in the world, not in the church.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Another parable He set before them, saying, The kingdom of the heavens is like a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his field,
verse.note: The fruit of the wheat in the first two parables and the fruit of the mustard seed here in the third parable are for food. This indicates that the kingdom people, the constituents of the kingdom and of the church, should be like a crop that produces food for the satisfaction of God and man.

verse.text: [i]And[/i] which is smaller than all the seeds; but when it has grown, it is greater than the herbs and becomes a [note]1[/note]tree, so that the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]birds of heaven come and roost in its branches.
verse.note: The church, which is the embodiment of the kingdom, should be like an herb that produces food. However, its nature and function were changed, so that it became a "tree," a lodging place for birds. (This is against the law of God's creation, that is, that every plant must be after its kind — [link]Gen. 1:11-12[/link].) This change happened in the first part of the fourth century, when Constantine the Great mixed the church with the world. He brought thousands of false believers into Christianity, making it Christendom, no longer the church. Hence, this third parable corresponds with the third of the seven churches in [link]Rev. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link], the church in Pergamos ([link]Rev. 2:12-17[/link] — see note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link] there). The mustard is an annual herb, whereas the tree is a perennial plant. The church, according to its heavenly and spiritual nature, should be like the mustard, sojourning on the earth. But with its nature changed, the church became deeply rooted and settled as a tree in the earth, flourishing with its enterprises as the branches in which many evil persons and things are lodged. This resulted in the formation of the outward organization of the outward appearance of the kingdom of the heavens.

Since the birds in the first parable signify the evil one, Satan ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]19[/link]), the birds of heaven here must refer to Satan's evil spirits with the evil persons and things motivated by them. They lodge in the branches of the great tree, that is, in the enterprises of Christendom.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Another parable He spoke to them: The kingdom of the heavens is like [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]leaven, which a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]woman took and hid in [xref]d[/xref]three measures of [note]3[/note]meal until the whole was leavened.
verse.note: In the Scriptures leaven signifies evil things ([link]1 Cor. 5:6[/link], [link]8[/link]) and evil doctrines ([link]16:6[/link], [link]11-12[/link]).

The church as the practical kingdom of the heavens, with Christ, the unleavened fine flour, as its content, must be a loaf of unleavened bread ([link]1 Cor. 5:7-8[/link]). However, the Catholic Church, which was fully and officially formed in the sixth century and which is signified by the woman here, took in many pagan practices, heretical doctrines, and evil matters and mixed them with the teachings concerning Christ, leavening the whole content of Christianity. This mixture became the corrupted content of the outward appearance of the kingdom of the heavens. This fourth parable corresponds with the fourth of the seven churches in [link]Rev. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link], the church in Thyatira ([link]Rev. 2:18-29[/link] — see note [link]20[sup]1[/sup][/link] there).

Meal, for making the meal offering ([link]Lev. 2:1[/link]), signifies Christ as food to both God and man. Three measures is the quantity needed to make a full meal ([link]Gen. 18:6[/link]). Hence, the hiding of the leaven in three measures of meal signifies that the Catholic Church has fully leavened in a hidden way all the teachings concerning Christ. This is the actual situation in the Roman Catholic Church. Such leavening is absolutely against the Scriptures, which strongly forbid putting any leaven into the meal offering ([link]Lev. 2:4-5[/link], [link]11[/link]).

verse.text: All these things Jesus spoke in [xref]a[/xref]parables to the crowds, and apart from a parable He spoke nothing to them,

So that what was spoken through the prophet might be fulfilled, saying, [xref]a[/xref]"I will open My mouth in parables; I will utter things [xref]b[/xref]hidden [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]from the foundation of the world."
verse.note: The kingdom people were chosen by God [i]before[/i] the foundation of the world ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]), but the mysteries of the kingdom were hidden [i]from[/i] the foundation of the world.

verse.text: Then, leaving the crowds, He went into the [xref]a[/xref]house. And His disciples came to Him, saying, Make the [xref]b[/xref]parable of the tares of the field clear to us.
And He answered and said, He who sows the good seed is the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man;
And the field is the world; and the [note]1[/note]good seed, these are the [xref]a[/xref]sons of the kingdom; and the [note]1[/note]tares are the [xref]b[/xref]sons of the evil one;
verse.note: This parable discloses that not long after the kingdom was established through the building of the church, the situation of the kingdom of the heavens changed. The kingdom was established with the sons of the kingdom, the wheat. But the sons of the evil one, the tares, grew up to alter the situation. Hence, a difference has arisen between the kingdom of the heavens and its outward appearance. The sons of the kingdom, the wheat, constitute the kingdom, whereas the sons of the evil one, the tares, have formed the outward appearance of the kingdom, which today is called Christendom.

verse.text: And the enemy who sowed them is the [xref]a[/xref]devil; and the harvest is the [xref]b[/xref]consummation of the age; and the reapers are angels.
Therefore just as the tares are collected and burned up with fire, so will it be at the consummation of the age.

The [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man will send His angels, and they will collect out of [note]1[/note]His [xref]b[/xref]kingdom all the [xref]c[/xref]stumbling blocks and those who practice [xref]d[/xref]lawlessness,
verse.note: The kingdom of the Son of Man, which is the earthly part of the millennium, the Messianic kingdom.

verse.text: And will cast them into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]furnace of fire. In that place there will be the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: The lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link], [link]15[/link]).
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: Then the [note]1[/note]righteous will [xref]a[/xref]shine forth like the sun in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of their Father. He who has [xref]c[/xref]ears to hear, let him hear.
verse.note: The sons of the kingdom ([link]v. 38[/link]), who are the overcomers.
The kingdom of the Father is the heavenly part of the millennium, the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens as a reward to the overcomers.

verse.text: The kingdom of the heavens is like a [note]1[/note]treasure hidden in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]field, which a [note]3[/note]man found and [xref]b[/xref]hid, and in his joy goes and sells all that he has, and [xref]c[/xref]buys that field.
verse.note: The previous three parables, concerning the outward appearance of the kingdom, were spoken publicly by the heavenly King in a boat to the crowds ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]34[/link]), whereas the three succeeding parables were given privately in a house to the disciples ([link]v. 36[/link]). This indicates that the things covered by these latter three parables are more hidden. The first parable concerns a treasure hidden in the field. The treasure hidden in the field must consist of gold or precious stones, the materials for the building of the church and the New Jerusalem ([link]1 Cor. 3:12[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:18-20[/link]). Since the church is the practical kingdom today, and since the New Jerusalem will be the kingdom in manifestation in the coming age, the treasure hidden in the field must signify the kingdom hidden on God's created earth.
The field is the earth created by God for His kingdom ([link]Gen. 1:26-28[/link]).

The man here is Christ, who found the kingdom of the heavens in [link]4:12-12:23[/link], hid it in [link]12:24-13:43[/link], and in His joy went to the cross in [link]16:21[/link]; [link]17:22-23[/link]; [link]20:18-19[/link]; and [link]26:1-27:52[/link] to sell all that He had and to buy the field, i.e., redeem the created and lost earth, for the kingdom.

verse.text: Again, the kingdom of the heavens is like a [note]1[/note]merchant seeking fine pearls;
verse.note: The merchant also is Christ, who was seeking the church for His kingdom. After finding it in [link]16:18[/link] and [link]18:17[/link], He went to the cross and sold all that He had and bought it for the kingdom.

verse.text: And finding one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pearl of great value, he went and sold all that he had and [xref]b[/xref]bought it.
verse.note: The pearl, produced in the death waters (the world filled with death) by the living oyster (the living Christ), wounded by a little rock (the sinner), and secreting its life-juice around the wounding rock (the believer — see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]), is material for the building of the New Jerusalem. Since the pearl comes out of the sea, which signifies the world corrupted by Satan ([link]Isa. 57:20[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:15[/link]), it must refer to the church, which is constituted mainly of regenerated believers from the Gentile world and which is of great value.

verse.text: Again, the kingdom of the heavens is like a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]net cast into the [note]2[/note]sea and gathering from [note]3[/note]every species,
verse.note: Lit., dragnet. This parable corresponds with that in [link]25:32-46[/link]. The net here signifies not the gospel of grace, which is preached in the church age, but the eternal gospel, which will be preached to the Gentile world during the great tribulation ([link]Rev. 14:6-7[/link] — see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link] there).
The sea signifies the Gentile world.
[i]Every species[/i] signifies all the nations, all the Gentiles ([link]25:32[/link]).

verse.text: Which, when it was filled, they brought onto the shore, and sat down and collected the [note]1[/note]good into vessels; but the [note]1[/note]foul they cast out.
verse.note: The good are the "sheep," who are justified; the foul are the "goats," who are condemned ([link]25:32[/link]).

verse.text: So it will be at the [xref]a[/xref]consummation of the age: the angels will go forth and separate the evil from the midst of the righteous,
And will cast them into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]furnace of fire. In that place there will be the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: The lake of fire ([link]25:41[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:10[/link], [link]15[/link]).
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: Have you understood all these things? They said to Him, Yes.

And He said to them, For this reason every [xref]a[/xref]scribe [xref]b[/xref]discipled to the kingdom of the heavens is like a householder who brings forth out of his [note]1[/note]treasure things [xref]c[/xref]new and old.
verse.note: After giving the seven parables concerning the mysteries of the kingdom, the Lord likened the discipled scribe to a householder who has a treasure, a rich store of things new and old, signifying not only the new and old knowledge of the Scriptures but also the new and old experiences of life in the kingdom.

verse.text: And when Jesus had finished these parables, He departed from there.

[xref]a[/xref]And He came into His own country and taught them in their [xref]b[/xref]synagogue, so that they were [xref]c[/xref]astounded and said, Where [i]did[/i] this man [i]get[/i] this [xref]d[/xref]wisdom and these works of power?
Is not this the [note]1[/note]carpenter's [xref]a[/xref]son? Is not His [xref]b[/xref]mother called Mary, and His [xref]c[/xref]brothers James and Joseph and Simon and Judas?
verse.note: In [link]12:24[/link] the Pharisees opposed and rejected Christ to the uttermost. Here the Galileans knew Him according to the flesh, not according to the spirit ([link]2 Cor. 5:16[/link]). They were blinded by their natural knowledge.

verse.text: And His sisters, are they not all with us? Where then [i]did[/i] this man [i]get[/i] all these things?
And they were [xref]a[/xref]stumbled because of Him. But Jesus said to them, A [xref]b[/xref]prophet is not without honor except in his [i]own[/i] country and in his [i]own[/i] house.
And He did [note]1[/note]not do many works of power there because of their unbelief.
verse.note: The rejection by the Pharisees caused the heavenly King to forsake them. The unbelief of the Galileans caused the Lord not to do many works of power among them.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]At that time [xref]b[/xref]Herod the tetrarch heard the report concerning Jesus,
And he said to his servants, This is [xref]a[/xref]John the Baptist; he has been raised from the dead, and because of this these [xref]b[/xref]works of power [note]1[/note]are operating through him.
verse.note: I.e., are operating and are being manifested.

verse.text: For Herod had seized John and bound him and put [i]him[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]prison on account of [xref]b[/xref]Herodias, the wife of Philip his brother.
For John had been saying to him, It is [xref]a[/xref]not lawful for you to have her.
And though he desired to kill him, he feared the crowd because they [xref]a[/xref]held him as a [xref]b[/xref]prophet.
But when Herod's [xref]a[/xref]birthday came, the daughter of Herodias danced in their midst and pleased Herod;
Hence, he promised with an oath to give her whatever she asked.
And she, being instigated by her mother, said, Give me here on a platter the head of John the Baptist.
And the king was grieved, yet because of the oaths and those reclining [i]at table[/i] with [i]him,[/i] he commanded [i]it[/i] to be given.
And he sent [i]men[/i] and [note]1[/note]beheaded John in the prison.
verse.note: In [link]12:24[/link] the Jewish religious leaders, representing the entire nation of the Jews, rejected the heavenly King to the uttermost. This forced Him to forsake His natural relationship with them ([link]12:46-50[/link]). Then in [link]13:53-58[/link] He was rejected by the Galileans also. Now in [link]ch. 14[/link], Matthew, in his arranging of events according to doctrine, unveils to us how Gentile politics treated the King's forerunner. It was evil and full of corruption and darkness. To this point Matthew has given a full picture of the Jews', the Galileans', and the Gentiles' rejection of the ministry of the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: And his head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she brought [i]it[/i] to her mother.
And his [xref]a[/xref]disciples came and took the corpse and buried it; and they came and reported [i]the matter[/i] to Jesus.

[xref]a[/xref]And when Jesus heard [i]this,[/i] He [note]1[/note]withdrew from there in a boat to a deserted place privately. And when the crowds heard [i]of it,[/i] they [note]2[/note]followed Him on foot from the cities.
verse.note: Because He had been rejected by the people in religious, cultured, and political circles, the heavenly King departed from them and withdrew to a deserted place privately. This indicates that thenceforth He would hide Himself in a deserted place, in a place without culture, away from the religious, cultured, and political circles. He did this by means of a boat, implying that He would do this through the church. Because He has been rejected by the civilized world, the Lord, through the church, has always hidden Himself in a realm without much culture, away from religious and political circles.

In spite of the rejection by all kinds of people, there were still a large number of people who followed the heavenly King. They did this by leaving their cities. It was not that the King came to their cities to visit them, but that they left their cultured cities to follow Him in a deserted place. Through all the centuries the true followers of Christ have left cultured spheres to follow their heavenly King outside the cultured world.

verse.text: And going forth, He saw a great crowd, and He was moved with [xref]a[/xref]compassion for them and healed their sick.

Now when evening fell, the disciples came to Him, saying, This place is deserted and the hour is already [note]1[/note]late. Send the crowds away that they may go into the villages and buy food for themselves.
verse.note: Lit., passed.

verse.text: But Jesus said to them, They do not need to go away. You [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]give them [i]something[/i] to [note]2[/note]eat.
verse.note: The disciples asked the Lord to send the crowds away so that the crowds could go to buy food for themselves ([link]v. 15[/link]), but the Lord told the disciples to give the crowds something to eat. The disciples' concept was to ask people to do something; this is the principle of the law. But the Lord's concept is to give people something to enjoy; this is the principle of grace.

In this record of the miracle, the Holy Spirit's intention in His inspiration is to show that what the followers of the heavenly King actually need is the proper food to satisfy their hunger. The disciples of Christ did not know this, nor did the crowds who followed. The heavenly King knew this and did something in a miraculous way to impress them with their real need and His provision for that need. All that they needed was His resurrection life, which would satisfy their spiritual hunger, as signified in this miracle.[br][br]What the heavenly King did indicates strongly and clearly that He provides for the necessities of His followers while they follow Him in this rejecting world. This corresponds with His word in the heavenly constitution saying that the kingdom people need not be anxious about what they will eat ([link]6:31-33[/link]).

verse.text: And they said to Him, We do not have [i]anything[/i] here except five [note]1[/note]loaves and two [note]1[/note]fish.
verse.note: [link]John 6:9[/link] tells us that these five loaves were barley loaves. Barley is a type of the resurrected Christ ([link]Lev. 23:10[/link]). Thus, the barley loaves signify Christ in resurrection as food to us. Loaves are of the vegetable life, signifying the generating aspect of Christ's life, whereas fish are of the animal life, signifying the redeeming aspect of Christ's life. For our spiritual hunger to be satisfied, we need Christ's generating life as well as His redeeming life. Both aspects are symbolized by small items — loaves and fish. This indicates that in this age the heavenly King came to His followers not as a great King to reign over them but as small pieces of food to feed them. See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: And He said, [note]1[/note]Bring them here to Me.
verse.note: Whatever we have of the Lord should be brought to the Lord that it may become a great blessing to many others. Often the Lord uses what we offer to Him to provide for the need of many others. It is in this way that He provides for His followers' need today also.

verse.text: And after commanding the crowds to [note]1[/note]recline on the grass, He took the [xref]a[/xref]five loaves and the two fish, and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]looking up to heaven, He [xref]c[/xref]blessed and [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]broke the loaves and [note]4[/note]gave [i]them[/i] to the disciples, and the disciples to the crowds.
verse.note: This was to put the people into good order and showed the Lord's wisdom and orderliness.
By looking up to heaven the heavenly King indicated that His source was His Father who is in the heavens.
Whatever we bring to the Lord must be broken that it may become a blessing to others.

The loaves were from the disciples, who brought them to the Lord. After being blessed and broken by the Lord, the loaves were given back to the disciples for distribution to the crowds, to whom the loaves became a great satisfaction. This indicates that the disciples were not the source of blessing; they were only the channels used by the Lord, who is the source of the people's satisfaction.

verse.text: And they all ate and were satisfied. And they took up what was left over of the [xref]a[/xref]broken pieces, [note]1[/note]twelve handbaskets full.
verse.note: That there were twelve handbaskets full of broken pieces indicates not only that the resurrected Christ is unlimited and inexhaustible but also that the Lord's provision for us is abundant, more than sufficient to meet all our need.

verse.text: And those who ate were about five thousand men, apart from women and children.
[xref]a[/xref]And immediately He [note]1[/note]compelled the disciples to step into the boat and to go before Him to the other side, while He sent the crowds away.
verse.note: The Lord compelled the disciples to leave Him in order that He might have more time to pray privately to the Father ([link]v. 23[/link]).

verse.text: And after He sent the crowds away, He went up to the mountain privately to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pray. And when [note]2[/note]night fell, He was there alone.
verse.note: Standing in the position of man ([link]4:4[/link]), the heavenly King, as the beloved Son of the Father ([link]3:17[/link]), needed to pray privately to His Father who was in the heavens, that He might be one with the Father and have the Father with Him in whatever He did on earth for the establishing of the kingdom of the heavens. He did this not in the deserted place but on the mountain, leaving all the people, even His disciples, that He might be alone to contact the Father.
Lit., evening. The time here is later than in [link]v. 15[/link]. Thus, the word is rendered [i]night[/i] here.

verse.text: Now the boat was already [note]1[/note]in the midst of the sea, being battered by the waves, for the wind was contrary.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS read, was already many stadia away from the land. (A stadion is approximately six hundred feet.)

verse.text: And in the [note]1[/note]fourth [xref]a[/xref]watch of the night He came to them, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]walking on the sea.
verse.note: The Roman guards kept four night watches, each of three hours, from sunset to sunrise. The first watch was the evening watch, the second the midnight watch, the third the cockcrowing watch, and the fourth the morning watch ([link]Mark 13:35[/link]). The fourth watch was probably from three to six o'clock in the morning.
While His disciples were distressed by the waves, the Lord walked on the sea. This testifies that He is the Creator and the Ruler of the universe ([link]Job 9:8[/link]).

verse.text: And the disciples, seeing Him walking on the sea, were [xref]a[/xref]startled, saying, It is a ghost! And they cried out for fear.
But immediately Jesus talked to them, saying, Take [xref]a[/xref]courage. [note]1[/note]It is I. Do [xref]b[/xref]not be afraid.
verse.note: Or, I am.

verse.text: And Peter answered Him and said, Lord, if it is You, command me to come to You on the water.
And He said, Come. And Peter, coming down from the boat, walked on the water and came toward Jesus.
But [note]1[/note]seeing the strong wind, he became frightened; and as he began to sink, he cried out, saying, Lord, [xref]a[/xref]save me!
verse.note: Peter came down from the boat and walked on the water by faith in the Lord's word ([link]v. 29[/link]); however, when he saw the strong wind, his faith vanished. He should have walked by faith in the Lord's word, not by looking at the circumstances (i.e., by sight). In following the Lord we should walk by faith, not by sight ([link]2 Cor. 5:7[/link]).

verse.text: And immediately Jesus stretched out His hand and took hold of him and said to him, You of [xref]a[/xref]little faith, why did you [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]doubt?
verse.note: Since the Lord said to Peter, "Come" ([link]v. 29[/link]), Peter should have stood on that word and should not have doubted. Hence, the Lord rebuked him. Faith comes from the Lord's word and stands on the Lord's word. As long as we have the Lord's word, we should simply believe in His word and not doubt.

verse.text: And when they got up into the boat, the [note]1[/note]wind ceased.
verse.note: This miracle testifies not only that the Lord is the Ruler of the heavens and the earth but also that He takes care of the hardships endured by His followers as they follow Him on the way. When we have the Lord in our boat, the wind ceases. The record of the two miracles in this chapter implies that during the time that Christ was being rejected by people in the religious and political circles, He and His followers were in a deserted place and on a stormy sea. Whatever the situation, He was able to provide for their need and carry them through the hardships.

verse.text: And those who were in the boat [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Him, saying, Truly You are the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of God.
verse.note: To recognize that the Lord is the Son of God is to realize that He is equal to God ([link]John 5:18[/link]). This indicates that the disciples acknowledged the Lord's divinity ([link]1:23[/link]; [link]3:17[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And they crossed over and came to land at [xref]b[/xref]Gennesaret.
And when the men of that place recognized Him, they sent [i]word[/i] into all that surrounding region and brought to Him all who were ill.
And they begged Him that they might only touch the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fringe of His garment. And as many as [xref]b[/xref]touched were completely [note]2[/note]healed.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].
Lit., saved.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then some Pharisees and scribes [note]1[/note]came to Jesus from [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem, saying,
verse.note: Although the Lord forsook the rejecting religionists, they still would not cease troubling Him. They came to Him from their religious center, Jerusalem, in order to find fault with Him. However, their troubling afforded Him another opportunity to reveal the truth concerning genuine cleanness ([link]vv. 10-11[/link], [link]15-20[/link]).

verse.text: Why do Your disciples [note]1[/note]transgress the [xref]a[/xref]tradition of the elders? For they do [xref]b[/xref]not wash their hands when they eat bread.
verse.note: This reveals that in following the Lord the disciples did not keep traditions. They cared only for the heavenly King's presence, not for anything else.

verse.text: And He answered and said to them, Why do you also [note]1[/note]transgress the commandment of God because of your tradition?
verse.note: The Jewish religionists accused the Lord's disciples of transgressing their tradition, but the Lord condemned the religionists for transgressing the commandment of God because of their tradition. They cared for their tradition, but they ignored God's commandment. In principle, the religious people today do the same thing. The Roman Catholic Church and most Protestant denominations make void the word of God because of their traditions.

verse.text: For God said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"Honor your father and your mother," and, "He who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]speaks evil of father or mother, let him [note]3[/note]be put to death."
verse.note: The Lord's dealing here with the Pharisees and scribes not only condemned them for making void the word of God because of their tradition but also implied that man should honor his parents. God in His government among men has ordained that man should honor his parents. He has made this the first commandment among the Ten Commandments that concerns human relationships ([link]Exo. 20:12[/link]). Fallen human nature, however, always prompts man to ignore his parents, that is, to rebel against God's government. In order to bring man back to God's government, the Lord as the heavenly King emphasized that man should honor his parents. This corresponds with His word in the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens concerning the fulfillment of the law ([link]5:17-19[/link]). Hence, the apostle also emphasized this matter strongly ([link]Eph. 6:1-3[/link]; [link]Col. 3:20[/link]). We, the kingdom people, must honor our parents and not excuse ourselves as the Jewish religionists did. To make any excuse indicates that we are not under the heavenly ruling but are following our fallen nature and the rebellious trend of today's generation.
Or, slanders, insults.

Lit., decease by death; meaning [i]to die by being put to death.[/i] The Greek word for [i]decease[/i] means [i]come to one's end.[/i] Hence, this phrase means [i]come to one's end by being put to death.[/i] It is quoted from two verses in the Septuagint — [link]Exo. 21:17[/link] and [link]Lev. 20:9[/link]. In those two verses it was translated from the Hebrew idiom.

verse.text: But you say, Whoever says to his father or his mother, Whatever you would have been profited by me is [i]now[/i] a [note]1[/note]gift [i]to God,[/i]
verse.note: An offering to God.

verse.text: Shall by no means honor his father or his mother; and you have deprived the word of God of its authority because of your tradition.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hypocrites! Well has Isaiah prophesied concerning you, saying,
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]"This people honors Me with their lips, but their [note]1[/note]heart stays far away from Me;
verse.note: The heavenly ruling of the kingdom requires inward reality, not mere outward practice. Such ruling deals with the real condition of the heart, not with the expression of the lips.

verse.text: But in [note]1[/note]vain do they worship Me, teaching as teachings the [xref]a[/xref]commandments of men."
verse.note: This reveals that some worship offered to God may be in vain. The main cause of this is to consider as teachings the commandments of men. We must worship God according to His word, which is the truth.

verse.text: And He called the crowd to [i]Him[/i] and said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Hear and understand:
It is not that which enters into the mouth [i]that[/i] [xref]a[/xref]defiles the man; but that which proceeds out of the mouth, this [note]1[/note]defiles the man.
verse.note: I.e., makes the man common, unclean ([link]Acts 11:8[/link]). So in [link]vv. 18[/link] and [link]20[/link]. In the kingdom life, defilement is not an outward matter but an inward matter.

verse.text: Then the disciples came and said to Him, Do You know that the Pharisees were stumbled when they heard this word?
And He answered and said, Every plant which My heavenly Father has [note]1[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]planted shall be [xref]b[/xref]rooted up.
verse.note: This word from the heavenly King indicates that the hypocritical Pharisees had not been planted by the heavenly Father. Because of their rejection of the heavenly King, they were uprooted from the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: Let them be. They are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blind guides of the blind; and if a blind man guides a blind man, both will fall into a pit.
verse.note: The self-righteous and arrogant religionists thought that they were clear concerning the way to serve God, not realizing that they were blind guides of the blind. Their eyes were veiled by their religion with their traditions; hence, they could not see the reality of God's economy and thus were not able to enter into the kingdom of the heavens. Their blindness led them to "fall into a pit."

verse.text: And Peter answered and said to Him, Explain this parable to us.
And He said, Are you also still [xref]a[/xref]without understanding?
Do you not understand that everything that goes into the mouth passes into the [xref]a[/xref]stomach and is expelled into the drain?
But the things which proceed out of the mouth come out of the heart, and those [xref]a[/xref]defile the man.
For out of the [xref]a[/xref]heart come [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]evil reasonings, murders, [xref]c[/xref]adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witnessings, blasphemies.
verse.note: In the kingdom of the heavens, defilement is not related to material things but to moral matters. Material things have nothing to do with the heavenly ruling, but moral matters do. That so many evils issue from our heart proves that we are not under the heavenly ruling.

verse.text: These are the things which defile the man, but eating with unwashed hands does not defile the man.
[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus went from there and withdrew into the parts of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Tyre and Sidon.
verse.note: The further troubling by the rejecting religionists caused the heavenly King to depart farther from them, even into the districts of Tyre and Sidon, into a Gentile land.

verse.text: And behold, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Canaanite woman came out from those borders and cried out, saying, Have mercy on me, [note]2[/note]Lord, [xref]b[/xref]Son of David! My daughter suffers terribly from demon possession.
verse.note: Because of the rejection by the religious Jews, the opportunity to contact the heavenly King came to the Gentiles, even to a weak Gentile woman.

The title [i]Lord[/i] implies Christ's divinity, and the title [i]Son of David,[/i] His humanity. It was proper for this woman, a Gentile, to address Christ as "Lord." However, she had no right to call Him "Son of David"; only the children of Israel were privileged to do so.

verse.text: But He did not answer her a word. And His disciples came and implored Him, saying, Send her away, for she is crying out after us.
But He answered and said, I was not [note]1[/note]sent except to the lost sheep of the [xref]a[/xref]house of Israel.
verse.note: The Lord was sent to the lost sheep of the house of Israel. However, at this time He came to a Gentile region, thus affording the Gentiles an opportunity to participate in His grace. This bears dispensational significance, showing that Christ came to the Jews first and that because of their unbelief, His salvation turned to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:46[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:11[/link]).

verse.text: But she came and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]worshipped Him, saying, [note]2[/note]Lord, help me!
verse.note: As she would worship God.
This second time she addressed Christ only as "Lord," not as "Son of David," because she realized that she was not a child of Israel but a heathen.

verse.text: But He answered and said, It is not good to take the children's [note]1[/note]bread and throw [i]it[/i] to the [note]2[/note]little [xref]a[/xref]dogs.
verse.note: The heavenly King's ministry in all His visits created opportunities for Him to reveal Himself further. In the situations created in [link]chs. 9[/link] and [link book="Matt."]12[/link], He had opportunities to reveal Himself as the Physician, the Bridegroom, the new cloth, the new wine, the Shepherd, the real David, the greater temple, the Lord of the harvest, the One who is more than Jonah, and the One who is more than Solomon. Here another opportunity was created for Him to reveal Himself, this time as the children's bread. The Canaanite woman considered Him the Lord — a divine person — and the Son of David — a royal descendant, great and high in His reign. But He unveiled Himself to her as small pieces of bread, good for food. This implies that as the heavenly King, He rules over His people by feeding them with Himself as bread. We can be the proper people in His kingdom only by being nourished with Him as our food. To eat Christ as our supply is the way to be the kingdom people in the reality of the kingdom.
This indicates that in the eyes of the Lord all the heathen are dogs, which are unclean in the eyes of God ([link]Lev. 11:27[/link]).

verse.text: And she said, Yes, Lord, for even the little dogs eat of the [note]1[/note]crumbs which fall from their masters' [xref]a[/xref]table.
verse.note: The Canaanite woman, not offended by the Lord's word but admitting that she was a heathen dog, considered that at that time Christ, after being rejected by the children, the Jews, became crumbs under the table as a portion to the Gentiles. The holy land of Israel was the table on which Christ, the heavenly bread, had come as a portion to the children of Israel. But they threw Him off the table to the ground, the Gentile land, so that He became broken crumbs as a portion to the Gentiles. What a realization this Gentile woman had at that time! No wonder the heavenly King admired her faith ([link]v. 28[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus answered and said to her, O woman, great is your [xref]a[/xref]faith! Be it [xref]b[/xref]done to you as you wish. And her daughter was healed from that [xref]c[/xref]hour.
[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus departed from there and came beside the [xref]b[/xref]Sea of [note]1[/note]Galilee; and He went up to the [xref]c[/xref]mountain and sat there.
verse.note: Because He had been rejected by the Jewish religion, the Lord remained in Galilee of the Gentiles as the healing light. He would not go to Jerusalem, the Jews' religious center, to heal the Jews ([link]13:15[/link]).

verse.text: And great crowds came to Him, having with them the lame, the blind, the crippled, the dumb, and many other [i]sick ones;[/i] and they [note]1[/note]laid them at His feet, and He healed them,
verse.note: Lit., cast.

verse.text: So that the crowd marveled, because they saw the [xref]a[/xref]dumb speaking, the crippled healthy and the lame walking, and the [xref]b[/xref]blind seeing. And they [xref]c[/xref]glorified the [xref]d[/xref]God of Israel.

[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus called His disciples to [i]Him[/i] and said, I am moved with [xref]b[/xref]compassion for the crowd, because for three days now they have remained with Me and they do not have anything to eat. And I am [note]1[/note]not willing to send them away hungry, lest they faint on the way.
verse.note: Christ would not allow His followers to hunger and faint on the way while they followed Him.

verse.text: And the disciples said to Him, Where [i]can[/i] we [i]get[/i] so many loaves in [i]this[/i] [note]1[/note]desolate place to [xref]a[/xref]satisfy so great a crowd?
verse.note: Even in the barren wilderness the Lord was able to feed His followers and satisfy them, regardless of how many there were. The disciples had experienced this before, in [link]14:15-21[/link]; however, it seems that they had not learned the lesson of faith. Here they set their eyes on the environment instead of on the Lord. Yet the Lord's presence was better than a rich store.

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, [note]1[/note]How many loaves do you have? And they said, Seven, and a few small fish.
verse.note: The Lord always wants to use what we have to bless others.

verse.text: And after He commanded the crowd to recline on the ground,
He [note]1[/note]took the [xref]a[/xref]seven loaves and the fish, and giving [xref]b[/xref]thanks, He broke [i]them[/i] and gave [i]them[/i] to the disciples, and the disciples to the crowds.
verse.note: If we offer all that we have to the Lord, He will take it, break it, and give it back to us for distribution to others, to whom it will become a satisfying and overflowing blessing ([link]v. 37[/link]). Whatever we offer to the Lord, however little it is, will be multiplied by His blessing hand to meet the need of a great multitude ([link]v. 38[/link]); thereby His desire is fulfilled ([link]v. 32[/link]).

verse.text: And they all ate and were satisfied. And they took up what was left over of the [xref]a[/xref]broken pieces, seven baskets full.
And those who ate were four thousand men, apart from women and children.
And after He sent the crowds away, He stepped into the boat and came to the borders of Magadan.
[xref]a[/xref]And the Pharisees and Sadducees came, and [xref]b[/xref]testing [i]Him[/i] asked Him to show them a [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sign out of heaven.
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]. So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: But He answered and said to them, [note]1[/note]When evening falls, you say, [i]There will be[/i] fair weather, for the sky is red;
verse.note: The words from this point to the end of [link]v. 3[/link] are omitted by some ancient authorities.

verse.text: And in the morning, It will be stormy today, for the sky is red and gloomy. The [note]1[/note]face of the sky you know [i]how[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]discern, but you cannot [note]2[/note][i]discern[/i] the signs of the times.
verse.note: I.e., appearance.
See note [link]56[sup]5[/sup] in Luke 12[/link].

verse.text: An [xref]a[/xref]evil and adulterous generation seeks after a sign, and a sign shall not be given to it, except the [note]1[/note]sign of [xref]b[/xref]Jonah. And He [xref]c[/xref]left them and went away.
verse.note: Jonah was the prophet who turned from Israel to the Gentiles and was put into the belly of the great fish. After remaining there for three days, he emerged to become a sign to that generation for repentance ([link]Jonah 1:2[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]3:2-10[/link]). He was a type of Christ, who, as the Prophet sent by God to His people ([link]Deut. 18:15[/link], [link]18[/link]), would turn from Israel to the Gentiles, would be buried in the heart of the earth for three days, and would then be resurrected, becoming a sign to that generation for salvation. The Lord's word here implies that for that evil and adulterous Jewish and religious generation, the Lord would do nothing but die and be resurrected as a sign, the greatest sign, to them that they might be saved if they would believe.

verse.text: And when the disciples came to the other side, they had forgotten to take [note]1[/note]bread.
verse.note: From [link]15:1[/link] through [link]16:12[/link] Matthew's record is very much concerned with the matter of eating. Eating unclean things may defile us. Eating is the way to partake of Christ ([link]15:21-28[/link]), and by eating we feed on the unlimited and inexhaustibly rich supply of Christ ([link]15:32-39[/link]). But we must beware of eating any leaven ([link]vv. 5-12[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, Watch and beware of the [xref]a[/xref]leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
But they reasoned among themselves, saying, It is because we did not take bread.
And Jesus, knowing [i]it,[/i] said, Why are you reasoning among yourselves, you of [xref]a[/xref]little faith, because you have no bread?
Do you not yet understand nor remember the [xref]a[/xref]five loaves of the five thousand and how many [note]1[/note]handbaskets you took up?
verse.note: A basket used for a journey.

verse.text: Nor the [xref]a[/xref]seven loaves of the four thousand and how many [note]1[/note]baskets you took up?
verse.note: Larger than the handbaskets in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: How is it that you do not understand that [i]it was[/i] not about bread [i]that[/i] I spoke to you? But beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
Then they understood that He did not say to beware of the leaven of bread, but of the [note]1[/note]teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
verse.note: Referring to the things taught. The teaching of the Pharisees was hypocritical ([link]23:13[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]25[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]29[/link]), and the teaching of the Sadducees, which denied the resurrection, angels, and spirits ([link]Acts 23:8[/link]), was like today's modernism. Hence, both the teaching of the Pharisees and the teaching of the Sadducees were impure and evil and were likened to leaven, which was not to be seen among God's people ([link]Exo. 13:7[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now when Jesus came into the parts of [note]1[/note]Caesarea Philippi, He asked His disciples, saying, Who do men say that the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of Man is?
verse.note: In the northern part of the Holy Land, close to the border, at the foot of Mount Hermon, on which the Lord was transfigured ([link]17:1-2[/link]). It was far from the holy city and the holy temple, where the atmosphere of the old Jewish religion filled every man's thought, leaving no room for Christ, the new King. The Lord brought His disciples purposely to such a place with its clear atmosphere that their thought might be released from the effects of the religious surroundings in the holy city and holy temple and that He might reveal to them something new concerning Himself and the church, which are the pulse of His heavenly kingdom. It was in Caesarea Philippi that the vision concerning Him as the Christ, the Son of the living God, came to Peter ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]). It was there also that the church was revealed and mentioned for the first time as the means of bringing in the kingdom of the heavens ([link]vv. 18-19[/link]).
As a man, Christ was a mystery to that generation, as He is to people today.

verse.text: And they said, [note]1[/note]Some, [xref]a[/xref]John the Baptist; and others, [xref]b[/xref]Elijah; and still others, Jeremiah or one of the prophets.
verse.note: Without heavenly revelation people can realize, at most, only that Christ is the greatest among the prophets; no one can know that He is the Christ, the Son of the living God ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: He said to them, But you, who do you say that I am?
And Simon Peter answered and said, You are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Christ, the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]living God.
verse.note: [i]The Christ[/i] refers to the One concerning whom God prophesied in the Old Testament through the prophets and whom His saints through the ages looked for ([link]John 1:41[/link], [link]45[/link]; [link]Luke 2:25-26[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]), the One who would come to accomplish the will of God ([link]Heb. 10:5-7[/link]).[br][br][i]The Christ,[/i] referring to the anointed One of God, speaks of the Lord's commission, whereas [i]the Son of the living God,[/i] referring to the Second of the Triune God, speaks of His person. His commission is to accomplish God's eternal purpose through His crucifixion, resurrection, ascension, and second coming, whereas His person embodies the Father and consummates in the Spirit for a full expression of the Triune God.
The living God is in contrast to dead religion. The Lord is the embodiment of the living God, having nothing to do with dead religion.

verse.text: And Jesus answered and said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed are you, [xref]b[/xref]Simon [note]1[/note]Barjona, because [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]flesh and blood has not [xref]d[/xref]revealed [i]this[/i] to you, but My [note]3[/note]Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: I.e., son of Jonah.
[i]Flesh and blood[/i] refers to the natural man, who was created and became fallen.
Only the Father knows the Son ([link]11:27[/link]); hence, only He can reveal the Son to us.

verse.text: And I [note]1[/note]also say to you that you are [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Peter, and upon [note]3[/note]this [xref]b[/xref]rock I will [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]build My [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]church, and the [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]gates of [xref]f[/xref]Hades shall not prevail [xref]g[/xref]against it.
verse.note: The Father's revelation concerning Christ is only the first half of the great mystery, which is Christ and the church ([link]Eph. 5:32[/link]). Hence, the Lord needed to reveal to Peter the second half also, which concerns the church.
Or, a stone; material for God's building ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]).

[i]This rock[/i] refers not only to Christ but also to this revelation concerning Christ, a revelation that Peter received from the Father. The church is built on Christ and on this revelation concerning Christ.

The Lord's building of His church began on the day of Pentecost ([link]Acts 2:1-4[/link], [link]41-42[/link]). Yet the Lord's prophecy here still has not been fulfilled, even up to the twentieth century. The Lord is not building His church in Christendom, which is composed of the apostate Roman Catholic Church and the Protestant denominations. This prophecy is being fulfilled through the Lord's recovery, in which the building of the genuine church is being accomplished.

Gk. [i]ekklesia,[/i] meaning [i]an out-calling.[/i] This word is used in reference to a called-out congregation. [i]My church[/i] indicates that the church is of the Lord, not of any other person or thing; it is not like the denominations, which are denominated according to some person's name or according to some matter.

[i]Gates of Hades[/i] refers to Satan's authority or power of darkness ([link]Col. 1:13[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18[/link]), which cannot prevail against the genuine church built by Christ upon this revelation concerning Him as the rock, with stones such as Peter, a transformed human being. This word of the Lord's indicates also that Satan's power of darkness will attack the church. Hence, there is spiritual warfare between Satan's power, which is his kingdom, and the church, which is God's kingdom.

verse.text: I will give to you the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]keys of the [note]2[/note]kingdom of the heavens, and whatever you [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]bind on the earth shall [note]4[/note]have been bound in the heavens, and whatever you [note]3[/note]loose on the earth shall [note]4[/note]have been loosed in the heavens.
verse.note: According to history there were two keys. Peter used one on the day of Pentecost to open the gate so that the Jewish believers could enter the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Acts 2:38-42[/link]), and he used the other in the house of Cornelius to open the gate so that the Gentile believers could enter ([link]Acts 10:34-48[/link]).

[i]Kingdom of the heavens[/i] is used here interchangeably for [i]church,[/i] which is used in the previous verse. This is a strong proof that the genuine church is the kingdom of the heavens in this age. This is confirmed by [link]Rom. 14:17[/link], in which the kingdom of God is mentioned in obvious reference to the proper church life.

This Gospel is concerned with the kingdom of the heavens, which is a matter of authority. The church revealed in this book represents the kingdom with its reign. Hence, the authority to bind and to loose was given not only to Peter, the apostle for the church here, but also to the church itself ([link]18:17-18[/link]).

Whatever the church people bind or loose on earth must be something that has already been bound or loosed in the heavens. We can bind or loose only what has already been bound or loosed in the heavens.

verse.text: Then He charged the disciples [note]1[/note]not to tell [xref]a[/xref]anyone that He was the Christ.
verse.note: The revelation concerning Christ with His church is always hidden from religious people.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]From that time Jesus began to show to His disciples that He [note]1[/note]must go to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem and suffer many things from the elders and chief priests and scribes and be [xref]c[/xref]killed and on the third day be raised.
verse.note: After the revelation of the great mystery concerning Christ and the church, the crucifixion and resurrection of Christ were unveiled. In order for Christ to build His church, He had to go to the religious center, pass through crucifixion, and enter into resurrection.

verse.text: And Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him, saying, [i]God[/i] be merciful to You, Lord! This shall by [note]1[/note]no means happen to You!
verse.note: The natural man is never willing to take the cross.

verse.text: But He turned and said to Peter, Get behind Me, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Satan! [note]2[/note]You are a stumbling block to Me, for you are [note]3[/note]not setting your [xref]b[/xref]mind on the things of God, but on the things of men.
verse.note: Christ perceived that it was not Peter but Satan who was frustrating Him from taking the cross. This reveals that our natural man, which is not willing to take the cross, is one with Satan.
Or, You are a snare to Me.
When we are setting our mind not on the things of God but on the things of men, we become Satan, a stumbling block to the Lord on His way to fulfill God's purpose.

verse.text: Then Jesus said to His disciples, If anyone wants to come after Me, let him [note]1[/note]deny [note]2[/note]himself and take up his [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]cross and [note]4[/note]follow Me.
verse.note: To deny our self is to forfeit our soul-life, the natural life ([link]v. 26[/link]; [link]Luke 9:25[/link]).

Three terms in [link]vv. 23-25[/link] are related to one another: [i]mind, himself,[/i] and [i]soul-life.[/i] Our mind is the expression of our self, and our self is the embodiment of our soul-life. Our soul-life is embodied in and lived out by our self, and our self is expressed through our mind, our thought, our concept, our opinion. When we set our mind not on the things of God but on the things of men, our mind grasps the opportunity to act and express itself. This was what happened with Peter. Hence, the Lord's subsequent word indicated that Peter had to deny himself, i.e., not save his soul-life but lose it. Losing the soul-life is the reality of denying the self. This is to take up the cross.

The cross is not merely a suffering; it is also a killing. It kills and terminates the criminal. Christ first bore the cross and then was crucified. We, His believers, first were crucified with Him and now bear the cross. To us, to bear the cross is to remain under the killing of the death of Christ for the terminating of our self, our natural life, and our old man. In so doing we deny our self that we may follow the Lord.

Before the Lord's crucifixion the disciples followed Him in an outward way. But now, after His resurrection, we follow Him in an inward way. Because in resurrection He has become the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]) dwelling in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]), we follow Him in our spirit ([link]Gal. 5:16-25[/link]).

verse.text: For whoever wants to save his [xref]a[/xref]soul-life shall [note]1[/note]lose it; but whoever [note]2[/note]loses his soul-life for My sake shall find it.
verse.note: Or, destroy.
See note [link]39[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: For what shall a man be profited if he gains the whole world, but forfeits his [note]1[/note]soul-life? Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul-life?
verse.note: In [link]Luke 9:24-25[/link] [i]soul-life[/i] is replaced with [i]himself,[/i] indicating that our soul-life is our self.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man is to [xref]b[/xref]come in the [xref]c[/xref]glory of His Father with His [xref]d[/xref]angels, and then He will [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]repay each man according to his doings.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that the Lord's rewarding of His followers at His coming back, as mentioned in this verse, will be according to whether they lose or save their soul, as mentioned in [link]vv. 25-26[/link].
This will take place at the judgment seat of Christ when He comes back ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]).

verse.text: Truly I say to you, There are some of those standing here who shall by no means taste death until they see the Son of Man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]coming in His kingdom.
verse.note: This was fulfilled by the Lord's transfiguration on the mountain ([link]17:1-2[/link]). His transfiguration was His coming in His kingdom. It was seen by His three disciples — Peter, James, and John.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And after six days Jesus [xref]b[/xref]took with [i]Him[/i] Peter and James and John his brother, and [note]1[/note]brought them up to a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]high mountain privately.
verse.note: The record from [link]13:53-17:8[/link] portrays the way to follow the heavenly King, from His rejection to the entering of the manifestation of the kingdom. His followers not only shared His being rejected by the Jews ([link]13:53-58[/link]) but also were persecuted and even martyred by Gentile politics ([link]14:1-12[/link]). They were in a deserted place with Him in a situation of poverty, yet they were richly cared for by Him ([link]14:13-21[/link]). When they were on the stormy sea under the contrary wind, He walked on the sea, calmed the storm, and brought them through ([link]14:22-34[/link]). At that point many sick ones were healed by touching Him ([link]14:35-36[/link]), but the hypocritical worshippers of God came to heckle Him because His followers transgressed their tradition ([link]15:1-20[/link]). Then His disciples followed Him to a Gentile region, where a demon-possessed Gentile was healed ([link]15:21-28[/link]). After that, they followed Him along the sea of Galilee and up the mountain, where all kinds of sick people were healed and the need of His followers and the crowd was again richly provided for in a barren wilderness ([link]15:29-39[/link]). After that, both the fundamentalists and the modernists of that day came to tempt Him, and He indicated that He would die to be a unique sign to them ([link]16:1-4[/link]). Then He charged His followers to beware of the leaven of both the fundamentalists and the modernists ([link]16:5-12[/link]). After all that, He brought His followers to the border of the Holy Land, close to a Gentile land, that they might have a revelation of Him, of the church, and of the cross as the way for them to enter into the kingdom ([link]16:13-28[/link]). Finally, He brought them into glory in the manifestation of the kingdom ([link]vv. 1-8[/link]).

Since the Lord's transfiguration occurred six days after the revelations (given at the foot of Mount Hermon) in [link]ch. 16[/link] concerning Christ and the church, the high mountain here must be Mount Hermon. To receive the revelation concerning Christ and the church, we must be far away from the religious environment; but to see the vision of the transfigured Christ, we need to be on a high mountain, far above the earthly level.

verse.text: And He was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]transfigured before them, and His face shone like the [xref]b[/xref]sun, and His garments became as [xref]c[/xref]white as the light.
verse.note: Lit., transformed.

verse.text: And behold, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Moses and [xref]b[/xref]Elijah appeared to them, conversing with Him.
verse.note: Moses died and God hid his body ([link]Deut. 34:5-6[/link]); Elijah was taken by God into heaven ([link]2 Kings 2:11[/link]). God purposely did these two things that Moses and Elijah might appear with Christ on the mount of His transfiguration. They were preserved by God so that they could be the two witnesses in the great tribulation ([link]Rev. 11:3-4[/link]). Moses represented the law, and Elijah, the prophets; and the law and the prophets were the constituents of the Old Testament as a full testimony of Christ ([link]John 5:39[/link]). Now Moses and Elijah appeared and conversed with Christ concerning His death ([link]Luke 9:31[/link]), which had been spoken of in the Old Testament ([link]Luke 24:25-27[/link], [link]44[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link]).

verse.text: And Peter answered and said to Jesus, Lord, it is good for us to be here; if You are willing, I will make [note]1[/note]three [xref]a[/xref]tents here, one for You and one for Moses and one for Elijah.
verse.note: In his absurd proposal, Peter put Moses and Elijah on the same level as Christ; i.e., he made the law and the prophets equal with Christ. This was absolutely against God's economy. In God's economy the law and the prophets are only a testimony of Christ; they should not be put on the same level with Him.

verse.text: While he was still speaking, behold, a bright [xref]a[/xref]cloud overshadowed them, and behold, a [xref]b[/xref]voice out of the cloud, saying, [note]1[/note]This is My Son, the [xref]c[/xref]Beloved, in whom I have found My delight. [xref]d[/xref]Hear [note]2[/note]Him!
verse.note: This declaration of the Father, given to vindicate the Son, was first spoken after Christ's rising from baptism, which signified His resurrection from the dead. This was the second time the Father made this declaration, this time to vindicate the Son in His transfiguration, which prefigures the coming kingdom.
In God's economy, after Christ came, we should hear Him; we should no longer hear the law or the prophets, since the law and the prophets were fulfilled in and by Christ.

verse.text: And when the disciples [xref]a[/xref]heard [i]this,[/i] they [xref]b[/xref]fell on their face and were greatly frightened.
And Jesus came to [i]them[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]touched them and said, Arise, and do not be afraid.
And when they lifted up their eyes, they saw [note]1[/note]no one except Jesus Himself alone.
verse.note: Peter proposed to keep Moses and Elijah, i.e., the law and the prophets, with Christ, but God took Moses and Elijah away, leaving no one except Jesus Himself. The law and the prophets were shadows and prophecies, not the reality; the reality is Christ. Now that Christ, the reality, is here, the shadows and prophecies are no longer needed. No one except Jesus Himself should remain in the New Testament. Jesus is today's Moses; as such, He imparts the law of life into His believers. Jesus is also today's Elijah; as such, He speaks for God and speaks forth God within His believers. This is God's New Testament economy.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as they were coming down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, saying, Tell the [note]1[/note]vision to no one until the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man is [xref]c[/xref]raised from the dead.
verse.note: The vision of the transfigured, glorified Jesus can be seen clearly only in the resurrection of Christ.

verse.text: And the disciples asked Him, saying, Why then do the scribes say that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Elijah must come first?
verse.note: This was according to [link]Mal. 4:5-6[/link].

verse.text: And He answered and said, [note]1[/note]Elijah indeed is coming and will [xref]a[/xref]restore all things;
verse.note: This will be fulfilled at the time of the great tribulation, when Elijah will be one of the two witnesses ([link]Rev. 11:3-4[/link]), as prophesied in [link]Mal. 4:5-6[/link].

verse.text: But I say to you that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Elijah has already come; and they did not recognize him, but [xref]b[/xref]did with him the things they wished. So also the Son of Man is about to suffer by them.
verse.note: This refers to John the Baptist ([link]v. 13[/link]), who came in the spirit and power of Elijah ([link]Luke 1:13-17[/link]) and was rejected ([link]11:18[/link]) and beheaded ([link]14:3-12[/link]).

verse.text: Then the disciples understood that He spoke to them concerning John the Baptist.
[xref]a[/xref]And when they came to the crowd, a man came to Him, falling on his knees before Him and saying,
Lord, have mercy on my son, for he [note]1[/note]has epilepsy and suffers terribly; for often he falls into the fire and often into the water.
verse.note: Lit., is moonstruck. [i]Epilepsy[/i] indicates the true nature of the disease.

verse.text: And I brought him to Your disciples, and they were not able to heal him.
And Jesus answered and said, O [xref]a[/xref]unbelieving and [xref]b[/xref]perverted generation! How long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him here to Me.
And Jesus [xref]a[/xref]rebuked it, and the demon came out from him; and the boy was healed from that hour.
Then the disciples, coming to Jesus privately, said, Why were we not able to cast it out?

And He said to them, Because of your [xref]a[/xref]little faith; for truly I say to you, If you have faith like a [xref]b[/xref]mustard seed, you will say to this [xref]c[/xref]mountain, Move from here to there, and it will move; and nothing will be [xref]d[/xref]impossible to you.
[note]1[/note]But this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting.
verse.note: Most ancient authorities omit this verse.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And while they [note]1[/note]were gathering together in [xref]b[/xref]Galilee, Jesus said to them, The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men,
verse.note: Some ancient authorities read, abode.

verse.text: And they will [xref]a[/xref]kill Him, and on the third day He will be raised. And they were greatly grieved.
And when they came to [xref]a[/xref]Capernaum, those who take up the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]temple tax came to Peter and said, Does not your Teacher pay the [note]1[/note]temple tax?
verse.note: A Jewish poll tax for the temple, equal to a half-shekel ([link]Exo. 30:12-16[/link]; [link]38:26[/link]).

verse.text: He said, [note]1[/note]Yes. And when he came into the house, Jesus [note]2[/note]anticipated him, saying, What do you [xref]a[/xref]think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth receive custom or poll tax, from their sons or from strangers?
verse.note: On the Mount of Transfiguration Peter heard the voice from heaven, which charged him to hear Christ ([link]17:5[/link]). If he had still remembered that word, he would have referred the poll tax gatherers' question to Christ to hear what He would say. But he answered instead of listening to what Christ would say.
Peter had spoken presumptuously. Hence, the Lord stopped him and corrected him before he began to speak to Him.

verse.text: And when he said, From strangers, Jesus said to him, So then the [note]1[/note]sons are free.
verse.note: The sons of kings are always free from paying custom or poll tax. The half-shekel was paid by God's people for His temple. Since Christ was the Son of God, He was free from paying it. This was contrary to Peter's answer concerning this matter.[br][br]Peter had received the revelation concerning Christ's being the Son of God ([link]16:16-17[/link]) and had seen the vision of the Son of God ([link]v. 5[/link]). Now, in application of what he had seen, he was put to the test by the poll tax gatherers' question. He failed in his answer because he forgot the revelation that he had received and the vision that he had seen. He forgot that the Lord was the Son of God, who, as such, did not need to pay the poll tax for His Father's house.

verse.text: But that we do not [xref]a[/xref]stumble them, [note]1[/note]go to the sea and cast a hook, and take the first fish that comes up. And when you open its mouth, you will find a [note]2[/note]stater; take that and [note]3[/note]give [i]it[/i] to them for Me [note]4[/note]and you.
verse.note: After shutting Peter's mouth, the Lord, as the New Testament Prophet, today's Elijah, told him to go fishing and that in so doing he would find a stater. This prophecy was fulfilled. Peter was no doubt troubled that he had to go fishing and wait for a fish to appear with a stater.
Equal to one shekel.

After convincing Peter that He did not need to pay the half-shekel, the Lord, as the New Testament Lawgiver, today's Moses, commanded Peter to pay it for Him. The Lord did this purposely to teach Peter that in God's New Testament economy He is the unique One; neither Moses nor Elijah nor Peter nor anyone else has the position to speak or to give the command.
While the Lord was correcting and teaching Peter, He took care of his need. This is always the Lord's way in dealing with us.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]In that hour the disciples came to Jesus, saying, Who then is [xref]b[/xref]greatest [note]1[/note]in the kingdom of the heavens?
verse.note: This chapter deals with the way we should live and act in the kingdom of the heavens: (1) we should become like little children ([link]vv. 2-4[/link]); (2) we should not stumble others or set up any stumbling block ([link]vv. 5-9[/link]); (3) we should not despise even a little believer ([link]vv. 10-14[/link]); (4) we should hear the church and not be condemned by it ([link]vv. 15-20[/link]); and (5) we should forgive a brother without limit ([link]vv. 21-35[/link]). All this indicates that to enter into the kingdom of the heavens we must be humble and not despise any believer, but love our brother and forgive our brother.

verse.text: And He called a little child to [i]Him[/i] and stood him in their midst
And said, Truly I say to you, Unless you turn and become like [xref]a[/xref]little children, you shall by no means [xref]b[/xref]enter into the kingdom of the heavens.
He therefore who will [xref]a[/xref]humble himself like this little child, he is the greatest in the kingdom of the heavens.
And whoever receives one such little child [note]1[/note]because of My name, receives Me;
verse.note: Lit., upon; i.e., based on, according to.

verse.text: And whoever [xref]a[/xref]stumbles one of these little ones who believe into Me, it is [note]1[/note][i]more[/i] profitable for him that a [note]2[/note]great [xref]b[/xref]millstone be hung around his neck and he be drowned in the open sea.
verse.note: Or, advantageous, better.
Lit., millstone (turned) by a donkey.
