verse.text: Woe to the world because of [xref]a[/xref]stumbling blocks! For it is necessary for stumbling blocks to come, but woe to that man through whom the stumbling block comes.

If your [xref]a[/xref]hand or your foot stumbles you, [note]1[/note]cut it off and cast [i]it[/i] from you; it is better for you to enter into life maimed or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be cast into the eternal [xref]b[/xref]fire.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And if your [xref]a[/xref]eye stumbles you, [note]1[/note]pluck it out and cast [i]it[/i] from you; it is better for you to enter into life with one eye than to have two eyes and be cast into the [note]2[/note]Gehenna of fire.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].
See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: See that you do not despise one of these little ones, for I say to you that their [xref]a[/xref]angels in the heavens continually behold the face of My Father who is in the heavens.
[note]1[/note]For the Son of Man has come to save that which is lost.
verse.note: Many ancient MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]What do you think? [xref]b[/xref]If any man has a hundred sheep and one of them goes astray, will he not leave the ninety-nine on the mountains and go and seek the one that has gone astray?
And if it so happens that he finds it, truly I say to you that he rejoices over it more than over the ninety-nine which have not gone astray.
In the same way, it is not the will of [note]1[/note]your Father who is in the heavens that one of these little ones [xref]a[/xref]perish.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS read, My.

verse.text: Moreover if your brother [xref]a[/xref]sins against you, go, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]reprove him [note]2[/note]between you and him alone. If he hears you, you have gained your brother.
verse.note: That he may know his sin and confess his wrongdoing.
That no third party may know the wrongdoing of the sinning brother. This is a covering of love.

verse.text: But if he does not hear [i]you,[/i] take with you one or two more, that by the mouth of two or three [xref]a[/xref]witnesses every word may be established.

And if he refuses to hear them, [note]1[/note]tell [i]it[/i] to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]church; and if he refuses to hear the church also, let him be to you [note]3[/note]just like the [xref]b[/xref]Gentile and the [xref]c[/xref]tax collector.
verse.note: If a brother sins against us, we need to deal with him first in love ([link]v. 15[/link]), then by two or three witnesses ([link]v. 16[/link]), and finally through the church with authority ([link]v. 17[/link]).

The church revealed in [link]16:18[/link] is the universal church, which is the unique Body of Christ, whereas the church revealed here is the local church, the expression of the unique Body of Christ in a certain locality. [link]Chapter 16[/link] concerns the building of the universal church, whereas this chapter concerns the practice of the local church. In both of its aspects the church represents the kingdom of the heavens, having authority to bind and to loose.

If any believer refuses to hear the church, he will lose the fellowship of the church and will be like the Gentile (the heathen) and the tax collector (the sinner), who are outside the fellowship of the church.

verse.text: Truly I say to you, Whatever you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bind on the earth shall [note]2[/note]have been bound in heaven, and whatever you [note]1[/note]loose on the earth shall [note]2[/note]have been loosed in heaven.
verse.note: Here to bind means to condemn, and to loose means to forgive.
See note [link]19[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: Again, truly I say to you that if two of you are [note]1[/note]in harmony on earth concerning any matter for which they [note]2[/note]ask, [note]3[/note]it will be done for them from My Father who is in the heavens.
verse.note: As musical sounds are in harmony.
Strictly, [i]ask[/i] here refers to prayer that deals with the brother who refuses to hear the church ([link]v. 17[/link]).
Lit., it will be unto them.

verse.text: For where there are [note]1[/note]two or three [note]2[/note]gathered into My name, there am I in their [xref]a[/xref]midst.
verse.note: These two or three are the two or three in [link]v. 16[/link]. They are gathered together into the Lord's name, but they are not the church; for [link]v. 17[/link] says that if there is some problem, they need to tell it to the church.

The meetings of the believers are initiated by the Lord, who calls the believers out of all persons, matters, and things that occupy them and gathers them together into His name to enjoy the riches of His presence.[br][br]Such a gathering of a few people, of two or three, implies one of the ways for the church to meet locally. Such meetings of a few people must have been held in the believers' homes, as mentioned in [link]Acts 2:46[/link] and [link]5:42[/link], for the purpose of prayer ([link]v. 19[/link]; [link]Acts 12:5[/link], [link]12[/link]), fellowship, the breaking of bread, teaching, or the preaching of the gospel ([link]Acts 2:42[/link]; [link]5:42[/link]). Many such meetings may be held separately in the same locality, yet they are still the unique church in that locality ([link]v. 17[/link]). Otherwise, they are not separate meetings but divisions, and they become sects ([link]Gal. 5:20[/link]).

verse.text: Then Peter came and said to Him, Lord, how often shall my brother [xref]a[/xref]sin against me and I [xref]b[/xref]forgive him? Up to [xref]c[/xref]seven times?
Jesus said to him, I do not say to you, Up to seven times, but, Up to seventy times seven.
For this reason the kingdom of the heavens has become like a [note]1[/note]king who desired to [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]settle accounts with his slaves.
verse.note: Lit., a man, a king.
This refers to the judgment at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]).

verse.text: And when he began to settle [i]them,[/i] one who owed him [note]1[/note]ten thousand talents was brought to him.
verse.note: Such a large amount indicates that it was impossible for the debtor to pay off the debt. This refers to the heavy debt of our sins against the Lord accumulated after we are saved.

verse.text: But since he did not have [i]the means[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]repay, the master commanded him to be [xref]b[/xref]sold, as well as his wife and children and all that he had, and repayment to be made.
Then the slave fell down and worshipped him, saying, Be patient with me and I will repay you all.
And the master of that slave was moved with compassion and released him and [note]1[/note]forgave him the loan.
verse.note: This refers to the forgiveness of our debts incurred after we are saved and become slaves of the Lord.

verse.text: But that slave went out and found one of his fellow slaves who owed him a [note]1[/note]hundred denarii, and he took hold of him and began to choke [i]him,[/i] saying, Repay [i]me[/i] what you owe.
verse.note: Less than one ten thousandth of ten thousand talents. It refers to a sin committed against us by a brother after we are saved and become slaves of the Lord.

verse.text: Then his fellow slave fell down and begged him, saying, Be patient with me and I will repay you.
But he would not; instead, he went away and threw him into prison until he would repay what was owed.
Then his fellow slaves, seeing what had taken place, were greatly [note]1[/note]grieved and came and explained fully to their master all that had taken place.
verse.note: Our not forgiving the brother who sins against us will grieve the other brothers, and they may bring this matter to the Lord.

verse.text: Then his master called him to [i]him[/i] and said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Evil slave, all that debt I forgave you, because you begged me.
Should you not also have had [xref]a[/xref]mercy on your fellow slave even [xref]b[/xref]as I had mercy on you?
And his master became angry and [note]1[/note]delivered him to the torturers until he would [xref]a[/xref]repay all that was owed.
verse.note: This refers to the Lord's dealing with His believers at His coming back. If we do not forgive the brother who sins against us, we will be disciplined by the Lord until we forgive him from the heart, i.e., until we repay all that is owed. Then the Lord will forgive us. This is forgiveness in the kingdom. This implies that if we do not forgive a brother from our heart today, we will not be allowed to enter into the kingdom in the coming age. See note [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: So also will My heavenly Father do to you if each of you does [xref]a[/xref]not forgive his brother [xref]b[/xref]from your hearts.
And when Jesus finished these words, He departed from Galilee and came into the borders of Judea [xref]a[/xref]beyond the Jordan.
And great crowds followed Him, and He healed them there.
[xref]a[/xref]And some Pharisees came to Him, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]testing Him and saying, Is it lawful for a man to [note]2[/note]divorce his wife for any cause?
verse.note: The religionists did not let the Lord go but came again and again to test Him. However, their testing always afforded the Lord an opportunity to unveil Himself and God's economy.
Lit., release. So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: And He answered and said, Have you [xref]a[/xref]not read that [note]1[/note]He who [xref]b[/xref]created [i]them[/i] from the beginning made them male and female,
verse.note: From here to the end of [link]v. 6[/link], the Lord's word not only acknowledged God's creation of man but also confirmed God's ordination regarding man's marriage, that is, that one male and one female are to be joined and yoked together as one flesh and are not to be separated by man.

verse.text: And said, "For this cause shall a man leave his father and his mother and shall be [xref]a[/xref]joined to his wife; and the two shall be one flesh"?
So then they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has yoked together, let man not [xref]a[/xref]separate.
They said to Him, Why then did Moses [note]1[/note]command [i]us[/i] to give [i]her[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]certificate of divorce and divorce her?
verse.note: This commandment was not a part of the basic law but was a supplement to the law. It was given by Moses not according to God's ordination from the beginning but as something temporary, because of the hardness of man's heart.

verse.text: He said to them, Moses, because of your [xref]a[/xref]hardness of heart, allowed you to divorce your wives, but from the [note]1[/note]beginning it has not been so.
verse.note: The commandment given by Moses concerning divorce was a deviation from God's original ordination concerning marriage, but for the kingdom of the heavens Christ as the heavenly King recovered marriage back to the beginning. This indicates that the kingdom of the heavens, which corresponds with God's ordination from the beginning, does not allow divorce.

verse.text: But I say to you that whoever divorces his wife, except for [note]1[/note]fornication, and marries another, commits [xref]a[/xref]adultery; [note]2[/note]and he who marries her who has been divorced commits adultery.
verse.note: Lit., harlotry, whoredom. This is worse than adultery. The Lord's word here indicates definitely that nothing but fornication breaks the marriage tie. (Of course, death breaks it spontaneously.) Hence, except for fornication there is no excuse for divorce.
The words from here to the end of the verse are omitted by some ancient authorities.

verse.text: His disciples said to Him, If the case of the man with his wife is [note]1[/note]like this, it is not profitable to marry.
verse.note: At that point the disciples realized that according to God's ordination, marriage is the strictest bond. Once a person is married, he is fully bound, having no way to be released except through the committing of fornication by the spouse (or through the death of the spouse). It was such a realization that caused the disciples to think that it was not profitable to marry. But it was not under their control.

verse.text: And He said to them, [note]1[/note]Not all men [i]can[/i] [note]2[/note]accept this word, but [i]only those[/i] to whom it has been [xref]a[/xref]given.
verse.note: Not all men, but only those to whom God has given the gift, are able to refrain from marriage. Without God's gift, anyone who attempts to remain unmarried will meet with temptations.
Lit., have room for.

verse.text: For there are eunuchs who were born so from their mother's womb, and there are eunuchs who were made eunuchs by men, and there are eunuchs [note]1[/note]who made themselves eunuchs [xref]a[/xref]because of the [note]2[/note]kingdom of the heavens. He who can [i]accept it,[/i] let him accept [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: These are the ones to whom God has given the gift to remain unmarried for the sake of the kingdom of the heavens. Paul was such a one ([link]1 Cor. 7:7-8[/link]; [link]9:5[/link]).

The religionists' temptation here afforded the Lord an opportunity to reveal a further matter concerning the kingdom of the heavens. [link]Chapter 18[/link] reveals how we must deal with the brothers so that we can enter into the kingdom of the heavens, whereas this chapter reveals that marriage life ([link]vv. 3-12[/link]) and our attitude toward riches ([link]vv. 16-30[/link]) are related to the kingdom of the heavens. Marriage life touches the matter of lust, and our attitude toward riches touches the matter of covetousness. The kingdom of the heavens rules out every trace of our lust and covetousness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then little children were brought to Him that He might lay His hands on them and pray, but the disciples [xref]b[/xref]rebuked them.
But Jesus said, Allow the little children and do not prevent them from coming to Me, for [xref]a[/xref]of [note]1[/note]such is the kingdom of the heavens.
verse.note: Here the Lord stressed again that to participate in the kingdom of the heavens, we must be like little children.

verse.text: And after He laid His hands on them, He went on from there.
[xref]a[/xref]And behold, someone came to Him and said, Teacher, what good thing shall I do that I may [note]1[/note]have [xref]b[/xref]eternal life?
verse.note: Having eternal life as spoken of in Matthew differs from having eternal life as spoken of in John. Matthew is concerned with the kingdom, whereas John is concerned with life. In John, to have eternal life is to be saved by God's uncreated life that we may live by that life today and for eternity; but in Matthew, to have eternal life is to participate in the reality of the kingdom of the heavens in this age by God's eternal life and to share in the kingdom's manifestation in the coming age, thereby enjoying God's eternal life in a fuller way.

verse.text: And He said to him, Why do you ask Me concerning what is good? There is [i]only[/i] [note]1[/note]One [i]who is[/i] [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]good. But if you want to [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]enter into life, [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]keep the commandments.
verse.note: This One is God. Only God is good. This indicates not only that the young man asking the question was not good but also that the Lord Jesus is God, who is good. If He were not God, He too would not be good.
Lit., the good.

Here to enter into life means to enter into the kingdom of the heavens ([link]v. 23[/link]). The kingdom of the heavens is a realm of God's eternal life. Hence, when we enter into it, we enter into God's life. This differs from being saved. To be saved is to have God's life enter into us to be our life, whereas to enter into the kingdom of the heavens is to enter into God's life to enjoy the riches of God's life. The former is to be redeemed and regenerated by the Holy Spirit, whereby we receive God's life; the latter is to live and walk by God's life. One is a matter of life; the other is a matter of living. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link].

This is not the requirement for salvation; it is related to entering into the kingdom of the heavens. According to the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens, to enter into the kingdom of the heavens requires us to meet not only the standard of the old law but also the standard of the complemented new law given by the King ([link]5:17-48[/link]). Salvation requires only faith, whereas the kingdom of the heavens requires the surpassing righteousness that issues from the keeping of the old law and the complemented law given by the heavenly King.

verse.text: He said to Him, Which ones? And Jesus said, "You shall [xref]a[/xref]not murder; you shall not commit adultery; you shall not steal; you shall not bear false witness;
[xref]a[/xref]Honor your father and mother; and you shall [xref]b[/xref]love your neighbor as yourself."
The young man said to Him, All these things I have kept. What do I still lack?

Jesus said to him, If you want to be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]perfect, go, [xref]b[/xref]sell your possessions and give to the poor, and you will have [xref]c[/xref]treasure in the heavens; and come, [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]follow Me.
verse.note: Even though the young man had observed the commandments of the old law — or so he assumed — he still was not perfect, not up to the standard of the requirement of the complemented new law, for he was not willing to sell what he had and store up treasure in heaven, as the constitution of the kingdom required ([link]6:19-21[/link]).
To follow the Lord is to love Him above all things ([link]10:37-38[/link]). This is the supreme requirement for entering into the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: But the young man, hearing this word, went away [note]1[/note]sorrowing, for he had many possessions.
verse.note: Loving material possessions above the Lord causes one to sorrow, but those who love Christ above all things accept with joy the loss of their possessions ([link]Heb. 10:34[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Jesus said to His disciples, Truly I say to you, [i]Only[/i] with difficulty will a [xref]b[/xref]rich man enter into the kingdom of the heavens.
And again I say to you, It is [note]1[/note]easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of [note]2[/note]God.
verse.note: The Lord's word here indicates the impossibility of entering into the kingdom of God by our natural life.

[link]Verse 23[/link] uses [i]kingdom of the heavens,[/i] but here [i]kingdom of God[/i] is used. At this point the kingdom of the heavens had not come, but the kingdom of God was there. Hence, the Lord used the term [i]kingdom of God.[/i]

verse.text: And when the disciples heard [i]this,[/i] they were greatly astonished and said, Who then can be [note]1[/note]saved?
verse.note: As most Christians do today, the disciples confused salvation with entering into the kingdom of the heavens. The Lord's word to the young man concerned entering into the kingdom of the heavens ([link]vv. 23-24[/link]), but the disciples thought that it referred to salvation. Their concept of salvation was natural and common. They did not grasp the Lord's revelation concerning entering into the kingdom of the heavens.

verse.text: And looking upon [i]them,[/i] Jesus said to them, With men this is [note]1[/note]impossible, but with God all things are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]possible.
verse.note: By our human life it is impossible to enter into the kingdom of the heavens, but it is possible by God's divine life, which is Christ Himself imparted into us so that we can live the kingdom life. By Christ, who empowers us to do all things ([link]Phil. 4:13[/link]), we can fulfill the requirements of the kingdom.

verse.text: Then Peter answered and said to Him, Behold, we have left all and [xref]a[/xref]followed You. What then will there be for us?

And Jesus said to them, Truly I say to you that you who have followed Me, in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]restoration, when the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man sits on the [xref]c[/xref]throne of His glory, you also shall [xref]d[/xref]sit on twelve thrones, [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
verse.note: This is the restoration in the coming kingdom age ([link]Acts 3:21[/link]), after the Lord's second coming.

In the coming kingdom the overcomers will sit on thrones to reign over the earth ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link]). The first twelve apostles, including Peter, will judge the twelve tribes of Israel, and the other overcomers will rule over the nations ([link]Rev. 2:26[/link]).

verse.text: And everyone who has left houses or [xref]a[/xref]brothers or sisters or father or mother or children or fields for My name's sake shall [note]1[/note]receive [note]2[/note]a hundred times as much and shall [note]3[/note]inherit [xref]b[/xref]eternal life.
verse.note: To receive a hundred times as many houses, fields, and relatives is to be rewarded in this age ([link]Mark 10:30[/link]). This refers to our enjoyment today of brothers and sisters in the Lord, with their possessions.
Some ancient authorities read, manifold.

To inherit eternal life is to be rewarded in the coming age ([link]Luke 18:29-30[/link]), in the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, with an enjoyment of the divine life that is fuller than the enjoyment in this age.

verse.text: But many [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first will be last, and [i]many[/i] last first.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 20[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For the kingdom of the heavens is like a [note]2[/note]man, [i]who is[/i] a householder, who went out early in the [note]3[/note]morning to hire [note]4[/note]workmen for his [note]5[/note][xref]a[/xref]vineyard.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that the parable in [link]vv. 1-16[/link] is an explanation of [link]19:30[/link].
Denoting Christ, who is the householder.
Morning here is 6:00 a.m., denoting the earliest part of the church age, when Christ came to call His disciples into the kingdom.
The workmen denote the disciples.
The vineyard denotes the kingdom.

verse.text: And having [note]1[/note]agreed with the workmen for a [note]2[/note]denarius a day, he sent them into his vineyard.
verse.note: Referring to the agreement the Lord made in [link]19:27-29[/link].
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link]. The denarius here denotes the reward the Lord offered Peter in His agreement with him in [link]19:27-29[/link].

verse.text: And he went out about the [note]1[/note]third hour and saw others standing [note]2[/note]idle in the [note]3[/note]marketplace,
verse.note: Hebrew time; so in Matthew, Mark, Luke, and Acts. This is 9:00 a.m., denoting the second part of the church age.
This word indicates that whoever does not work in the kingdom of the heavens is standing idle in the world.
The marketplace denotes the world.

verse.text: And to those he said, You also go into the vineyard, and whatever is right I will give you. And they went.
And again he went out about the [note]1[/note]sixth and the [note]2[/note]ninth hour and did likewise.
verse.note: 12:00 noon, denoting the middle part of the church age.
3:00 p.m., denoting the fourth part of the church age.

verse.text: And about the [note]1[/note]eleventh hour he went out and found others standing, and said to them, Why have you been standing here all the day idle?
verse.note: 5:00 p.m., denoting the fifth part of the church age. So in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: They said to him, Because [note]1[/note]no one has hired us. He said to them, You [note]2[/note]also go into the vineyard.
verse.note: Outside the kingdom of God, no human beings are employed by God.
Even near the end of the church age the Lord still calls people.

verse.text: And when [note]1[/note]evening fell, the master of the vineyard said to his steward, Call the workmen and pay them their wages, beginning from the [note]2[/note]last ones to the first.
verse.note: 6:00 p.m., denoting the end of the church age.

This is against the natural and commercial concept. It indicates that the wages paid to the last workmen are not according to their work but according to the gracious wish of the Lord of the vineyard.

verse.text: And when those [i]hired[/i] about the eleventh hour came, they received each a denarius.
And when the [note]1[/note]first ones came, they supposed that they would receive more. And they themselves also received each a denarius.
verse.note: These first workmen included Peter, who made a deal with the Lord in [link]19:27-29[/link].

verse.text: And when they received [i]it,[/i] they murmured against the householder,
[note]1[/note]Saying, These last ones worked one hour, and you have made them [note]2[/note]equal to us who bore the burden of the day and the scorching heat.
verse.note: They did not know [link]Rom. 9:14-15[/link], [link]20[/link]. There is no unrighteousness with the Lord. He will have mercy on whom He will have mercy. Who were they to reply against the Lord?
Peter's natural concept, representing that of all believers, was commercial; he did not know the Lord's gracious wish.

verse.text: But he answered [note]1[/note]one of them and said, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Friend, I am doing nothing unrighteous to you. Did you not [note]3[/note]agree with me for a denarius?
verse.note: By [i]one of them,[/i] the Lord was referring undoubtedly to Peter.
Lit., comrade, companion, partner.
Denoting the agreement the Lord made with Peter in [link]19:27-29[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Take what is yours and go. I [note]1[/note]want to give to this last one even as I have given to you.
verse.note: This was a strong answer to Peter from the Lord, indicating that the Lord had given him what he thought he deserved. But the Lord has the right to give the same wages to the last workmen according to His own wish, in the principle not of work but of grace. This shattered Peter's natural and commercial mind and corrected his concept.

verse.text: Is it not lawful for me to do what I [note]1[/note]wish with what is mine? Or is your eye [note]2[/note]evil because I am [note]1[/note]good?
verse.note: In dealing with the Lord in [link]19:27[/link], Peter's concept was altogether commercial, according to the principle of work, not grace. In His answer to Peter, the Lord strongly indicated that His reward to His followers is not a commercial matter but a matter according to His desire and grace. For the disciples to gain the kingdom of the heavens, they needed to leave all and follow the Lord; but what He will give them as a reward is more than they deserve. It is not according to the principle of commerce but according to the Lord's good pleasure. This is an incentive to His followers.
Cf. note [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 7[/link].

verse.text: Thus shall the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]last be first and the first last.
verse.note: The last are the latest workmen, and the first are the earliest ones. In working, the earliest come first, but in receiving the reward, the last become the first. It is in this way that the Lord makes the last first and the first last.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as Jesus was going up to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem, He took the twelve disciples aside privately, and on the way He said to them,
Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be delivered to the chief priests and scribes. And they will condemn Him to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]death,
verse.note: This was the third time the Lord revealed His death to the disciples. The first was in Caesarea Philippi, before His transfiguration ([link]16:13[/link], [link]21[/link]). The second was in Galilee, after His transfiguration ([link]17:22[/link]). This third time was on the way to Jerusalem. This revelation was a prophecy, altogether strange to the natural concept of the disciples; yet it would be fulfilled literally, in every detail.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]deliver Him to the Gentiles to [xref]b[/xref]mock and to scourge and to [xref]c[/xref]crucify [i]Him,[/i] and on the [xref]d[/xref]third day He will be raised.
[xref]a[/xref]Then the mother of the [note]1[/note]sons of [xref]b[/xref]Zebedee came to Him with her sons, worshipping and asking something of Him.
verse.note: John and James.

verse.text: And He said to her, What do you want? She said to Him, Say that these two sons of mine will [xref]a[/xref]sit, one on Your right and one on Your left, in Your kingdom.
But Jesus answered and said [i]to them,[/i] You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to [note]1[/note]drink the [xref]a[/xref]cup which I am about to drink? They said to Him, We are able.
verse.note: If we ask to sit on the throne in the kingdom, we must be prepared to drink the cup of suffering. To suffer the cross is the way to enter into the kingdom ([link]Acts 14:22[/link]). The selfish entreaty of the mother of John and James afforded the Lord an opportunity to reveal the way to enter into the kingdom.

verse.text: He said to them, My cup you shall indeed [xref]a[/xref]drink, but to sit on My right and on My left, this is [note]1[/note]not Mine to give, but [i]it is for[/i] those for whom it has been prepared by My Father.
verse.note: Standing in the position of man, the Lord was fully subject to the Father; He did not assume the right to do anything outside the Father.

verse.text: And when the ten heard [i]this,[/i] they were indignant concerning the two brothers.
[xref]a[/xref]But Jesus called them to [i]Him[/i] and said, You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and the great exercise authority over them.
It shall not be so among you; but whoever wants to become [xref]a[/xref]great among you shall be your [note]1[/note]servant,
verse.note: This is absolutely contrary to the natural, self-seeking mind. The indignation of the ten disciples ([link]v. 24[/link]) also afforded the Lord an opportunity to reveal the way to live in the kingdom: to be willing to serve others as a servant, even as a slave ([link]v. 27[/link]), rather than rule over others.

verse.text: And whoever wants to be first among you shall be your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]slave;
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Just as the [xref]a[/xref]Son of [note]1[/note]Man did not come to be served, but to [xref]b[/xref]serve and to give His [note]2[/note]life as a [xref]c[/xref]ransom for many.
verse.note: In this book, the book on the kingdom, the Lord stood always in the position of man. Although the kingdom of the heavens is constituted with the divine life, it is carried out in humanity.
Lit., soul, soul-life.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as they were going out from Jericho, a great crowd followed Him.
And behold, two [xref]a[/xref]blind men sitting by the road, hearing that Jesus was passing by, cried out, saying, Have mercy on us, Lord, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of David!
verse.note: The royal title of Christ for the children of Israel. See note [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: And the crowd [xref]a[/xref]rebuked them so that they would be silent, but they cried out the more, saying, Have mercy on us, Lord, Son of David!
And Jesus, standing still, called them and said, What do you want Me to do for you?
They said to Him, Lord, that our eyes may be opened.
And Jesus, moved with [xref]a[/xref]compassion, touched their eyes, and immediately they received their sight and followed Him.
[xref]a[/xref]And when they [note]1[/note]drew near to Jerusalem and came to Bethphage at the Mount of [xref]b[/xref]Olives, then Jesus sent two disciples,
verse.note: They began the journey from Galilee in [link]19:1[/link]. They were on the way in [link]20:17[/link] and passed through Jericho in [link]20:29[/link]. Now they came to the Mount of Olives, near Jerusalem.

verse.text: Saying to them, Go into the village opposite you, and immediately you will [note]1[/note]find a donkey tied and a colt with her; untie [i]them[/i] and lead [i]them[/i] to Me.
verse.note: This indicates that the Lord is omniscient.

verse.text: And if anyone says anything to you, you shall say, The [note]1[/note]Lord has need of them; [note]2[/note]and immediately he will send them.
verse.note: This indicates that Christ is the Lord of all.
This clause differs from the corresponding clause in [link]Mark 11:3b[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now this took place in order that what was spoken through the prophet might be [xref]b[/xref]fulfilled, saying,
[xref]a[/xref]"Say to the [note]1[/note]daughter of Zion, Behold, your King is coming to you, [xref]b[/xref]meek and mounted on a donkey, and on a colt, a [note]2[/note]foal of a beast of burden."
verse.note: Denoting the people of Jerusalem (cf. [link]Psa. 137:8[/link]; [link]45:12[/link]).
Signifying the humble and lowly state in which the King of the heavenly kingdom was willing to remain.

verse.text: And the disciples went and did as Jesus directed them,
And led the donkey and the colt. And they put their [note]1[/note]garments on them, and He sat upon them.
verse.note: Garments signify the human virtues in people's conduct. The disciples honored the lowly King by putting their garments on the donkey and the colt for Him to ride on, and the crowd honored Him by spreading their garments in the road for Him to pass through ([link]v. 8[/link]).

verse.text: And most of the crowd spread their own [xref]a[/xref]garments in the road, and others cut [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]branches from the trees and spread [i]them[/i] in the road.
verse.note: The branches of the palm tree ([link]John 12:13[/link]), which signify the victorious life ([link]Rev. 7:9[/link]) and the satisfaction of enjoying the rich produce of that life, as typified by the Feast of Tabernacles ([link]Lev. 23:40[/link]; [link]Neh. 8:15[/link]). The crowd used both their garments and the palm tree branches to celebrate the lowly King's coming.

verse.text: And the crowds who went before Him and those who followed cried out, saying, [note]1[/note]Hosanna to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of David! [xref]b[/xref]Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the [xref]c[/xref]highest!
verse.note: A Hebrew expression meaning [i]do save, we pray[/i] ([link]Psa. 118:25[/link]).
The royal title of the lowly King.

verse.text: And when He [xref]a[/xref]entered into Jerusalem, all the city was stirred, saying, Who is this?
And the crowds said, This is the [xref]a[/xref]prophet Jesus from [xref]b[/xref]Nazareth of Galilee.

[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus entered into the temple and cast out all those who were selling and buying in the temple. And He overturned the tables of the [xref]b[/xref]money changers and the seats of those who were selling the [xref]c[/xref]doves,
And He said to them, It is written, [xref]a[/xref]"My house shall be called a house of prayer," but you are making it a [xref]b[/xref]den of robbers.
And the [xref]a[/xref]blind and the lame came to Him in the temple, and He healed them.

But when the chief priests and the scribes saw the wonders that He did and the children who were crying out in the temple and saying, [xref]a[/xref]Hosanna to the Son of David, they were [note]1[/note]indignant.
verse.note: The stubborn chief priests and scribes were indignant, even after they saw the wonders the lowly King performed. Their indignation was due to their pride and jealousy, which blinded them from seeing any vision concerning the heavenly King.

verse.text: And they said to Him, Do you hear what these are saying? And Jesus said to them, Yes. Have you [xref]a[/xref]never read, [xref]b[/xref]"Out of the mouth of [xref]c[/xref]infants and sucklings You have perfected praise"?
And leaving them, He went [xref]a[/xref]out of the city to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Bethany and lodged there.
verse.note: In His last visit to Jerusalem the Lord remained there only during the day for His ministry. Every evening He departed to lodge in Bethany, on the eastern slope of the Mount of Olives ([link]Mark 11:19[/link]; [link]Luke 21:37[/link]), where the house of Mary, Martha, and Lazarus and the house of Simon were ([link]John 11:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:6[/link]). In Jerusalem He was rejected by the leaders of Judaism, but in Bethany He was welcomed by His lovers.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now in the morning as He returned to the city, He became [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]hungry.
verse.note: This signified that the Lord was hungry for fruit from the children of Israel, that God might be satisfied.

verse.text: And seeing a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fig tree on the way, He came to it and found nothing on it except leaves only. And He said to it, May there [note]2[/note]no longer be fruit from you forever! And the fig tree was instantly [note]3[/note]dried up.
verse.note: The fig tree here is a symbol of the nation of Israel ([link]Jer. 24:2[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]8[/link]). This tree was full of leaves but fruitless, signifying that at that time the nation of Israel was full of outward show but had nothing that could satisfy God.
This signifies the curse on the nation of Israel.
From that time the nation of Israel was truly dried up.

verse.text: And when the disciples saw [i]this,[/i] they marveled, saying, How did the fig tree instantly dry up?

And Jesus answered and said to them, Truly I say to you, If you have [xref]a[/xref]faith and do not [xref]b[/xref]doubt, you will not only do what [i]was done[/i] to the fig tree, but even if you say to this [xref]c[/xref]mountain, Be taken up and cast into the sea, it will happen.
And all that you [xref]a[/xref]ask in prayer, if you believe, you will receive.

[xref]a[/xref]And when He came into the temple, the chief priests and elders of the people came to Him as He was [xref]b[/xref]teaching and said, By what authority do You do these things? And [xref]c[/xref]who gave You this authority?
And Jesus answered and said to them, I also will ask you one [note]1[/note]thing, which if you tell Me, I also will tell you by what authority I do these things.
verse.note: Lit., word.

verse.text: The baptism of John, from where did it [i]come,[/i] from [xref]a[/xref]heaven or from men? And they reasoned among themselves, saying, If we say, From heaven, He will say to us, Why then did you not believe him?
But if we say, From men, we fear the crowd, for all hold John as a [xref]a[/xref]prophet.
And they answered Jesus and said, We do [note]1[/note]not know. He too said to them, [note]2[/note]Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
verse.note: This was a lie.

This indicated that the Lord knew that the Jewish leaders would not tell Him what they knew; hence, neither would He tell them what they asked. They lied to the Lord in saying, "We do not know." But the Lord spoke the truth wisely to them, exposing their lie and avoiding their question.

verse.text: But what do you think? A man had two children. And he came to his first son and said, Child, go today and work in the [xref]a[/xref]vineyard.
And he answered and said, I do not want to; yet later he regretted and went.
And he came to the other and said likewise. And he answered and said, I [i]will,[/i] sir; yet he did not go.

Which of the two did the will of the father? They said, The [note]1[/note]first. Jesus said to them, Truly I say to you that the [xref]a[/xref]tax collectors and the [xref]b[/xref]harlots are going into the kingdom of [xref]c[/xref]God before you.
verse.note: In [link]Luke 15:1-2[/link], [link]11-32[/link], the Lord likened the leaders of Judaism to the firstborn son, and the tax collectors and sinners to the second son; but here the Lord likened them in the opposite order. This indicates that the Jews were the firstborn of God ([link]Exo. 4:22[/link]) and had the birthright. However, because of their unbelief the birthright was shifted to the church, which has become God's firstborn ([link]Heb. 12:23[/link]).

verse.text: For John came to you in the [xref]a[/xref]way of [note]1[/note]righteousness, and you did not believe him, but the tax collectors and the harlots believed him. And you, when you saw [i]it,[/i] did not later regret [i]it[/i] to believe him.
verse.note: The Gospel of Matthew, as the book on the kingdom, stresses the matter of righteousness, for the kingdom life is one of strict righteousness, which we must seek ([link]5:20[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]6:33[/link]). John the Baptist came in the way of such righteousness, and the Lord Jesus was willing to be baptized by John to fulfill such righteousness ([link]3:15[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Hear another parable. There was a man, a [note]1[/note]householder, who planted a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]vineyard and put a [xref]c[/xref]hedge around it, and dug a [xref]d[/xref]winepress in it, and built a tower; and he leased it out to [note]1[/note]vinedressers and went [xref]e[/xref]abroad.
verse.note: The householder is God, the vineyard is the city of Jerusalem ([link]Isa. 5:1[/link]), and the vinedressers are the leaders of the Israelites ([link]v. 45[/link]).

verse.text: And when the time [i]to harvest[/i] the fruit drew near, he [xref]a[/xref]sent his [note]1[/note]slaves to the vinedressers to get his fruit.
verse.note: These were the prophets sent by God ([link]2 Chron. 24:19[/link]; [link]36:15[/link]).

verse.text: And the vinedressers took his slaves and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beat one, and [xref]b[/xref]killed another, and [xref]c[/xref]stoned another.
verse.note: This was the persecution suffered by the Old Testament prophets ([link]Jer. 37:15[/link]; [link]Neh. 9:26[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 24:21[/link]).

verse.text: Again, he sent some other slaves, more than the first, and they did likewise to them.
Then later he sent to them his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]son, saying, They will respect my son.
verse.note: This is Christ.

verse.text: But the vinedressers, when they saw the son, said among themselves, [note]1[/note]This is the [xref]a[/xref]heir. Come, let us [xref]b[/xref]kill him and take possession of his inheritance.
verse.note: This statement indicates that the Jewish leaders, wanting to maintain their false position, envied Christ because of His rights.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]took him and cast [i]him[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]out of the vineyard and [xref]c[/xref]killed [i]him.[/i]
verse.note: Christ was killed outside the city of Jerusalem ([link]Heb. 13:12[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore when the master of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those vinedressers?

They said to Him, He will miserably [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]destroy those evil men and will lease the vineyard to [note]2[/note]other vinedressers, who will give the [xref]b[/xref]fruit to him in their seasons.
verse.note: This was fulfilled when the Roman prince Titus and his army destroyed Jerusalem in A.D. 70.
These were the apostles.

verse.text: Jesus said to them, Have you [xref]a[/xref]never read in the Scriptures, [xref]b[/xref]"The [note]1[/note]stone which the [note]1[/note]builders rejected, this has become the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]head of the corner. This was from the Lord, and it is marvelous in our eyes"?
verse.note: The stone is Christ, who is for God's building ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; [link]Zech. 3:9[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:4[/link]), and the builders are the Jewish leaders, who should have been working on God's building.
Christ is not only the foundation stone ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]) and the topstone ([link]Zech. 4:7[/link]) but also the cornerstone.

verse.text: Therefore I say to you that the [note]1[/note]kingdom of [xref]a[/xref]God shall be taken from you and shall be given to a [note]2[/note]nation producing its [xref]b[/xref]fruit.
verse.note: The kingdom of God was already there among the Israelites, but the kingdom of the heavens had only drawn near ([link]3:2[/link]; [link]4:17[/link]). This proves that the kingdom of the heavens is different from the kingdom of God. (See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].)
This is the church.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]he who falls on this [xref]a[/xref]stone shall be broken to pieces; but on [note]2[/note]whomever it falls, it shall [xref]b[/xref]crush him to powder and scatter him like chaff.
verse.note: This is a person who stumbles on Christ; referring in particular to the unbelieving Israelites ([link]Isa. 8:15[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:32[/link]).

These are the nations, the Gentiles, that Christ will smite and break into pieces at His coming back ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]). To the believers Christ is the foundation stone, the One in whom they trust ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]); to the unbelieving Jews He is the stone of stumbling ([link]Isa. 8:14[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:33[/link]); and to the nations He will be the smiting stone.

verse.text: And when the chief priests and the Pharisees heard His parables, they perceived that He was speaking concerning them.
And though they sought to [xref]a[/xref]seize Him, they feared the crowds because they held Him as a [xref]b[/xref]prophet.
And Jesus answered and spoke again in [xref]a[/xref]parables to them, saying,

[xref]a[/xref]The [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of the heavens has become like a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]king who prepared a [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]wedding feast for his [note]2[/note]son.
verse.note: The parable of the vineyard in [link]ch. 21[/link] refers to the Old Testament, in which was the kingdom of God ([link]21:43[/link]), whereas the parable of a wedding feast in this chapter refers to the New Testament, in which is the kingdom of the heavens.[br][br]In the foregoing parable ([link]21:33-46[/link]) the Lord illustrated how the Jews, who were in the kingdom of God, would be punished, and how the kingdom of God would be taken from them and given to the kingdom people. Another parable was needed for Him to illustrate how the kingdom people, who are in the kingdom of the heavens, will be dealt with strictly. Both parables indicate that the kingdom is a serious matter.
The king is God, and the son is Christ.

In the foregoing parable the Old Testament was likened to a vineyard, with the focus mainly on the matter of labor under the law; in this parable the New Testament is likened to a wedding feast, with the focus mainly on the matter of enjoyment under grace.

verse.text: And he sent his [note]1[/note]slaves to call those who had been called to the wedding feast, yet they would not come.
verse.note: These are the first group of New Testament apostles.

verse.text: Again, he sent [note]1[/note]other slaves, saying, Tell those who have been called, Behold, I have prepared my [note]2[/note]dinner: my [note]3[/note]oxen and my [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]fatted cattle have been slain, and all things are ready. Come to the wedding feast.
verse.note: These are the apostles sent later by the Lord.
Primarily the first meal, taken early in the morning, before work.
Both the oxen and the fatted cattle refer to Christ, who was killed so that God's chosen people could enjoy Him as a feast.

verse.text: But they disregarded [i]it[/i] and went off, one to his own field and another to his business,
And the rest took hold of his slaves, [xref]a[/xref]treated [i]them[/i] shamefully, and [xref]b[/xref]killed [i]them.[/i]
And the king became angry, and he sent his [note]1[/note]troops and [xref]a[/xref]destroyed those murderers and burned their city.
verse.note: These were the Roman troops who, under the leadership of Titus, destroyed Jerusalem in A.D. 70.

verse.text: Then he said to his slaves, The wedding feast is ready, but those who have been called were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not worthy.
verse.note: The rejection by the Jews made them unworthy to enjoy the New Testament ([link]Acts 13:46[/link]).

verse.text: Go therefore to the [note]1[/note]crossroads, and as many as you find, call to the wedding feast.
verse.note: Because of the rejection by the Jews, the preaching of the New Testament turned to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:46[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:11[/link]).

verse.text: And those slaves went out into the streets and gathered all whom they found, both evil and good, and the wedding feast was filled with those reclining [i]at table.[/i]
But when the king came in to look at those reclining [i]at table,[/i] he saw there a man who was not [xref]a[/xref]clothed with a [note]1[/note]wedding garment,
verse.note: This wedding garment is typified by the embroidered garment in [link]Psa. 45:14[/link] and is signified by the fine linen in [link]Rev. 19:8[/link] (see note 2 there). This is the surpassing righteousness of the overcoming believers, mentioned in [link]5:20[/link] (see note 1 there). The man not clothed with a wedding garment is saved, because he has come to the wedding feast. He has received Christ as his righteousness that he might be justified before God ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:26[/link]), but he has not lived Christ out as his subjective righteousness ([link]Phil. 3:9[/link]) that he might participate in the enjoyment of the kingdom of the heavens. He has been called to salvation, but he has not been chosen for the enjoyment of the kingdom of the heavens, which is for the overcoming believers only.

verse.text: And he said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Friend, how did you come in here without a wedding garment? And he was speechless.

Then the king said to the [note]1[/note]servants, Bind his feet and hands, and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]cast him out into the outer darkness. In that place there will be the [note]3[/note]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: The servants should refer to the angels (cf. [link]13:41[/link], [link]49[/link]).

To be cast out into the outer darkness is not to perish; it is to be dealt with dispensationally, to be disqualified from participating in the enjoyment of the kingdom during the millennium, for not having lived by Christ an overcoming life. In the millennium the overcoming believers will be with Christ in the bright glory of the kingdom ([link]Col. 3:4[/link]), whereas the defeated believers will suffer discipline in outer darkness (see note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]).
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: For many are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]called but few are [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]chosen.
verse.note: To be called is to receive salvation ([link]Rom. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:1[/link]), whereas to be chosen is to receive a reward. All believers have been called, but few will be chosen to receive a reward.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then the [note]1[/note]Pharisees went and took [xref]b[/xref]counsel how they might ensnare Him in [i]His[/i] [xref]c[/xref]words.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: And they sent to Him their disciples with the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Herodians, saying, Teacher, we know that You are true and that You teach the way of God in truth and [note]2[/note]do not fear anyone, for You do not [note]3[/note]regard the [xref]b[/xref]person of men.
verse.note: The Herodians were those who took sides with King Herod's regime and took part with him in infiltrating Grecian and Roman manners of life into Jewish culture. They sided with the Sadducees but were opposed to the Pharisees. But here they united with the Pharisees to ensnare the Lord Jesus.
Lit., it does not matter to you concerning anyone.
Lit., look into the face of men.

verse.text: Tell us therefore, What do You think? [note]1[/note]Is it lawful to give tribute to [xref]a[/xref]Caesar, or not?
verse.note: This was truly an ensnaring question. Giving tribute to Caesar was opposed by all the Jews. If the Lord Jesus had said that it was lawful to do this, He would have offended all the Jews, whose leaders were the Pharisees. If He had said that it was not lawful, the Herodians, who stood with the Roman government, would have had strong ground to accuse Him.

verse.text: But Jesus, knowing their evil intent, said, Why do you [xref]a[/xref]tempt Me, [note]1[/note]hypocrites?
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Show Me the coin for the tribute. And they brought to Him a [note]2[/note]denarius.
verse.note: The Lord Jesus did not show the Roman coin but asked them to show one to Him. Since they possessed one of the Roman coins, they were caught.
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, Whose is this image and inscription?
They said, Caesar's. Then He said to them, Render then the [note]1[/note]things that are Caesar's [xref]a[/xref]to Caesar and the [note]2[/note]things that are God's to God.
verse.note: This is to pay tribute to Caesar according to his governmental regulations.
This is to pay the half-shekel to God according to [link]Exo. 30:11-16[/link], and to offer all the tithes to God according to the law of God.

verse.text: And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they marveled. And they left Him and went away.
[xref]a[/xref]On that day some [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sadducees, who say that there is no resurrection, came to Him and questioned Him,
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: Saying, Teacher, Moses said, If anyone dies and does not have children, his brother as next of kin shall marry his [xref]a[/xref]wife and raise up seed to his brother.
Now there were seven brothers with us. And the first married and died, and having no seed, he left his wife to his brother;
Likewise also the second and the third until the seventh.
And last of all the woman died.
In the resurrection, then, whose wife will she be of the seven? For they all had her.
And Jesus answered and said to them, You err, [xref]a[/xref]not [note]1[/note]knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God.
verse.note: Knowing the Scriptures is one thing; knowing the power of God is another. We need to know both. The Scriptures here refer to the Old Testament verses that concern the matter of resurrection, and the power of God refers to the power of resurrection.

verse.text: For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven.
But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not [xref]a[/xref]read that which was spoken to you by God, saying,
[xref]a[/xref]"I am the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob"? He is not the God of the dead, but of the [note]1[/note]living.
verse.note: As God is the God of the living and is called "the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob," so the dead Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob will be resurrected. This is the way the Lord Jesus expounded the Scriptures not only according to the letter but also according to the life and power implied within them.

verse.text: And when the crowds heard [i]this,[/i] they were [xref]a[/xref]astounded at His teaching.
[xref]a[/xref]But the Pharisees, when they heard that He had muzzled the Sadducees, gathered themselves together.
And one of them, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lawyer, asked [i]Him[/i] a question, [xref]b[/xref]testing Him,
verse.note: One who was knowledgeable in the law of Moses, a professional interpreter of the law of the Old Testament.

verse.text: Teacher, which is the great commandment in the law?
And He said to him, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall [xref]b[/xref]love the Lord your God [note]1[/note]with all your heart and [note]1[/note]with all your soul and [note]1[/note]with all your mind."
verse.note: Lit., in.

verse.text: This is the great and first commandment.
And the second is like it: [xref]a[/xref]"You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
On these [note]1[/note]two commandments hang all [xref]a[/xref]the Law and the Prophets.
verse.note: Both commandments, the commandment to love God and the commandment to love man, are a matter of love. Love is the spirit of God's commandments.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now while the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus questioned them,
Saying, What do you think concerning the [note]1[/note]Christ? Whose son is He? They said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]David's.
verse.note: As portrayed in [link]21:23-22:46[/link], during His last visit to Jerusalem, the center of Judaism, Christ was surrounded by the chief priests, elders, Pharisees, Herodians, and Sadducees, along with a lawyer, all of whom endeavored to ensnare Him by asking puzzling and insidious questions. First, the chief priests, representing the authority of the Jewish religion, and the elders, representing the authority of the Jewish people, asked Him concerning His authority ([link]21:23[/link]). Their question was according to their religious concept. Second, the Pharisees, the fundamentalists, and the Herodians, who were zealous in politics, asked Him a question related to politics. Third, the Sadducees, the modernists, questioned Him concerning fundamental belief. Fourth, a self-approved lawyer asked Him a question concerning the law. After answering all their questions wisely, He asked them a question concerning the Christ. This is the question of questions. Their questions were related to religion, politics, belief, and the law. His question was concerning the Christ, who is the center of all things. They knew religion, politics, belief, and the law, but they paid no attention to Christ. Hence, He asked them, "What do you think concerning the Christ?" This question of questions must be answered by everyone.

verse.text: He said to them, How then does David in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit call Him Lord, saying,
verse.note: Christ can be known by us only in our spirit through God's revelation ([link]Eph. 3:5[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]"The Lord said to my Lord, Sit at My right hand until I put Your enemies [xref]b[/xref]underneath Your feet"?
If then David calls Him [note]1[/note]Lord, how is He his [note]1[/note]son?
verse.note: Christ is God; in His divinity He is the Lord of David. He is also a man; in His humanity He is the Son of David. The Pharisees had only half the scriptural knowledge concerning Christ's person, i.e., that He was the Son of David according to His humanity. They did not have the other half, i.e., that He was the Son of God according to His divinity.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no one was able to answer Him a word, nor did anyone from that day dare to question Him anymore.
verse.note: Christ's question of questions concerning His wonderful person muzzled the mouths of all His opposers.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then Jesus spoke to the crowds and to His disciples,
Saying, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scribes and the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Pharisees have seated themselves in [xref]c[/xref]Moses' seat;
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: Therefore all that they tell you, [xref]a[/xref]do and keep; but do not do according to their [xref]b[/xref]works, for they say [i]things[/i] and do not do [i]them.[/i]
And they bind burdens, [xref]a[/xref]heavy and hard to bear, and lay them on men's shoulders; but they themselves will not move them with their finger.

And all their works they do to be [xref]a[/xref]seen by men, for they broaden their [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]phylacteries and enlarge the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fringes [i]of their garments,[/i]
verse.note: Phylacteries are small leather boxes containing parts of the law written on parchment. According to [link]Deut. 6:8[/link] and [link]11:18[/link], they were worn on the forehead as a frontlet and on the left arm. The scribes and the Pharisees broadened them and considered them a charm.

The law required the Israelites to make fringes on the borders of their garments with a band of blue. The fringes signified that their conduct (typified by the garment) was regulated by the heavenly rule (indicated by the band of blue), and they were to be a reminder to them to keep God's commandments ([link]Num. 15:38-39[/link]). The scribes and Pharisees enlarged the fringes, pretending that they were keeping God's commandments and were being regulated by them to a surpassing degree.

verse.text: And they love the [xref]a[/xref]place of honor at the dinners and the chief seats in the synagogues
And the [xref]a[/xref]salutations in the marketplaces and to be called by men, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Rabbi.
verse.note: A title of honor meaning [i]teacher, master.[/i]

verse.text: But you, do not be called Rabbi, for [note]1[/note]One is your [xref]a[/xref]Teacher, and you are all [xref]b[/xref]brothers.
verse.note: Christ alone is our Teacher and Master.

verse.text: And do not call [i]anyone[/i] on earth your father, for [note]1[/note]One is your [xref]a[/xref]Father, [note]2[/note]He who is in the heavens.
verse.note: God alone is our Father.
Lit., the Heavenly.

verse.text: Neither be called [note]1[/note]instructors, because [note]2[/note]One is your Instructor, the Christ.
verse.note: Or, guides, teachers, directors.
Christ alone is our Instructor, Guide, Teacher, and Director.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]greatest among you shall be your servant.
And he who will [xref]a[/xref]exalt himself shall be humbled, and he who will [xref]b[/xref]humble himself shall be exalted.

But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, [note]1[/note]hypocrites! For you [xref]a[/xref]close off the kingdom of the heavens in the face of men; for you do [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]not enter in yourselves, nor do you allow those who are entering to enter.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]. So throughout this chapter.
In today's Christianity some are just like this.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you [xref]a[/xref]devour the widows' houses, even while for a pretense you make long prayers. For this reason you shall receive greater [note]2[/note]judgment.
verse.note: This verse is not found in the earliest MSS.
Or, condemnation.

verse.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you go about the sea and the dry land to make one [xref]a[/xref]proselyte; and when he becomes [i]one,[/i] you make him twice as much a [xref]b[/xref]son of [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Gehenna as yourselves.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]. So in [link]v. 33[/link].

verse.text: Woe to you, [xref]a[/xref]blind [xref]b[/xref]guides, who say, Whoever [xref]c[/xref]swears by the temple, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the gold of the temple, [note]1[/note]he is bound.
verse.note: Lit., he owes. So in [link]v. 18[/link].

verse.text: Fools and blind men, which is greater, the gold or the temple which [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctifies the gold?
verse.note: To make the gold holy positionally by changing its position from a common place to a holy place. See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].

verse.text: And, Whoever swears by the altar, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the [xref]a[/xref]gift which is upon it, he is bound.
Blind men, which is greater, the gift or the altar which [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctifies the gift?
verse.note: This too was a positional sanctification, not a dispositional one, and was accomplished by changing the gift's location from a common place to a holy place. See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].

verse.text: Therefore he who swears by the altar swears by it and by all the things upon it;
And he who swears by the temple swears by it and by Him who [xref]a[/xref]dwells in it;
And he who swears by [xref]a[/xref]heaven swears by the [xref]b[/xref]throne of God and by Him who sits upon it.

Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For [xref]a[/xref]you [xref]b[/xref]give a tenth of the mint and the anise and the cummin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law — [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]justice and [xref]d[/xref]mercy and faithfulness. But these you should have done and [note]2[/note]not neglected the others.
verse.note: Or, judgment.
Although the Lord stressed the weightier matters, He charged us not to neglect the lighter ones.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Blind guides, who strain out the gnat but swallow the camel!
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For [xref]a[/xref]you [xref]b[/xref]cleanse the outside of the cup and the dish, but inwardly they are full of extortion and self-indulgence.
Blind Pharisee, cleanse first the inside of the cup and the dish so that their outside also may become clean.

Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you resemble [xref]a[/xref]whitewashed [xref]b[/xref]graves, which outwardly appear beautiful but inwardly are full of dead men's [xref]c[/xref]bones and all [xref]d[/xref]uncleanness.
So you also outwardly appear righteous to men, but inwardly you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you [xref]a[/xref]build up the graves of the prophets and adorn the tombs of the righteous,
And say, If we had been [i]there[/i] in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.
So then you testify against yourselves that you are the sons of those who [xref]a[/xref]murdered the prophets.
And you, [xref]a[/xref]fill up the measure of your fathers!
Serpents! Brood of [xref]a[/xref]vipers! How shall you escape the judgment of [xref]b[/xref]Gehenna?

[xref]a[/xref]Therefore, behold, I [xref]b[/xref]send to you [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]prophets and wise men and [xref]d[/xref]scribes. Some of them you will [xref]e[/xref]kill and crucify, and some of them you will [xref]f[/xref]scourge in your synagogues and [xref]g[/xref]persecute from [xref]h[/xref]city to city,
verse.note: The New Testament apostles sent out by the Lord.

verse.text: So that upon you may come all the righteous [xref]a[/xref]blood shed on the earth, from the [xref]b[/xref]blood of righteous Abel to the blood of [xref]c[/xref]Zachariah, son of Barachiah, whom you murdered between the temple and the altar.
Truly I say to you, [note]1[/note]All these things shall come upon this [xref]a[/xref]generation.
verse.note: Referring to all the sins through which the blood of the righteous was shed on the earth.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and [xref]b[/xref]stones those who are sent to her! How often [note]1[/note]I desired to gather your [xref]c[/xref]children together, the way a hen gathers her brood under her [xref]d[/xref]wings, and you would not!
verse.note: It was always God Himself who cared for Jerusalem, as a bird flutters over her young ([link]Isa. 31:5[/link]; [link]Deut. 32:11-12[/link]). Hence, when the Lord Jesus said, "I desired to gather your children together, the way a hen gathers her brood under her wings," He indicated that He was God Himself.

verse.text: Behold, your [note]1[/note]house is left to you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]desolate.
verse.note: Since [i]house[/i] here is singular, it must denote the house of God, which was the temple ([link]21:12-13[/link]). It had been the house of God, but now it was called "your house" because the Jews had made it a den of robbers ([link]21:13[/link]).
This prophecy corresponds with that in [link]24:2[/link], which was fulfilled when Titus and the Roman army destroyed Jerusalem in A.D. 70.

verse.text: For I say to you, You shall by no means see Me from now on until you say, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is He who [note]1[/note]comes in the name of the Lord.
verse.note: This is the Lord's second coming, when all the remnant of Israel will turn and will believe in Him and be saved ([link]Rom. 11:23[/link], [link]26[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Jesus came out [note]1[/note]from the [note]2[/note]temple and was going away, and His disciples came to [i]Him[/i] to show Him the buildings of the [note]2[/note]temple.
verse.note: The Lord came out from the temple, indicating that He had left the temple. This was to fulfill His word in [link]23:38[/link], concerning His leaving the temple to the rejecting Jews as their house of desolation. This was equivalent to God's glory leaving the temple in the ancient time ([link]Ezek. 10:18[/link]).
The entire precincts of the temple.

verse.text: But He answered and said to them, Do you not see all these things? Truly I say to you, There shall by [xref]a[/xref]no means be left here a stone upon a stone, which shall not be [note]1[/note]thrown down.
verse.note: This was fulfilled in A.D. 70 when Titus and the Roman army destroyed Jerusalem.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as He sat on the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Mount of Olives, the disciples came to Him privately, saying, Tell us, [note]2[/note]When will these things be? And what will be the [xref]c[/xref]sign of Your [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]coming and of the [xref]e[/xref]consummation of the age?
verse.note: To receive the vision of the Lord's prophecy concerning this age, we need to climb the high mountain to enter into His presence.

The disciples' question concerned three matters: (1) the time when "these things" would take place, including not only the destruction of the temple ([link]v. 2[/link]) but also the things mentioned in [link]23:32-39[/link]; (2) the sign of Christ's coming; and (3) the sign of the consummation of the age. The Lord's word from [link]24:4-25:46[/link] answered the disciples' question concerning these three matters.

Gk. [i]parousia,[/i] which means [i]presence.[/i] Christ's coming will be His presence with His people. This presence (parousia) will begin with the rapture of the man-child ([link]Rev. 12:5[/link]) and the rapture of the firstfruits ([link]Rev. 14:1-4[/link]) and will end with His appearing on the earth with the saints. During the period of His parousia there will be the great tribulation ([link]v. 21[/link]; [link]Rev. 9:1-21[/link]; [link]11:14[/link]; [link]16:1-21[/link]), which will begin with supernatural calamities ([link]Rev. 6:12-17[/link]; [link]8:7-12[/link]); Christ's descending to the air ([link]Rev. 14:14[/link]); the rapture of the majority of the believers to the air ([link]1 Thes. 4:15-17[/link]); the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]); and the marriage of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link]). (See "The Chart of the Seventy Weeks and the Coming of Christ, with the Rapture of the Saints").

verse.text: And Jesus [note]1[/note]answered and said to them, [note]2[/note]See that no one [xref]a[/xref]leads you astray.
verse.note: The Lord's answer has three sections: the first section ([link]vv. 4-31[/link]) concerns the Jews, who are the chosen; the second ([link]v. 32-25:30[/link]) concerns the church; and the third ([link]25:31-46[/link]) concerns the Gentiles (the nations). The first section, concerning the Jews, should be interpreted literally, whereas the second section, concerning the church, should be interpreted spiritually, because it is spoken in parables for the reason given in [link]13:11-13[/link]. For instance, the winter in [link]v. 20[/link] is the actual winter, but the summer in [link]v. 32[/link] is a symbol signifying the time of restoration. The third section, concerning the Gentiles, also should be interpreted literally.

Some aspects of the prophecy in [link]vv. 4-14[/link] have been fulfilled, and some are in the process of being fulfilled. At the time of the great tribulation, which will be the consummation, the end, of this age, the prophecy will be fully fulfilled.

verse.text: For many will come in My name, saying, I am the Christ, and they will lead many astray.
And you will be hearing of [note]1[/note]wars and rumors of wars. See that you are not alarmed, for it must happen; but the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]end is not yet.
verse.note: [i]Wars[/i] here denotes all the wars from the first century to the present. They are signified by the red horse of the second seal in [link]Rev. 6:3-4[/link].

[i]The end[/i] denotes the consummation of this age ([link]v. 3[/link]; [link]Dan. 12:4[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]6-7[/link]), which will be the three and a half years of the great tribulation. Although [link]vv. 6-9[/link] and [link]14[/link] are in the section concerning Israel, the tribulations and the preaching of the gospel mentioned in these verses take place generally, in the whole world, from the time of Christ's ascension to the end of this age. [link]Verse 15[/link], immediately following [link]v. 14[/link], speaks concerning the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]v. 21[/link]), which is the time when Antichrist will set up his image in the temple of God, which image will thereby become the abomination of desolation.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]nation will rise up [xref]a[/xref]against nation, and [note]1[/note]kingdom against kingdom; and there will be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]famines and [note]3[/note]earthquakes in various places.
verse.note: [i]Nation[/i] denotes the people, the Gentiles; [i]kingdom[/i] denotes an empire.
Famines issue mainly from war. According to history, war has often brought famine, signified by the black horse of the third seal in [link]Rev. 6:5-6[/link].

Since Christ's ascension, earthquakes have been occurring throughout all the centuries and will be intensified at the end of this age ([link]Rev. 6:12[/link]; [link]8:5[/link]; [link]11:13[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]16:18[/link]).

verse.text: All these things are the beginning of [note]1[/note]birth pangs.
verse.note: Birth pangs are for the bringing forth of a child. In His New Testament economy, God's desire and purpose are to bring forth many sons ([link]Gal. 3:26[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:10[/link]) as His expression. Hence, [i]birth pangs[/i] here refers to all the tribulations in the New Testament age, including wars, famines, earthquakes, afflictions, and persecutions, as mentioned in [link]vv. 6-9[/link] and [link]21[/link]. The birth pangs here are suffered only by the New Testament believers for the Lord's sake, whereas the travailing in birth in [link]Rev. 12:2[/link] refers to all the travailings suffered throughout the generations by God's people in both the Old Testament and the New Testament. These tribulations, along with the preaching of the gospel ([link]v. 14[/link]), are used by God to produce His many sons so that He can constitute the church in this age, accomplish the kingdom in the coming age, and produce the New Jerusalem in eternity as the ultimate consummation of the church and the kingdom that He may have an eternal expression in eternity future. [link]Galatians 4:19[/link] and [link]Rev. 12:2[/link] and [link]5[/link] confirm this viewpoint.

verse.text: Then they will deliver [note]1[/note]you up to [xref]a[/xref]tribulation and will [xref]b[/xref]kill you, and you will be [xref]c[/xref]hated by all the nations because of My name.
verse.note: Referring to the Jewish disciples, who were the prophets and wise men sent to the Jews ([link]23:34[/link]).

verse.text: And at that time many will be stumbled and will deliver up one another and will hate one another.
And many [xref]a[/xref]false prophets will arise and will lead many astray.
And because lawlessness will be multiplied, the [xref]a[/xref]love of the many will grow cold.
But he who has [xref]a[/xref]endured to the end, this one shall be [note]1[/note]saved.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gospel of the kingdom will be preached in the whole inhabited earth for a [note]2[/note]testimony to all the nations, and then the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]end will come.
verse.note: The gospel of the kingdom, which includes the gospel of grace ([link]Acts 20:24[/link]), brings people not only into God's salvation but also into the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Rev. 1:9[/link]). The gospel of grace emphasizes forgiveness of sin, God's redemption, and eternal life, whereas the gospel of the kingdom emphasizes the heavenly ruling of God and the authority of the Lord. This gospel of the kingdom will be preached in the whole earth for a testimony to all the nations before the end of this age. Hence, that preaching, signified by the white horse of the first seal in [link]Rev. 6:1-2[/link], will be a sign of the consummation of this age.
The gospel of the kingdom is a testimony to all the nations (Gentiles). This testimony must spread to the whole earth before the end of this age, the time of the great tribulation.
See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Therefore when you see the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]abomination of [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]desolation, which was spoken of through [xref]d[/xref]Daniel the prophet, standing in the [note]4[/note]Holy Place (let him who reads [xref]e[/xref]understand),
verse.note: No one knows the length of time spanning the events mentioned in [link]vv. 4-14[/link]. But the prophecy in [link]vv. 15-31[/link], concerning the remnant of the Jews, definitely will be fulfilled in the last three and a half years of this age, the time of the great tribulation, the second half of the last week prophesied in [link]Dan. 9:27[/link], which will begin with the setting up of Antichrist's image (the idol) in the temple ([link]v. 15[/link]) and will end with Christ's open coming ([link]v. 30[/link]).

[i]Abomination[/i] denotes an idol ([link]Deut. 29:17[/link], ASV). Here it refers to Antichrist's image, which will be set up as an idol in the temple of God ([link]Rev. 13:14-15[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:4[/link]) at the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]v. 21[/link]). Hence, this idol will be another sign of the consummation of this age.

Lit., causing desolation, desolating. The abomination, the image of Antichrist, will cause desolation. Antichrist is called "the destroyer" (Apollyon — [link]Rev. 9:11[/link]); he will do much destroying ([link]Dan. 8:13[/link], [link]23-25[/link]; [link]9:27[/link]).
[i]Holy Place[/i] here refers to the sanctuaries in God's temple ([link]Psa. 68:35[/link]; [link]Ezek. 7:24[/link]; [link]21:2[/link]).

verse.text: Then let those in Judea flee to the mountains;
Let him who is on the [xref]a[/xref]housetop not come down to take the things out of his house;
And let him who is in the field not turn back to take his garment.
But woe to those who are [note]1[/note]pregnant and to those who are nursing [i]babies[/i] in those days.
verse.note: For those who are pregnant or are nursing babies, it will be difficult to escape.

verse.text: And pray that your flight may not be in [note]1[/note]winter, nor on a [note]2[/note]Sabbath,
verse.note: Winter is a time when escape is difficult.

On the Sabbath one was allowed to walk only a short distance ([link]Acts 1:12[/link]), a distance not adequate for escaping. The mentioning of the Sabbath here indicates that the Jews would still keep the Sabbath after the restoration of the nation of Israel. The disciples, the audience for the Lord's word here, had a twofold status, one as representatives of the remnant of the Jews and the other as the New Testament believers, who constitute the church. In the section of the Lord's word that concerns the Jews ([link]vv. 4-31[/link]), the disciples represent the remnant of the Jews, whereas in the section that concerns the church ([link]24:32-25:30[/link]), they represent the New Testament believers. In the four Gospels, in matters regarding outward circumstances, the Lord treated His disciples as Jews, but in matters concerning spirit and life, He considered them New Testament believers.

verse.text: For at that time there will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]great tribulation, such as has not occurred from the beginning of the world until now, nor shall by any means ever occur.
