verse.note: The great tribulation will occur in the last three and a half years of this age. See note [link]2[sup]4[/sup] in Rev. 11[/link]. The great tribulation spoken of here will have Jerusalem as its center and Judea as its circumference, whereas the trial mentioned in [link]Rev. 3:10[/link] will have Rome as its center and the whole inhabited earth as its circumference.

verse.text: And unless those days had been cut [note]1[/note]short, no flesh would be saved; but on account of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]chosen, those days will be cut short.
verse.note: The great tribulation will last only three and a half years. See note [link]2[sup]4[/sup] in Rev. 11[/link].
[i]The chosen[/i] here refers to the Jews, God's chosen people ([link]Rom. 11:28[/link]). So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: At that time if anyone says to you, Behold, [xref]a[/xref]here is the [note]1[/note]Christ! or, Here! do not believe [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The Jews rejected Jesus as their Messiah and are expecting a Messiah who is yet to come. They need to be warned that Messiah, the Christ, will not arise here or there on earth but will descend from heaven on the cloud.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]false Christs and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]false prophets will arise and will [note]3[/note]show great [xref]c[/xref]signs and wonders so as to lead astray, if possible, even the [xref]d[/xref]chosen.
verse.note: Antichrist will be the last of the false Christs and will work signs and lying wonders with the power of Satan in order to deceive the perishing ([link]2 Thes. 2:3[/link], [link]9-10[/link]).

[i]Another beast[/i] in [link]Rev. 13:11[/link] denotes the last of the false prophets ([link]Rev. 19:20[/link]), who will do great signs to deceive those who dwell on earth ([link]Rev. 13:13-14[/link]).
Lit., give.

verse.text: Behold, I have told you beforehand.
[xref]a[/xref]Therefore if they say to you, Behold, He is in the [note]1[/note]wilderness, do not go forth; Behold, [i]He is[/i] in the [note]2[/note]inner rooms, do not believe [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The wilderness is where a person might go in order to separate himself from the world. His doing this might easily cause people to wonder whether he is the Messiah, as happened in the case of John the Baptist ([link]3:1[/link]; [link]John 1:19-20[/link]).
Or, private rooms; a place where a person can make himself appear mystical so as to charm people.

verse.text: For just as the [note]1[/note]lightning comes forth from the east and shines to the west, so will the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]coming of the Son of Man be.
verse.note: The second coming of Christ has two aspects: one is the secret aspect, related to His watchful believers; the other is the open aspect, related to the unbelieving Jews and Gentiles. The lightning here signifies the open aspect, which will take place after the great tribulation ([link]vv. 29-30[/link]), whereas the thief's coming in [link]v. 43[/link] signifies the secret aspect, which will occur before the great tribulation. Lightning may be considered as being concealed in a cloud, waiting for an opportunity to flash forth. In a similar way, Christ will be clothed with a cloud ([link]Rev. 10:1[/link]) in the air for a time and then will suddenly appear, like a flash of lightning striking the earth. Hence, the Lord's coming like a flash of lightning will be a sign of the end of the Lord's parousia (see note [link]3[sup]3[/sup][/link]). This implies also that the Lord is like electricity.
See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup][/link]. So in [link]vv. 37[/link] and [link]39[/link].

verse.text: Wherever the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]corpse is, there will the [note]1[/note]vultures be gathered together.
verse.note: Taken in context, [link]vv. 15[/link] and [link]21[/link] imply that at the end of this age Antichrist will be the cause of the great tribulation. It is he who will need to be judged and destroyed. All people in Adam are dead ([link]1 Cor. 15:22[/link]); thus, the evil Antichrist, who with his evil armies will war against the Lord at Armageddon ([link]Rev. 19:17-21[/link]), is in the eyes of the Lord a stinking corpse, good for the vultures' appetite. Furthermore, in the Scriptures both the Lord and those who trust in Him are likened to an eagle ([link]Exo. 19:4[/link]; [link]Deut. 32:11[/link]; [link]Isa. 40:31[/link]), and the swift, destroying armies are likened to flying eagles ([link]Deut. 28:49[/link]; [link]Hosea 8:1[/link]). Hence, the vultures here, being predatory birds of the eagle kind, refer undoubtedly to Christ and His overcomers, who will come as a swift, flying army to war against Antichrist and his armies and destroy them at Armageddon, thus executing God's judgment upon them. This indicates not only that at His appearing, Christ with His overcoming saints will appear in the place where Antichrist is with his armies, but also that Christ with His overcomers will appear swiftly from the air like vultures. This corresponds with the flash of lightning in the foregoing verse.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And immediately [note]1[/note]after the tribulation of those days, the [note]2[/note]sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
verse.note: This is strong proof that the open coming of Christ will take place after the great tribulation ([link]v. 21[/link]).

This supernatural calamity will occur in heaven after the great tribulation, at the close of the end of this age (see note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 6[/link]). This differs from the calamities of the sixth seal and the fourth trumpet ([link]Rev. 6:12-13[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]), which will occur at the beginning of the great tribulation.

verse.text: And at that time the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and then all the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]tribes of the [note]2[/note]land will [note]3[/note]mourn, and they will see the [xref]c[/xref]Son of Man coming [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]on the clouds of heaven with [note]5[/note]power and great glory.
verse.note: We have no way of knowing what this sign is. However, it must be supernatural and clearly visible (perhaps like the lightning in [link]v. 27[/link]), appearing in heaven.

The tribes here are the tribes of the nation of Israel, and the land is the Holy Land. At the Lord's appearing, all the tribes of Israel will repent and mourn ([link]Zech. 12:10-14[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]).
Lit., beat the breast.

By this time the Lord will no longer be in the cloud but on the cloud, appearing to the people on earth. This is the open aspect of His second coming. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 10[/link] and note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 14[/link].

In Christ's first coming He manifested His authority in acts such as His casting out of demons and His healing of diseases ([link]Mark 6:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 8:8-9[/link]), to vindicate Himself as the heavenly King; whereas in His second coming He will exercise His power to execute God's judgment, to destroy Antichrist and his armies, and to bind Satan, for the establishing of His kingdom on earth.

verse.text: And He will send His angels with a loud trumpet call, and they will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gather His [xref]b[/xref]chosen together from the [xref]c[/xref]four winds, from one end of the [xref]d[/xref]heavens to the [i]other[/i] end.
verse.note: After the great tribulation, at His coming back to earth, the Lord will gather together to the Holy Land the scattered Jews from all parts of the earth. This will be the fulfillment not only of the Lord's word in [link]23:37[/link] but also of God's promise in the Old Testament (see reference 31a).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]But learn the parable from the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fig tree: As soon as its branch has [note]3[/note]become tender and [note]4[/note]puts forth its leaves, you know that the [note]5[/note]summer is near.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] indicates that [link]v. 32[/link] begins another section. This section, [link]24:32-25:30[/link], concerns the church.

The fig tree, signifying the nation of Israel, was cursed in [link]21:19[/link] (see notes there). It passed through a long winter, from the first century A.D. to 1948, when Israel was restored as a nation. At that time its branch became tender and put forth its leaves. To the believers this fig tree is a sign of the end of this age.
The branch's becoming tender signifies that life has come back.
The putting forth of leaves signifies engaging in outward activities.

Winter signifies the time of being dried up ([link]21:19[/link]), the time of tribulation ([link]vv. 7-21[/link]); summer signifies the age of the (restored) kingdom ([link]Luke 21:30-31[/link]), which will begin at the Lord's second coming.

verse.text: So also you, when you see [note]1[/note]all these things, know that [note]2[/note]it is near, at the doors.
verse.note: [i]All these things[/i] refers to the things predicted in [link]vv. 7-32[/link].
[i]It[/i] refers to the restoration of the kingdom of Israel ([link]Acts 1:6[/link]), signified by the summer in [link]v. 32[/link].

verse.text: Truly I say to you that this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]generation shall by no means pass away until all these things happen.
verse.note: [i]Generation[/i] here does not refer to a generation defined according to an age or a person, like the generations mentioned in [link]1:17[/link]; it refers to a generation defined by the moral condition of the people, like the generations in [link]11:16[/link]; [link]12:39[/link], [link]41-42[/link], [link]45[/link]; and [link]Prov. 30:11-14[/link].

verse.text: Heaven and earth will [xref]a[/xref]pass away, but My [xref]b[/xref]words shall by no means pass away.
But concerning that [xref]a[/xref]day and hour, no one knows, not even the angels of the heavens nor the [note]1[/note]Son, but the Father only.
verse.note: The Son, standing in the position of the Son of Man ([link]v. 37[/link]), does not know the day and hour of His coming back.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For just as the [note]1[/note]days of Noah were, so will the [xref]b[/xref]coming of the Son of Man be.
verse.note: The Lord's coming (parousia) will be like the [i]days[/i] of Noah. This indicates that when the Lord's parousia is about to come, it will be like the days of Noah; that is, the situation before the Lord's coming will be like that in the days of Noah.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For as they were in those days before the flood, [note]2[/note]eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day in which [xref]a[/xref]Noah entered into the ark,
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that this verse is the explanation of why and how the Lord's parousia will be like the days of Noah. In the days of Noah the following conditions existed: (1) people were befuddled by eating, drinking, marrying, and giving in marriage, and (2) they did not know that judgment was coming, until the flood came and took them away. When the Lord's parousia is about to come, people will likewise be befuddled by the necessities of this life and will not know that God's judgment (signified by the flood) will come upon them by the Lord's appearing. The believers, however, should be de-drugged and should soberly know that Christ is coming to execute God's judgment upon this corrupted world.

In the beginning, eating, drinking, and marriage were ordained by God for man's existence. But because of man's lust Satan utilizes these necessities of human life to occupy man and keep him from God's interest. At the end of this age, near the coming of the Lord's parousia, this kind of situation will be intensified.

verse.text: And they did not know [i]that judgment was coming[/i] until the flood came and took all away, so also will the [xref]a[/xref]coming of the Son of Man be.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]At that time two [note]2[/note]men will be [note]3[/note]in the field; one is [note]4[/note]taken and one is left.
verse.note: [i]At that time[/i] indicates that while the worldly people are befuddled by the material things and have no sense of the coming judgment, some of the sober and watchful believers will be taken. To the befuddled and senseless people, this should be a sign of Christ's coming.
These men must be brothers in Christ.

Both [i]in the field[/i] and [i]grinding[/i] signify working for a living. Although the believers should not be befuddled by the necessities of this life, they need to work for a living. Any thought of giving up proper work by which one earns a living is another extreme of Satan's tactics.
This is to be raptured before the great tribulation. This rapture is a sign of the Lord's coming (parousia) and a sign to the Jews.

verse.text: Two [note]1[/note]women will be [note]2[/note]grinding at the mill; one is [note]3[/note]taken and one is left.
verse.note: These women must be sisters in the Lord.
See note [link]40[sup]3[/sup][/link].
See note [link]40[sup]4[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Watch [xref]b[/xref]therefore, for you do not know on what day [note]1[/note]your Lord comes.
verse.note: Both [i]watch therefore[/i] and [i]your Lord[/i] prove that the two men and two women in [link]vv. 40[/link] and [link]41[/link] are saved believers. The Lord would not charge unsaved people to watch, nor is He the Lord of the unsaved.

verse.text: But know this, that if the [note]1[/note]householder had known in which watch the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]thief was coming, he would have watched and would not have allowed his [note]1[/note]house to be broken into.
verse.note: [i]Householder[/i] refers to the believer, and [i]house[/i] to the conduct and work that a believer has built up in his Christian life.

A thief comes at an unknown time to steal precious things. The Lord will come secretly, as a thief, to those who love Him and will take them away as His treasures. Hence, we should watch ([link]v. 42[/link]).

verse.text: For this reason you also be [xref]a[/xref]ready, because at an hour when you do not expect [i]it,[/i] the Son of Man is [note]1[/note]coming.
verse.note: This is the Lord's secret coming to the watchful overcomers.

verse.text: Who then is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faithful and [note]1[/note]prudent slave, whom the master has set over his [note]2[/note]household to [note]3[/note]give them food at the proper time?
verse.note: Faithfulness is shown toward the Lord, whereas prudence is exercised toward the believers. Watchfulness is for being raptured into the Lord's presence ([link]v. 42[/link]); faithfulness is for reigning in the kingdom ([link]v. 47[/link]).
[i]Household[/i] refers to the believers ([link]Eph. 2:19[/link]), who constitute the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]).
[i]Give them food[/i] refers to ministering the word of God and Christ as the life supply to the believers in the church.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Blessed is that slave whom his master, when he comes, will find so doing.
verse.note: Here to be blessed is to be rewarded with the authority to rule in the manifestation of the kingdom.

verse.text: Truly I say to you that he will [xref]a[/xref]set him [note]1[/note]over all his possessions.
verse.note: In the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, the Lord will set the faithful slave over all His possessions. This will be a reward to him.

verse.text: But if that [note]1[/note]evil slave says in his heart, My master [xref]a[/xref]delays,
verse.note: The evil slave is a saved believer, as seen in the fact that (1) he was appointed by the Lord ([link]v. 45[/link]), (2) he called the Lord "my Master," and (3) he believed that the Lord was coming.

verse.text: And begins to [note]1[/note]beat his fellow slaves and [note]2[/note]eats and drinks with the [xref]a[/xref]drunken,
verse.note: This is to mistreat fellow believers.
This is to keep company with worldly people, who are drunk with worldly things.

verse.text: The master of that slave will come on a [xref]a[/xref]day when he does not expect [i]him[/i] and at an hour which he does not know,

And will [note]1[/note]cut him asunder and appoint his [note]2[/note]portion with the [note]3[/note]hypocrites. In that place there will be the [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: Referring to being cut off from the glorious Christ, from the glory of His kingdom, and from His glorious presence in His kingdom, unable to participate in Christ and the glory of His kingdom in the manifestation of the kingdom, which the faithful slaves will enjoy ([link]v. 45[/link]; [link]25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). This corresponds with [i]cast out[/i]...into the outer darkness in the conclusion of the parable of the talents ([link]25:14-30[/link]), which completes this section, [link]vv. 45-51[/link].
This is not to perish eternally but to be chastened dispensationally. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: At that time the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of the heavens will be likened to [note]2[/note]ten [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]virgins, who took their [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]lamps and [note]5[/note]went forth to [xref]d[/xref]meet the [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]bridegroom.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 5[/link] and notes [link chapter="13"]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].

Ten is the major part of twelve ([link]Gen. 42:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Kings 11:30-31[/link]; [link]Matt. 20:24[/link]). Hence, the ten virgins represent the majority of the believers, who will have died before the Lord's coming. The two men or two women in [link]24:40-41[/link] represent the remaining believers, who will live until the Lord's coming.

Virgins signify believers viewed from the aspect of life ([link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]). Believers, who are the kingdom people, are like chaste virgins. As virgins they bear the Lord's testimony (the lamp) in the dark age and are going out of the world to meet the Lord. For this they need not only the indwelling but also the filling of the Holy Spirit.

Lamps signify the spirit of the believers ([link]Prov. 20:27[/link]), which contains the Spirit of God as the oil ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link]). The believers shine forth the light of the Spirit of God from within their spirit. Thus, they become the light of the world and shine as a lamp in the darkness of this age ([link]5:14-16[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:15-16[/link]), bearing the testimony of the Lord for the glorification of God.
[i]Went forth[/i] signifies that the believers are going out of the world to meet the coming Christ.
The bridegroom signifies Christ as the pleasant and attractive person ([link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]Matt. 9:15[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]five of them were [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]foolish and [note]1[/note]five were [xref]c[/xref]prudent.
verse.note: Five is composed of four plus one, signifying that man (signified by four) with God (signified by one) added to him bears responsibility. The fact that five of the virgins are foolish and five are prudent does not indicate that half the believers are foolish and the other half are prudent. It indicates that all believers bear the responsibility of being filled with the Holy Spirit.
Being foolish does not make these five virgins false. In nature they are the same as the five prudent ones.

verse.text: For the foolish, when they took their lamps, did not take [note]1[/note]oil with them;
verse.note: Oil signifies the Holy Spirit ([link]Isa. 61:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]).

verse.text: But the prudent took oil in their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vessels with their lamps.
verse.note: Man is a vessel made for God ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link], [link]23-24[/link]), and man's personality is in his soul. Hence, [i]vessels[/i] here signifies the souls of the believers. The five prudent virgins not only have oil in their lamps but also take oil in their vessels. That they have oil in their lamps signifies that they have the Spirit of God dwelling in their spirit ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link], [link]16[/link]), and that they take oil in their vessels signifies that they have the Spirit of God filling and saturating their souls.

verse.text: And while the bridegroom [xref]a[/xref]delayed, they all became [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]drowsy and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]slept.
verse.note: Becoming drowsy signifies becoming sick ([link]Acts 9:37[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:30[/link]).
Sleep signifies death ([link]1 Thes. 4:13-16[/link]; [link]John 11:11-13[/link]). While the Lord delays His return, a majority of the believers become sick and then die.

verse.text: But at [note]1[/note]midnight there was a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]cry, Behold, the bridegroom! Go forth to [note]3[/note]meet him!
verse.note: Midnight signifies the darkest time of this dark age (night). That time will be the end of this age, the time of the great tribulation.
This cry signifies the voice of the archangel ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]).

A word different from [i]meet[/i] in [link]v. 1[/link]. The word in [link]v. 1[/link] refers to meeting someone alone and in secret, whereas the word here refers to meeting someone openly according to plan and ceremony.

verse.text: Then all those virgins [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]arose and [note]2[/note]trimmed their own lamps.
verse.note: [i]Arose[/i] signifies resurrection from the dead ([link]1 Thes. 4:14[/link]). This is the resurrection predicted in [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link] and [link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link].

Lit., adorned. [i]Trimmed their own lamps[/i] signifies the virgins' dealing with the testimony in their living. This indicates that after we are resurrected, our living for the Lord's testimony still needs to be dealt with if it has not been perfected before we die.

verse.text: And the foolish said to the prudent, [note]1[/note]Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are [note]2[/note]going out.
verse.note: This word implies that even after they are resurrected, the foolish believers will still need the filling of the Holy Spirit.

[i]Going out[/i] proves that the lamps of the foolish virgins were lighted; they contained some oil but did not have an adequate supply. The foolish virgins represent the believers who are regenerated with the Spirit of God and indwelt by the Spirit of God, but who have not been filled with Him sufficiently to have their whole being saturated with Him.

verse.text: But the prudent answered, saying, Perhaps there will [note]1[/note]not be enough for us and for you; go rather to [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]those who sell, and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]buy for yourselves.
verse.note: No one can obtain the filling of the Holy Spirit for others.

Here those who sell oil must be the two witnesses who appear during the great tribulation, the two olive trees and the two sons of oil ([link]Rev. 11:3-4[/link] and notes; [link]Zech. 4:11-14[/link]).

[i]Buy[/i] indicates that a price must be paid. Having the filling of the Holy Spirit is at a cost, such as giving up the world, dealing with self, loving the Lord above all, and counting all things loss for Christ. If we do not pay this price today, we will have to pay it after we are resurrected.

verse.text: And as they were going away to buy, the bridegroom [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]came; and [note]2[/note]those who were [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]ready [note]4[/note]went in with him to the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]wedding feast. And the [note]6[/note]door was [xref]d[/xref]shut.
verse.note: This is the Lord's coming to the air ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]), a part of His coming (parousia).
They must be those who are invited to the marriage dinner of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 19:9[/link] and note 1).

We should be ready ([link]24:44[/link]), always having oil in our vessel, always being filled with the Spirit of God in our whole being. Watching and being ready should be our daily exercise for the Lord's coming (parousia).
This is the rapture of the resurrected believers to the air ([link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link]) at the time that the Lord's coming (parousia) descends to the air.

This is the marriage dinner of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 19:9[/link]), which will be spread in the air ([link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link]) on the path of the Lord's coming (parousia). It will occur before the manifestation of the kingdom and will be a reward of mutual enjoyment with the Lord, a reward to be given to the believers who are ready, who are equipped with the filling of the Holy Spirit before they die.
This is not the door of salvation but the door through which one enters into the enjoyment of the Lord's wedding feast.

verse.text: And later the rest of the virgins [note]1[/note]came also, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Lord, lord, open to us!
verse.note: This is the resurrected believers' coming before the Lord at a later time; it occurs later because of their unreadiness.

verse.text: But he answered and said, Truly I say to you, I do [note]1[/note]not know you.
verse.note: [i]Not know[/i] here carries the sense of [i]not recognize, not approve,[/i] as in [link]Luke 13:25[/link]. The foolish virgins had their lamps lighted, went forth to meet the Lord, died, and were resurrected and raptured, but were late in paying the price for the filling of the Holy Spirit. Because of this the Lord would not recognize them, approve them, for participation in His wedding feast. They miss this dispensational reward but do not lose their eternal salvation.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Watch therefore, for you do not know the [xref]b[/xref]day nor the hour.
verse.note: This word, the same as in [link]24:42[/link], indicates that [link]vv. 1-13[/link] are a completion of [link]24:40-44[/link], a section on the believers' being watchful that they may be raptured. [link chapter="24"]Verses 40-44[/link] in [link]ch. 24[/link] unveil the rapture of living believers who are ready. [link chapter="25"]Verses 1-13[/link] of this chapter are needed to reveal the rapture of those who have died and are resurrected.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For [i]the[/i] [note]1[/note][i]kingdom of the heavens is[/i] just like a [note]2[/note]man about to go [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]abroad, who called his own [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]slaves and delivered to them [note]4[/note]his [xref]d[/xref]possessions.
verse.note: This parable of the talents, like the parable of the ten virgins, concerns the kingdom of the heavens.
The man here signifies Christ, who was about to go abroad, into the heavens.

Slaves signify believers viewed from the aspect of service ([link]1 Cor. 7:22-23[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:1[/link]; [link]James 1:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:1[/link]). The believers' status in relation to Christ is of two aspects: in life they are virgins living for Him; in service, in work, they are His purchased slaves serving Him.
[i]His possessions[/i] signifies the church ([link]Eph. 1:18[/link]) with all the believers, who constitute God's household ([link]24:45[/link]).

verse.text: To one he gave five [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]talents, and to another two, and to another one, to each according to his [note]2[/note]own ability. And he went abroad.
verse.note: A talent, the largest unit of weight, was worth six thousand denarii (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link]). In the parable of the virgins, oil signifies the Spirit of God ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]), whereas in this parable, talents signify spiritual gifts ([link]Rom. 12:6[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:4[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:10[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:6[/link]). For life we need oil, the Spirit of God, even His filling, that we may be enabled to live the virgin life for the Lord's testimony; for service, for work, we need the talent, the spiritual gift, that we may be equipped as a good slave to accomplish what the Lord intends to accomplish. The filling of the Spirit in life enables us to use the spiritual gift in service (work), and the spiritual gift in service matches the filling of the Spirit in life, that we may be a perfect member of Christ.
[i]Own ability[/i] signifies our natural ability, which is constituted of God's creation and our learning.

verse.text: Immediately he who had received the five talents went and [note]1[/note]traded with them and [note]2[/note]gained another five.
verse.note: [i]Traded with them[/i] (talents) signifies our using of the gift that the Lord has given us.
[i]Gained another five[/i] (talents) signifies that the gift we received from the Lord has been used to the fullest extent, without any loss or waste.

verse.text: Similarly, he [i]who had received[/i] the two gained another two.
But he who had received the [note]1[/note]one went off and [note]2[/note]dug in the earth and [note]3[/note]hid his master's money.
verse.note: The main emphasis in this parable is on the one-talented one, who received the smallest gift. It is very easy for the least gifted to mistreat or ignore their gift.

The earth signifies the world; thus, [i]dug in the earth[/i] signifies becoming involved in the world. Any association, any involvement, with the world, even a little worldly talk, will bury the gift we have received from the Lord.

[i]Hid his master's money[/i] signifies rendering the Lord's gift useless, letting it lie waste under the cloak of certain earthly excuses. To make any excuse for not using the Lord's gift is to hide the gift. This is always the danger with the one-talented ones, those who consider their gift to be the smallest.

verse.text: Now after a [note]1[/note]long time the master of those slaves [note]2[/note]came and [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]settled accounts with them.
verse.note: [i]A long time[/i] signifies the entire church age.

[i]Came[/i] signifies the Lord's descending to the air ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]) in His coming (parousia). After burying the talent in the earth, the evil slave thought that all would be well. Little did he know that his master would come to settle accounts with him.

[i]Settled accounts[/i] signifies the Lord's judging at His judgment seat ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link]) in the air (within His parousia), where the believers' living, conduct, and work will be judged for reward or punishment ([link]1 Cor. 4:5[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:13-15[/link]). See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link].

verse.text: And he who had received the five talents [note]1[/note]came and brought another five talents, saying, Master, you delivered to me five talents; behold, I have gained [note]2[/note]another five talents.
verse.note: This is to come to the judgment seat of Christ.
The gaining of another five talents is the result of the full use of the gift of the five talents.

verse.text: His master said to him, Well [i]done,[/i] good and [xref]a[/xref]faithful slave. You were faithful over a [note]1[/note]few things; I will [xref]b[/xref]set you [note]2[/note]over [note]3[/note]many things. Enter into the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]joy of your master.
verse.note: [i]A few things[/i] signifies the Lord's work in this age.
[i]Over[/i] signifies the ruling authority in the coming kingdom.
[i]Many things[/i] signifies the responsibilities in the coming kingdom.

[i]The joy of your master[/i] signifies the enjoyment of the Lord in the coming kingdom. This refers to inward satisfaction, not to outward position. To participate in the Lord's joy is the greatest reward, better than the glory and position in the kingdom.

verse.text: And he [i]who had received[/i] the two talents also came and said, Master, you delivered to me two talents; behold, I have gained another two talents.
His master said to him, [note]1[/note]Well [i]done,[/i] good and faithful slave. You were faithful over a few things; I will [note]2[/note]set you over many things. Enter into the joy of your master.
verse.note: This is the same appraisal the Lord gave to the five-talented one.

This is the same reward the Lord gave to the five-talented one. Although the gift given to the two-talented one was smaller than that given to the five-talented one, the Lord's appraisal and reward were the same in both cases. This indicates that the Lord's appraisal and reward are not related to the size and quantity of our work, but to our faithfulness in using His gift to the fullest extent. The same appraisal and reward would have been given to the one-talented one if he had been as faithful.

verse.text: Then he who had received the one talent also [note]1[/note]came and said, Master, I [note]2[/note]knew about you, that you are a [note]3[/note]hard man, reaping where you did [note]4[/note]not sow, and gathering where you did [note]4[/note]not [note]5[/note]winnow.
verse.note: The one-talented one also, who did not gain any profit for the Lord, came to the judgment seat of Christ in the air. This proves that he was not only saved but also raptured to the air. No unsaved person can be raptured and come to the judgment seat of Christ.
The Greek word refers to outward, objective knowledge, not to inward, subjective realization.
Apparently, the Lord is hard in His strictness. He demands that we use His gift to the fullest extent for His work, which requires our absoluteness.

Apparently, the Lord's work always begins from zero. Reaping where He did not sow and gathering where He did not winnow, He seemingly demands that we work for Him with nothing. This should not be an excuse for the one-talented one to neglect the use of his gift; rather, this should force him to exercise his faith so that he can use his gift to the uttermost.
Lit., scatter. So in [link]v. 26[/link].

verse.text: And I was [note]1[/note]afraid and [note]2[/note]went off and hid your talent in the earth; behold, [note]3[/note]you have what is yours.
verse.note: To be afraid is negative. We should, rather, be positive and aggressive in using the Lord's gift.
This is to be too passive. We should be active in the Lord's work.
Merely to keep the Lord's gift and not lose it is not sufficient; we must gain a profit by using it.

verse.text: And his master answered and said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Evil and [xref]b[/xref]slothful slave, you knew that [note]1[/note]I reap where I did not sow and gather where I did not winnow.
verse.note: The Lord admits that He is strict in what He demands of His slaves for His work.

verse.text: Therefore you should have [note]1[/note]deposited my money with the money changers; and when I came, I would have recovered what is mine with [note]2[/note]interest.
verse.note: This signifies the use of the Lord's gift to save people and to minister His riches to them.
[i]Interest[/i] signifies the profitable result we gain for the Lord's work by using His gift.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Take away therefore the talent from him and [note]2[/note]give [i]it[/i] to him who has the ten talents.
verse.note: This signifies that in the coming kingdom the Lord's gift will be taken away from slothful believers.
This signifies that the faithful believers' gift will be increased.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]to everyone who has, [i]more[/i] shall be given, and he shall abound; but from him who does not have, even that which he has shall be taken away from him.
verse.note: To everyone who gains profit in the church age, more gifts will be given in the coming kingdom age; but concerning the one who has not gained a profit in the church age, even the gift that he has will be taken away from him in the coming kingdom age.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cast out the useless slave into the [note]2[/note]outer darkness. In that place [note]3[/note]there will be the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

This word, the same as in [link]24:51[/link], indicates that [link]vv. 14-30[/link] are a completion of [link]24:45-51[/link]. Both sections concern faithfulness for the Lord's work. [link chapter="24"]Verses 45-51[/link] in [link]ch. 24[/link] deal with the slave's unfaithfulness in fulfilling the Lord's commission. [link chapter="25"]Verses 14-30[/link] in this chapter are needed so that the slave's unfaithfulness in using the Lord's talent can be dealt with.
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But when the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of Man [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]comes in His [note]4[/note]glory and all the angels with Him, at that time He will sit on the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]throne of His glory.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] indicates that what is spoken in [link]vv. 31-46[/link] is another section, the section concerning the Gentiles.
[i]Son of Man[/i] is the title of Christ in relation to His kingdom, the Messianic kingdom ([link]13:41[/link]). His judgment here is a preparation for that kingdom.

This is the open aspect of the Lord's coming. (See notes [link chapter="24"]27[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 24[/link].) It will be the continuation of His coming mentioned in [link]24:30[/link].

The Lord's glory comprises the glory of His divinity ([link]John 17:22[/link], [link]24[/link]), the glory of His humanity ([link]Psa. 45:3[/link]), the glory of His resurrection ([link]John 7:39[/link]; [link]Acts 3:13-15[/link]), and the glory of His ascension ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]).
The throne of David ([link]Luke 1:32-33[/link]), which will be in Jerusalem ([link]19:28[/link]; [link]Jer. 3:17[/link]).

verse.text: And all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nations will be gathered [xref]b[/xref]before Him, and He will separate them from one another, just as the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
verse.note: [i]All the nations[/i] refers to all the Gentiles who remain at Christ's coming back to the earth, after He has destroyed those Gentiles who follow Antichrist at Armageddon ([link]Rev. 16:14[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]19:11-15[/link], [link]19-21[/link]). These remaining Gentiles will all be gathered and judged at Christ's throne of glory. This will be Christ's judgment of the living before the millennium ([link]Acts 10:42[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:1[/link]). It differs from His judgment of the dead at the great white throne after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]) and will be executed on the earth after His judgment of the believers at His judgment seat in the air ([link]vv. 19-30[/link]).

The Lord is the Shepherd not only of the believers ([link]John 10:11[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:20[/link]) and the Jews ([link]Psa. 80:1[/link]; [link]Jer. 31:10[/link]) but also of all the Gentiles ([link]Psa. 100:1-3[/link]).

verse.text: And He will set the sheep on His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]right hand and the goats on the left.
verse.note: The place of honor ([link]1 Kings 2:19[/link]; [link]Psa. 45:9[/link]).

verse.text: Then the [xref]a[/xref]King will say to those on His right hand, Come, you who are [xref]b[/xref]blessed of My Father, [note]1[/note]inherit the kingdom prepared for you [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]from the foundation of the world.
verse.note: After the judgment at Christ's throne of glory, the "sheep" will be transferred into the millennium to be the people living under the kingly ruling of Christ and the overcoming believers ([link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]; [link]12:5[/link]; [link]20:4-6[/link]) and under the priestly ministry of the saved Jews ([link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]). In this way the "sheep" will inherit the (coming) kingdom. In the millennium there will be three sections: (1) the earth, where the blessing of God's creation will be, as mentioned in [link]Gen. 1:28-30[/link]; (2) the nation of Israel in Canaan, from the Nile to the Euphrates, from which the saved Jews will rule over the whole earth ([link]Isa. 60:10-12[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:16-18[/link]); and (3) the heavenly and spiritual section ([link]1 Cor. 15:50-52[/link]), the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, where the overcoming believers will enjoy the kingdom reward ([link]5:20[/link]; [link]7:21[/link]). The kingdom that the "sheep" will inherit consists of the first section.

The blessing of the first section in the millennium, the blessing of God's creation, was prepared for the "sheep" from the foundation of the world, whereas the blessing in the third section, the blessing of the heavenly and spiritual kingdom, was ordained for the believers before the foundation of the world ([link]Eph. 1:3-4[/link]).

verse.text: For I was [note]1[/note]hungry and you gave Me [i]something[/i] to eat; I was thirsty and you gave Me a [xref]a[/xref]drink; I was a stranger and you took Me in,
verse.note: All the sufferings in [link]vv. 35-39[/link] will befall the believers who are left to be tried ([link]Rev. 3:10[/link] and note 2) during the great tribulation ([link]24:21[/link]).

verse.text: Naked and you clothed Me; I was sick and you visited Me; I was in prison and you came to Me.
Then the righteous will answer Him, saying, Lord, when have we seen You hungry and have fed [i]You,[/i] or thirsty and have given [i]You[/i] a drink?
And when have we seen You a stranger and have taken [i]You[/i] in, or naked and have clothed [i]You?[/i]
And when have we seen You sick or in prison and have come to You?

And the King will answer and say to them, Truly I say to you, Inasmuch as you have [note]1[/note]done [i]it[/i] to one of [note]2[/note]these, the [xref]a[/xref]least of My [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]brothers, you have done [i]it[/i] to [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Me.
verse.note: This will happen in the great tribulation, when the believers suffer the persecution of Antichrist ([link]Rev. 13:6-7[/link]; [link]20:4[/link]).
[i]These[/i] should refer to the believers who overcome the persecution of Antichrist ([link]Rev. 15:2[/link] and note 2). They will be with Christ at this judgment.
Christ's brothers are His believers ([link]12:49-50[/link]).
Christ is one with the believers, who are His members, as indicated in [link]Acts 9:4[/link].

verse.text: Then He will say also to those on the left, Go away from Me, you who are cursed, into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eternal fire [note]2[/note]prepared for the devil and his [xref]b[/xref]angels.
verse.note: The fire in the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:14-15[/link]). The "goats" will perish in the lake of fire, after Antichrist and the false prophet ([link]Rev. 19:20[/link]) and before the devil and the resurrected sinners ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link], [link]15[/link]). This is part of the fulfillment of [link]Rev. 14:10[/link].

The lake of fire was prepared for the devil and his angels, not for man. However, if any man follows the devil in opposing the Lord, he will share the lake of fire with the devil and the fallen angels.

verse.text: For I was hungry and you did not give Me [i]anything[/i] to eat; I was thirsty and you did not give Me a drink;
I was a stranger and you did not take Me in; naked and you did not clothe Me; sick and in prison, and you did not visit Me.
Then they also will answer, saying, Lord, when have we seen You hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison and did not minister to You?
Then He will answer them, saying, Truly I say to you, Inasmuch as you [note]1[/note]did not do [i]it[/i] to one of the least of these, neither have you done [i]it[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]Me.
verse.note: This also will occur during Antichrist's persecution.

verse.text: And these shall go away into eternal [note]1[/note]punishment, but the [note]2[/note]righteous [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]into eternal life.
verse.note: This is to perish in the lake of fire ([link]v. 41[/link]).

So that the believers left on earth will be cared for during Antichrist's persecution, an eternal gospel will be preached to the nations ([link]Rev. 14:6-7[/link] and notes), as illustrated by the parable of the net in [link]13:47-50[/link]. The Lord will then judge the nations not according to the law of Moses or the gospel of Christ, but according to the eternal gospel. This is a matter of God's dispensation. Those who obey that gospel and treat the suffering believers well will be blessed and reckoned as righteous and will inherit the kingdom ([link]v. 34[/link]); but those who do not will be cursed ([link]v. 41[/link]) and will perish for eternity.

The gospel of grace ([link]Acts 20:24[/link]) brings eternal life into the believers ([link]John 3:15-16[/link]) that they may live by God's life, whereas the eternal gospel brings the "sheep" into eternal life that they may live in the sphere of God's life.

verse.text: And when Jesus finished all these words, He said to His disciples,
You know that after two days the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Passover takes place, and the Son of Man is being [xref]b[/xref]delivered up to be crucified.
verse.note: The Passover was a type of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]). Christ was made the Lamb of God that God may pass over us, the sinners, as portrayed in type by the passover in [link]Exo. 12[/link]. For the fulfillment of the type, Christ as the Passover lamb had to be killed on the day of the Passover.[br][br]In the type, during the four days preceding the day of the Passover, the Passover lamb had to be examined in relation to its perfection ([link]Exo. 12:3-6[/link]). Before His crucifixion Christ came to Jerusalem for the last time, six days before the Passover ([link]John 12:1[/link]), and likewise was examined by the Jewish leaders for a few days ([link]21:23-22:46[/link]). No blemish was found in Him, and He was proved to be perfect and qualified to be the Passover lamb for us. See note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link].

verse.text: Then the chief priests and the elders of the people were [xref]a[/xref]gathered together in the courtyard of the high priest, who was called [xref]b[/xref]Caiaphas,
And they took [xref]a[/xref]counsel together to [xref]b[/xref]seize Jesus by craftiness and [xref]c[/xref]kill [i]Him.[/i]
But they said, [note]1[/note]Not at the feast, lest there be an [xref]a[/xref]uproar among the people.
verse.note: Eventually, under God's sovereignty they did kill the Lord Jesus at the feast ([link]27:15[/link]) for the fulfillment of the type.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now when Jesus was in [xref]b[/xref]Bethany, in the house of Simon the [note]1[/note]leper,
verse.note: A leper signifies a sinner ([link]8:2[/link] and note 1). Simon, a leper, must have been healed by the Lord. Being grateful to the Lord and loving Him, he spread a feast ([link]v. 7[/link]) in his house for the Lord and His disciples in order to enjoy His presence. A saved sinner would always do this.

verse.text: A woman came to Him, having an alabaster flask of ointment of great value, and she poured [i]it[/i] on His head as He reclined [i]at table.[/i]
But when the disciples saw [i]it,[/i] they were indignant, saying, Why this [note]1[/note]waste?
verse.note: The disciples considered Mary's love offering to the Lord a waste. Throughout the past twenty centuries thousands of precious lives, heart treasures, high positions, and golden futures have been "wasted" upon the Lord Jesus. To those who love Him in such a way He is altogether lovely and worthy of their offering. What they have poured upon Him is not a waste but a fragrant testimony of His sweetness.

verse.text: For this could have been sold for much and given to the [xref]a[/xref]poor.
But Jesus, knowing [i]it,[/i] said to them, Why do you trouble the woman? She has done a noble deed to Me.
For the [xref]a[/xref]poor you have with you always, [note]1[/note]but you do [xref]b[/xref]not always have Me.
verse.note: We must love the Lord and grasp the opportunity to love Him.

verse.text: For in pouring out this ointment on My body, she has done [i]it[/i] [note]1[/note]for My [xref]a[/xref]burial.
verse.note: Mary received the revelation of the Lord's death through the Lord's words in [link]16:21[/link]; [link]17:22-23[/link]; [link]20:18-19[/link]; and [link chapter="26"]v. 2[/link] of this chapter. Hence, she grasped the opportunity to pour upon the Lord the best that she had. To love the Lord with our best requires a revelation concerning Him.

verse.text: Truly I say to you, Wherever [note]1[/note]this [xref]a[/xref]gospel is proclaimed in the whole world, [note]2[/note]what this woman has done shall also be told as a [xref]b[/xref]memorial of her.
verse.note: In the foregoing verse the Lord spoke of His burial, implying His death and resurrection, accomplished for our redemption. Hence, in this verse He called the gospel "this gospel," referring to the gospel of His death, burial, and resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:1-4[/link]).

The story of the gospel is that the Lord loved us, and the story of Mary is that she loved the Lord. We must preach both — the Lord's loving us and our loving the Lord. One is for our salvation, and the other is for our consecration.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]At that time one of the twelve, the one called [xref]b[/xref]Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
verse.note: [i]At that time[/i] indicates that while one of the disciples was expressing her love to the Lord, loving Him to the uttermost, another was about to betray Him. One was treasuring the Lord, and at the same time another was delivering Him up.

verse.text: And said, What are you willing to give me, and I will deliver Him to you? And they weighed out to him [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thirty pieces of silver.
verse.note: I.e., thirty shekels of silver, the worth of a slave ([link]Exo. 21:32[/link]).

verse.text: And from then on he sought opportunity to [xref]a[/xref]deliver Him up.

[xref]a[/xref]Now on the first day of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref][i]Feast of[/i] Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying, Where do You want us to prepare for You to eat the passover?
verse.note: The Feast of Unleavened Bread is a feast of seven days ([link]Lev. 23:6[/link]). It is also called the Passover ([link]Luke 22:1[/link]; [link]Mark 14:1[/link]). Actually, the Feast of the Passover was the first day of the Feast of Unleavened Bread ([link]Exo. 12:6[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]15-20[/link]; [link]Lev. 23:5[/link]).

verse.text: And He said, Go into the city to a certain man and say to him, The [xref]a[/xref]Teacher says, My [xref]b[/xref]time is near. I am keeping the passover at your [i]house[/i] with My disciples.
And the disciples did as Jesus directed them, and they prepared the passover.
[xref]a[/xref]And when evening fell, He reclined [i]at table[/i] with the twelve.
And as they were eating, He said, Truly I say to you that [xref]a[/xref]one of you will betray Me.
And being greatly grieved, each one of them began to say to Him, I am not [i]the one,[/i] am I, Lord?
And He answered and said, The one who dips his hand with Me in the dish, this one will betray Me.

The Son of Man is going away, even as it is [xref]a[/xref]written concerning Him, but woe to that man through whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been good for that man if he had not been born.
And Judas, who was betraying Him, answered and said, I am not [i]the one,[/i] am I, [xref]a[/xref]Rabbi? He said to him, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]You have said [i]it[/i] yourself.
verse.note: The Lord let Judas's own word condemn him.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as they were [note]1[/note]eating, Jesus took [note]2[/note]bread and [xref]b[/xref]blessed [i]it,[/i] and He broke [i]it[/i] and gave [i]it[/i] to the disciples and said, Take, eat; this is My [note]2[/note]body.
verse.note: The Lord and the disciples first ate the passover ([link]vv. 20-25[/link]; [link]Luke 22:14-18[/link]). Then the Lord established His table with the bread and the cup ([link]vv. 26-28[/link]; [link]Luke 22:19-20[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:23-26[/link]) to replace the Feast of the Passover because He was going to fulfill the type and be the real Passover to us ([link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]). Now we are keeping the real Feast of Unleavened Bread ([link]v. 17[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 5:8[/link]).

The bread of the Lord's table is a symbol signifying the Lord's body, which was broken for us on the cross to release His life that we may participate in it. By participating in this life we become the mystical Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:27[/link]), which also is signified by the bread of the table ([link]1 Cor. 10:17[/link]). Hence, by partaking of this bread we have the fellowship of the Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 10:16[/link]).

verse.text: And He took a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cup and gave [xref]b[/xref]thanks, and He gave [i]it[/i] to them, saying, Drink of it, all [i]of you,[/i]
verse.note: The Lord's blood redeemed us from our fallen condition back to God and back to God's full blessing. Concerning the Lord's table ([link]1 Cor. 10:21[/link]), the bread signifies our participation in life, and the cup, our enjoyment of God's blessing. Hence, the cup is called "the cup of blessing" ([link]1 Cor. 10:16[/link]). In it are all the blessings of God and even God Himself as our portion ([link]Psa. 16:5[/link]). In Adam our portion was the cup of God's wrath ([link]Rev. 14:10[/link]). Christ drank that cup for us ([link]John 18:11[/link]), and His blood constitutes the cup of salvation for us ([link]Psa. 116:13[/link]), the cup that runs over ([link]Psa. 23:5[/link]). By partaking of this cup we have the fellowship of the blood of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 10:16[/link]).

verse.text: For this is My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant, which is being poured out for [xref]c[/xref]many for [xref]d[/xref]forgiveness of sins.
verse.note: The product of the vine ([link]v. 29[/link]) within the cup of the Lord's table also is a symbol, signifying the Lord's blood shed on the cross for our sins. His blood was required by God's righteousness for the forgiveness of our sins ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]).

Some MSS insert, new. The Lord's blood, having satisfied God's righteousness, enacted the new covenant. In this new covenant God gives us forgiveness, life, salvation, and all spiritual, heavenly, and divine blessings. When this new covenant is given to us, it is a cup ([link]Luke 22:20[/link]), a portion for us. The Lord shed His blood, God established the covenant, and we enjoy the cup, in which God and all that is of Him are our portion. The blood is the price that Christ paid for us, the covenant is the title deed that God made for us, and the cup is the portion that we receive from God.

verse.text: But I say to you, I shall by no means drink of this [note]1[/note]product of the vine from now on until that day when I drink it new with you in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of My Father.
verse.note: Referring to the juice of the grape.
This is the heavenly part of the millennium, the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens, in which the Lord will drink with us after His coming back.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And after [note]1[/note]singing a hymn, they went out to the [xref]b[/xref]Mount of Olives.
verse.note: This was a praise to the Father sung by the Lord with the disciples after the Lord's table.

verse.text: Then Jesus said to them, You will all be stumbled because of Me this night, for it is written, "I will [xref]a[/xref]smite the Shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be [xref]b[/xref]scattered."
But after I have been raised, I will go before you into [xref]a[/xref]Galilee.
Then Peter answered and said to Him, If all will be stumbled because of You, I will never be stumbled.
Jesus said to him, Truly I say to you that in this night, before a [xref]a[/xref]rooster crows, you will deny Me three times.
Peter said to Him, Even if I must [xref]a[/xref]die with You, I will by no means deny You. And all the disciples said likewise.
[xref]a[/xref]Then Jesus came with them to a [xref]b[/xref]place called [note]1[/note]Gethsemane, and He said to the disciples, Sit here while I go over there and pray.
verse.note: [i]Gethsemane[/i] means [i]oil press.[/i] At Gethsemane the Lord was pressed so that the oil, the Holy Spirit, could flow out.

verse.text: And taking Peter and the two [xref]a[/xref]sons of Zebedee aside, He began to be sorrowful and deeply distressed.
Then He said to them, My [xref]a[/xref]soul is exceedingly sorrowful, even to death. Remain here and watch with Me.

And going forward a little, He fell on His face and [xref]a[/xref]prayed, saying, My Father, if it is possible, let this [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]cup pass from Me; yet not as I [xref]c[/xref]will, but as You [i]will.[/i]
verse.note: Referring to His death on the cross.

verse.text: And He came to the disciples and found them sleeping. And He said to Peter, So were you not able to watch with Me for one hour?
[xref]a[/xref]Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The [note]1[/note]spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.
verse.note: In spiritual things we are often like this.

verse.text: Again, going away a second time, He prayed, saying, My Father, if this cannot pass away unless I drink it, Your [xref]a[/xref]will be done.
And coming again, He found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
And leaving them, He went away again and prayed a [xref]a[/xref]third time, saying the same word again.
Then He came to the disciples and said to them, Are you still sleeping and resting? Behold, the [xref]a[/xref]hour has drawn near, and the Son of Man is being delivered up into the hands of sinners.
Arise, let us be going. Behold, the one who is betraying Me has drawn near.
[xref]a[/xref]And while He was still speaking, behold, [xref]b[/xref]Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
Now the one who was betraying Him had given them a sign, saying, Whomever I kiss, He is the one; seize Him.
And immediately he came to Jesus and said, [note]1[/note]Rejoice, [xref]a[/xref]Rabbi, and [xref]b[/xref]kissed Him affectionately.
verse.note: A word of greeting, here and in [link]27:29[/link]. Both greetings were false (cf. [link]28:9[/link]).

verse.text: But Jesus said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Friend, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]what are you here for? Then they came and laid hands on Jesus and seized Him.
verse.note: This word is equivalent to: "What are you doing here? You are betraying Me!" This word was spoken to expose Judas's evil intention to betray the Lord.

verse.text: And behold, [note]1[/note]one of those with Jesus stretched out his hand and drew his [xref]a[/xref]sword, and struck the slave of the high priest and took off his [xref]b[/xref]ear.
verse.note: This was Peter ([link]John 18:10[/link], [link]26[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus said to him, Return your sword to its place, for all those who take up the [xref]a[/xref]sword will perish by the sword.
Or do you think that I cannot [note]1[/note]beseech My Father, and He will [note]1[/note]provide Me at once with more than twelve [note]1[/note]legions of [xref]a[/xref]angels?
verse.note: In Greek these three words are military terms.

verse.text: How then shall the [xref]a[/xref]Scriptures be fulfilled [i]which say[/i] that it must happen [note]1[/note]this way?
verse.note: [i]This way[/i] refers to His death on the cross, which was prophesied in the Scriptures. These prophecies had to be fulfilled.

verse.text: In that hour Jesus said to the crowds, Have you come out as against a robber with swords and clubs to arrest Me? Day after day I sat in the temple [xref]a[/xref]teaching, and you did not seize Me.
But all this has happened in order that the writings of the prophets may be fulfilled. Then all the disciples left Him and [xref]a[/xref]fled.
[xref]a[/xref]And those who seized Jesus led [i]Him[/i] away to [xref]b[/xref]Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had gathered.
And Peter [xref]a[/xref]followed Him at a distance to the courtyard of the high priest; and entering within, he sat with the attendants to see the end.
Now the chief priests and the whole [xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin were seeking [xref]b[/xref]false testimony against Jesus so that they might put Him to death,
And they did not find [i]it,[/i] though many false witnesses came forward. But later [xref]a[/xref]two came
And said, This man said, [note]1[/note]I am able to [xref]a[/xref]destroy the temple of God and build [i]it[/i] up in three days.
verse.note: This was a twisting of the Lord's word in [link]John 2:19[/link], "[You] destroy this temple."

verse.text: And the high priest stood up and said to Him, Do You answer [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nothing? What [i]is it that[/i] these testify [xref]b[/xref]against You?
verse.note: The Lord, standing before the Sanhedrin like a sheep before its shearers, would not say a word to vindicate Himself, fulfilling [link]Isa. 53:7[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus remained [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]silent. [xref]b[/xref]And the high priest said to Him, I charge You to [xref]c[/xref]swear by the living God to tell us [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]if You are the [xref]e[/xref]Christ, the Son of God.
verse.note: See note [link]62[sup]1[/sup][/link].
This is the same question that the devil asked in tempting the Lord before He began His ministry ([link]4:3[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus said to him, [xref]a[/xref]You have said [i]rightly.[/i] Nevertheless I say to you, From now on you will see the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of Man [xref]c[/xref]sitting at the right hand of Power and [xref]d[/xref]coming on the [xref]e[/xref]clouds of heaven.
verse.note: The high priest asked the Lord if He was the Son of God, but He answered with "the Son of Man." In His temptation He had answered the devil in the same way ([link]4:4[/link] and note 2). The Lord was the Son of Man on the earth before His crucifixion, has been the Son of Man in the heavens at the right hand of God since His resurrection ([link]Acts 7:56[/link]), and will be the Son of Man even at His coming back on the clouds. To accomplish God's purpose and to establish the kingdom of the heavens, the Lord had to be a man. Without man, God's purpose could not be carried out on earth, nor could the kingdom of the heavens be constituted on earth.

verse.text: Then the high priest [xref]a[/xref]tore his garments, saying, He has [xref]b[/xref]blasphemed! What further need do we have of witnesses? Behold, now you have heard the blasphemy.
What do you think? And they answered and said, He is worthy of [xref]a[/xref]death.
Then they [xref]a[/xref]spat in His face and beat Him with their fists, and others [xref]b[/xref]slapped [i]Him,[/i]
Saying, [note]1[/note]Prophesy to us, Christ! [xref]a[/xref]Who is the one who hit You?
verse.note: I.e., speak forth miraculously as a prophet. This mocking word implies, "Since You are a prophet of God, prophesy miraculously to identify the one who hit You."

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard, and a [note]1[/note]servant girl came to him and said, You also were with Jesus the Galilean.
verse.note: Peter could not withstand even a fragile little female!

verse.text: But he denied [i]it[/i] before all, saying, I do not know what you are talking about!
And after he had gone out to the porch, another girl saw him and said to those who were there, This man was with Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene.
And again he denied with an oath, I do not know the man!

And after a little while [note]1[/note]those who were standing [i]there[/i] came to Peter and said, Surely you also are one of them, for your [xref]a[/xref]speech also makes it clear [i]that[/i] you [i]are.[/i]
verse.note: Under God's sovereignty the environment would not let Peter go until he had been tested to the uttermost, that he might realize that he was absolutely untrustworthy and should no longer have any confidence in himself.

verse.text: Then he began to [note]1[/note]curse and to swear: I do not know the man! And immediately a rooster crowed.
verse.note: In his first denial Peter spoke words only ([link]v. 70[/link]); in his second denial he replied with an oath ([link]v. 72[/link]); in his third denial he cursed and swore.

verse.text: And Peter remembered the word which Jesus had said, Before a [xref]a[/xref]rooster crows, you will deny Me three times. And he went out and wept bitterly.
[xref]a[/xref]Now when morning had come, all the chief priests and the elders of the people took [xref]b[/xref]counsel against Jesus to put Him to death.
And having bound Him, they led [i]Him[/i] away and delivered [i]Him[/i] to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pilate the governor.
verse.note: Pilate, an agent of Caesar Tiberius, was a Roman procurator in Judea (Palestine) from A.D. 26-35. Not long after he unjustly delivered up the Lord Jesus to be crucified, his rule ended abruptly. He was banished and committed suicide.[br][br]In the evil conspiracy the Jewish religionists convinced the heathen politician to collaborate with them to kill the Lord Jesus.

verse.text: Then [xref]a[/xref]Judas, who betrayed Him, seeing that He was condemned, [note]1[/note]regretted and returned the [xref]b[/xref]thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
verse.note: Or, repented.

verse.text: Saying, I have sinned in betraying [xref]a[/xref]innocent blood. But they said, What is that to us? You see [i]to that[/i] yourself!
And he threw the pieces of silver into the temple and departed, and he went away and [xref]a[/xref]hanged himself.
And the [note]1[/note]chief priests took the pieces of silver and said, It is not lawful to put them into the [note]2[/note]temple [xref]a[/xref]treasury, since it is blood money.
verse.note: They would not take blood money. Actually, what they did to the Lord Jesus was more evil than Judas's deed ([link]v. 1[/link]).
A chest or place in the temple where the gifts offered to God were kept.

verse.text: And after taking counsel, they bought with it the potter's field as a burial place for strangers.
Therefore that field has been called the [xref]a[/xref]Field of Blood to this day.

At that time what was spoken through [note]1[/note]Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled, saying, [xref]a[/xref]"And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of Him that had been priced, whom they of the sons of Israel had priced,
verse.note: The word quoted in [link]vv. 9-10[/link] was spoken by Jeremiah but recorded in Zechariah ([link]Zech. 11:12-13[/link]). There was an idea among the Jews that Zechariah had the spirit of Jeremiah.

verse.text: And they gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord directed me."
[xref]a[/xref]And Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor questioned Him, saying, Are You the [xref]b[/xref]King of the Jews? And Jesus said, [xref]c[/xref]It is as you say.
And while He was being accused by the chief priests and elders, He answered [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nothing.
verse.note: The Lord would not vindicate Himself.

verse.text: Then Pilate said to Him, Do You not hear how many things they testify [xref]a[/xref]against You?
And He did [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not answer him, not even to one word, so that the governor marveled greatly.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now at the feasts the governor was accustomed to release to the crowd one prisoner whom they wanted.
And they had at that time a notorious prisoner named Barabbas.
Therefore when they were gathered together, Pilate said to them, [note]1[/note]Whom do you want me to release to you? Barabbas or Jesus who is called Christ?
verse.note: It was unjust of Pilate to ask this question, for he knew that the Lord was innocent ([link]v. 18[/link]) and that Barabbas was guilty.

verse.text: For he knew that [i]it was[/i] because of envy [i]that[/i] they had delivered Him up.

And while he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent [i]word[/i] to him, saying, Have nothing to do with that [xref]a[/xref]righteous man, for I have suffered much today in a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]dream because of Him.
verse.note: This was sovereign of God.

verse.text: But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to [xref]a[/xref]ask for Barabbas and to destroy Jesus.
And the governor answered and said to them, Which of the two do you want me to release to you? And they said, Barabbas.
Pilate said to them, What then shall I do with Jesus who is called Christ? They all said, Let Him be crucified!
But he said, Why, [xref]a[/xref]what evil has He done? But they cried out the more, saying, Let Him be crucified!

And Pilate, seeing that nothing was gained but rather that an [xref]a[/xref]uproar was taking place, took water and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]washed his hands before the crowd, saying, [note]2[/note]I am innocent of this [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]man's blood. You see [i]to it[/i] yourselves.
verse.note: This was to appease his conscience.
A timid and irresponsible withdrawal.
Some MSS add, righteous.

verse.text: And all the people answered and said, His [xref]a[/xref]blood be upon us and upon our children!
Then he released to them Barabbas, but Jesus he [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scourged and delivered up to be [note]2[/note]crucified.
verse.note: This utterly exposed the darkness and injustice of politics! This injustice fulfilled [link]Isa. 53:5[/link], [link]8[/link].

The Jewish death penalty was carried out by stoning ([link]Lev. 20:2[/link], [link]27[/link]; [link]24:14[/link]; [link]Deut. 13:10[/link]; [link]17:5[/link]). Crucifixion was a heathen practice ([link]Ezra 6:11[/link]) adopted by the Romans for the execution of slaves and heinous criminals only. The Lord Jesus' being crucified was a fulfillment not only of the Old Testament prophecies ([link]Deut. 21:23[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:13[/link]; [link]Num. 21:8-9[/link]) but also of the Lord's word concerning how He would die ([link]John 3:14[/link]; [link]8:28[/link]; [link]12:32[/link]). These could not have been fulfilled by stoning. See note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in John 18[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then the governor's soldiers took Jesus into the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]praetorium and gathered about Him the whole cohort.
verse.note: I.e., the governor's official residence.

verse.text: And they stripped Him and put a scarlet robe around Him,

And they wove a crown of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thorns and placed [i]it[/i] on His head and [i]put[/i] a reed in His right hand; and they kneeled before Him and [xref]b[/xref]mocked Him, saying, [note]2[/note]Rejoice, King of the Jews!
verse.note: Thorns are a symbol of the curse ([link]Gen. 3:17-18[/link]). On the cross the Lord Jesus became a curse for us ([link]Gal. 3:13[/link]).
A mocking salutation or congratulation. The same Greek word as in [link]26:49[/link].

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]spat on Him and took the reed and beat Him on the head.
And when they had mocked Him, they stripped Him of the robe and put His garments on Him, and [note]1[/note]led Him away to crucify [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: The Lord, as the Passover lamb to be sacrificed for our sins, was brought like a lamb to the slaughter, fulfilling [link]Isa. 53:7-8[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And as they were going out, they found a man of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Cyrene, Simon by name; this one they compelled to take up His cross.
verse.note: Cyrene was a Greek colonial city, the capital of Cyrenaica in North Africa. It seems that Simon was a Cyrenian Jew.

verse.text: And when they had come to a place called [note]1[/note]Golgotha, that is to say, Place of a Skull,
verse.note: [i]Golgotha[/i] is a Hebrew word ([link]John 19:17[/link]) that means [i]skull[/i] ([link]Mark 15:22[/link]). Its equivalent in Latin is [i]Calvaria,[/i] anglicized as [i]Calvary[/i] ([link]Luke 23:33[/link], KJV). It does not mean [i]a place of[/i] dead men's skulls, but simply [i]skull.[/i]

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]They gave Him [note]1[/note]wine to drink, mingled with [xref]b[/xref]gall. And when He tasted [i]it,[/i] He would [note]2[/note]not drink.
verse.note: Wine mingled with gall (and also with myrrh — [link]Mark 15:23[/link]) was used as a stupefying drink.
The Lord would not be stupefied; He would drink the bitter cup to the dregs.

verse.text: And when they had crucified Him, they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]divided His garments [i]among themselves,[/i] casting lots.
verse.note: The Lord was robbed to the uttermost by sinners, fulfilling [link]Psa. 22:18[/link]. This too exposed the darkness of Roman politics.

verse.text: And they sat down and [xref]a[/xref]guarded Him there.
[xref]a[/xref]And they set in writing over His head the charge against Him: THIS IS JESUS, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
At that time [xref]a[/xref]two [note]1[/note]robbers were crucified with Him, one on the right and one on the left.
verse.note: This was for the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 53:9a[/link].

verse.text: And those who were passing by blasphemed Him, [xref]a[/xref]wagging their heads
And saying, You who [xref]a[/xref]destroy the temple and build it up in three days, [xref]b[/xref]save Yourself! [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]If You are the Son of God, come down from the cross!
verse.note: This was a repetition of the devil's temptation in the wilderness ([link]4:6[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Likewise also the chief priests with the scribes and elders mocked [i]Him[/i] and said,
He saved others; Himself He [note]1[/note]cannot save. He is [xref]a[/xref]King of Israel; let Him come down now from the cross, and we will believe on Him.
verse.note: If He had saved Himself, He could not save us.

verse.text: He trusts in God; let Him [xref]a[/xref]rescue [i]Him[/i] now if He wants Him, for He said, I am the Son of God.
And in the same way the robbers who were crucified with Him also [xref]a[/xref]reproached Him.
[xref]a[/xref]Now from the [note]1[/note]sixth hour darkness fell over all the land until the [note]1[/note]ninth hour.
verse.note: The sixth hour was 12:00 noon, and the ninth was 3:00 p.m. The Lord was crucified from the third hour, 9:00 a.m. ([link]Mark 15:25[/link]), until the ninth hour, 3:00 p.m. He suffered on the cross for six hours. In the first three hours He was persecuted by men for doing God's will; in the last three hours He was judged by God to accomplish our redemption. It was during this time that God counted Him as our Substitute who suffered for our sin ([link]Isa. 53:10[/link]). Darkness fell over all the land ([link]v. 45[/link]) because our sin and sins and all negative things were being dealt with there; and because of our sin God forsook Him ([link]v. 46[/link]).

verse.text: And about the [note]1[/note]ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani? that is, [xref]a[/xref]My God, My God, [note]2[/note]why have You forsaken Me?
verse.note: See note [link]45[sup]1[/sup][/link].

God forsook Christ on the cross because He took the place of sinners ([link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]) — He bore our sins ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:6[/link]) and was made sin for us ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]).

verse.text: And some of those standing there, when they heard [i]this,[/i] said, This man is calling Elijah.
And immediately one of them ran, and taking a sponge, he soaked it with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vinegar and put it on a reed, and gave [i]it[/i] to Him to drink.
verse.note: Offered to the Lord in a mocking way ([link]Luke 23:36[/link]) for quenching His thirst ([link]John 19:28-30[/link] and note [link]30[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: But the rest said, Let [i]Him be.[/i] Let us see if Elijah is coming to save Him.
And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]yielded up His spirit.
verse.note: This was His giving up of His spirit ([link]John 19:30[/link]); it indicates that the Lord voluntarily yielded up His life ([link]Mark 15:37[/link]; [link]Luke 23:46[/link]).

verse.text: And behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]veil of the temple was split in two [note]2[/note]from top to bottom, and the [note]3[/note]earth was shaken and the [note]4[/note]rocks were split,
verse.note: This signifies that the separation between God and man had been abolished because the flesh of sin (the flesh being signified by the veil) taken by Christ ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]) had been crucified ([link]Heb. 10:20[/link] and note 2).
[i]From top to bottom[/i] indicates that the rending of the veil was God's doing from above.
This signifies that the base of Satan's rebellion was shaken.
This signifies that the strongholds of Satan's earthly kingdom were broken.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]tombs were opened, and many [note]2[/note]bodies of the saints who had fallen [xref]a[/xref]asleep were raised.
verse.note: This signifies that the power of death and Hades was conquered and subdued.
This signifies the releasing power of the death of Christ.

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note]came out of the tombs after His resurrection and entered into the holy city and [note]2[/note]appeared to many.
verse.note: In the type, the firstfruits of the harvest ([link]Lev. 23:10-11[/link]) were not a single stalk of wheat but a sheaf of wheat, typifying not only the resurrected Christ but also the saints who were raised from the dead after His resurrection, as seen here.[br][br]All the things listed in [link]vv. 51-53[/link] are different aspects of the excellent effect of the Lord's death.
Where they went after this we have no way to trace.

verse.text: Now the centurion and those with him [xref]a[/xref]guarding Jesus, when they saw the earthquake and the things that happened, became greatly frightened, saying, Truly this was the [xref]b[/xref]Son of God.
And many women were there looking on from a distance, who had followed Jesus from Galilee, [xref]a[/xref]ministering to Him,
Among whom were [xref]a[/xref]Mary the Magdalene, and [note]1[/note]Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the [xref]b[/xref]mother of the sons of Zebedee.
verse.note: The mother of the Lord Jesus ([link]13:55[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And when [note]1[/note]evening fell, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who himself had also become a disciple of Jesus.
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in John 19[/link].

verse.text: This man came to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded that it be given [i]to him.[/i]
And Joseph took the body and wrapped it in a clean, fine linen cloth.

And he [note]1[/note]laid it in his [i]own[/i] [xref]a[/xref]new tomb, which he had [xref]b[/xref]hewn in the rock. And having rolled a [xref]c[/xref]great stone in front of the door of the tomb, he went away.
verse.note: This was for the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 53:9b[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Mary the Magdalene was there, and the other Mary, sitting opposite the grave.
On the next day, which is [i]the day[/i] after the [note]1[/note]preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered unto Pilate,
verse.note: This was the day of preparation, Friday, when the passover was prepared ([link]26:19[/link]; [link]John 19:14[/link]).

verse.text: Saying, Sir, we have remembered that while He was still living, that [xref]a[/xref]deceiver said, [xref]b[/xref]After three days I will arise.

Therefore, give orders for the grave to be secured until the third day, lest His disciples come and [xref]a[/xref]steal Him away and say to the people, He has been raised from the dead. And the last deception will be worse than the first.
